reviews.review: Hong Kong is actually green. A lot of people (including some locals) have the misconception that Hong Kong is a concrete jungle. The truth is, only the central business district and some "new towns" in Hong Kong can be described as a concrete jungle. Most areas in Hong Kong are green green GREEN hills, covered entirely in grass and trees. Go for a hike on Dragon's Back and you'll know what I mean. The starting point and ending point of the trail are conveniently located. The views at some high points of the trail are breath-taking. Bring a lot of water though - you'll want to drink it.

A different side of Hong Kong. Nice hike if you fancy a change from the hustle and bustle of the city. Beautiful views of the sea, the islands and the hills - you would never think Hong Kong has this side to it! The trek is not too challenging but I would definitely advise wearing proper sports shoes as it does get a bit steep and rocky in places, and stock up on water and few snack for the road :)

Really the best trail. I read it's review which says it's the most beautiful trail in hongkong. And now when I have visited it already I really agree with that. I have been to lots of trails in hongkong, but this one will at the top of my list. As far as difficulty is concerned, the beginning 40-50min will be really difficult but last 2hr or so will easy when getting down to the big wave bay. One you reach the peak, you get a awesome view as as one your way to peak.

Was there finally on a cool fine day!. I read about it from Tripadvisor, funny. Never been to Dragon's Back even I am from Hong Kong; finally went for a hike last Saturday, walked for two hours, stunning view on a cool fine day!

Excellent Hiking holiday. My partner and i decided to incorporate some exercise into our holiday and we decided to take the Dragon back hike using the hong kong trail route. this route is pretty short, about 4-5km by estimation and we could have completed it in 1.5h but we decided to do a little picnic at the top with fanatic view and delicious dim sum we brought along. Please do remember to clear your own trash as we seen some lying around by others, thats just sad...

Great Views Over Shek O. If you're fit, even just a little bit, this is a very easy hike, you can reach the top in 15-30 minutes unless you're really taking it easy. Gets very busy weekends so try on a weekday and only go in good weather as otherwise it's pointless. There's a number of options you can take, the best is to start at Shek O Road, almost near Shek O, then end up at Big Wave Bay, plenty of sites to give you directions if you Google it. If you're into hiking or just want to escape the city, Dragons Back is definitely worth it and can be done in a morning or afternoon.

Great walk with amzing views. Not overly challenging but worth the trek for the amazing views from the top. A cold drink in Big Wave Bay is your reward for completing the walk. Some parts of the path are a bit challenging and I would avoid the hike after rain as it can get slippery.
Great hiking trail. The Dragon's Back trail is one way to go to the Big Wave Beach from Shek O. It is strenuous and takes about 2 hours, so take water!
Amazing Hike. At the top you get to see some of the most beautiful scenery. It is a little ways outside of HK but so worth the trip!

The greener pasture of Hong Kong. Loved this side of Hong Kong- away from the dense, cluttered, hustle bustle of a city life. A simple MTR ride to Shau Kei Wan station and exit A3 to the bus terminal. Signs will be everywhere directing one to the bus heading towards Dragon's back trail, alternatively look for like-minded people carrying backpacks or in trekking attire. A pleasant 2.5h walk from start to end (which is the Shek O' beach or Big Wave Bay). The total distance covered would be about 8.5km. A scenic view at the peak. Some may choose to turn back to the start after conquering the peak. But we kept walking till we saw more directions, leading us to the beach. The waves were huge! If you could surf, go for it. Perfect waves for surfers. A direct bus ride from the beach would bring you back to the bus terminal. Simple! Bring along water and some bites, but please don't leave the garbage behind. Respect the nature :)

Nice view!. The hike in itself took us about two hours. On a scale from 1-10 in terms of how difficult it was I would estimate a 5.The view of Big Wave Bay, and the corresponding beaches is breath taking and totally worth the strenuous physical effort! I would recommend, once you arrive to the beach, to reward yourself with a delicious fresh coconut, pat yourself on the shoulder for a great effort, and go for a dip in the ocean.

An easily accessible hiking trail in the city. The Dragon's Back was once named the best urban hike in Asia by TIME magazine.The trail was approximately 8 and a half kilometers long and the hiking profile was rather moderate that you could bring your kids for family activity without a problem.People started either from Shau Kei Wan (MTR), or from Shek O - a popular beach from where you could take bus going back to the city.

Perfect Hike for everyone!. To get there is truly easy, it takes maximum one hour to get to the top. The hike can be done by people from all ages, from small kids to elder people. In the end the view is beautiful and totally worth it.

Great views, and exercise too.. This is one of the best hikes in Hong Kong, with some fantastic views of the East of Hong Kong Island. Although it isn't regarded as a very difficult hike, there are many steps to assist the climbs to the best vantage points, so a reasonable level of fitness is necessary. It is easily accessible by MTR and then by bus, but it is popular on public holidays, and can get quite crowded.

Amazing. Take the island line mtr to shau kei wan station take the exit at bus station and take the number 9 bus marked shek o and exit the bus by the stop near the prison you will see a sign stating the start of the dragonback there. Its an undulating walk initially that takes you accross the island with great panoramic views accross most of the hong kong islands. Highly recommend this walk its really different from most other sites in hong kong.

So much fun . This was amazing place! You definitely should go there if you're in HK! Hike was kinda easy, but there's lots and lots of steps! View was breathtaking! Take plenty of water!And really easy to find; first subway and then bus 9.And don't worry, I didn't see any spiders or snakes!
amazing views. amazing views, a half day trip worth doing. stop at vista points and take beautiful photos of hk's green side

Great Views. Definitely worth the visit as the views are amazing, especially if you were lucky like us to go up on a day with blue skies. A nice place to get away from the busy city. It was easy to access via bus 9 from Shau Kei Wan MTR station. You catch it to To Tei Wan. I think it's best to go from there to big wave bay so there's a swim to look forward to at the end. The walk around two hours to complete. The number 9 bus also stops at big wave bay and takes you back to shau kei Wan MTR. I recommend making sure you take cash with you as they only accept cash in the minibus from big wave bay.

One amazing hike with incredible views. Despite living in HK for many years a while back, I'd never done this hike before and I wish I had. It's incredible. We did it in the early morning with our 2 little ones - 7 and 10 - and yes some whinging but they did it and enjoyed it at the end. It's a long hike for them and it was hot (mid-August) and very humid. We missed the route down to the Shek O Village directly and went up to the top of the peak and then round back through the trees. Awesome scenery but it made it longer! Had to then get the bus round to Shek O but all was good with noodles and drinks by the beach.No sooner had we sat down for food than there was the most amazing rainstorm with thunder and lots of lightening - it wouldn't have been nice had we been caught up the top in the storm.This is another side of HK - away from the amazing city - and it's incredible.Some guy biked up as well and passed us (at speed) on the way down. Very impressive.
Dragon's Back. This is what Asia is all about. It's amazing, be sure to check this place out, you won't regret it! :)
nice and windy. Easy to walk and nice scenery......completed in 2 hours. Beautiful place to exercise. HK should have more of such places for people to come n hike.

Beautiful views. The Dragon's Back is a fairly easy hike and definitely worth it. The views are breathtaking! To get the most out of your hike, gather a good group of friends and enjoy the scenery together. However, be careful if you go for the hike after a rainy day since the road might get very slippery, especially when going down.
My bloody legs fell off, twice. This gentle hike involves millions of steps and completely knackered me for days. The views were worth it though!
Amazing hike. We did it in very inclement weather and it was still breathtaking. Quite steep in parts, fairly well signposted. You need to be fairly fit. Wear good walking shoes.

Great hike to get outside the city.. Take a scenic 20 minute bus ride and enjoy a few hours of easy hiking. The views are wonderful and give you some respite from the chaotic city. Walk down to big wave beach and visit some of the local villages. Bring plenty of water and watch out for snakes and spiders.
Amazing . I highly recommend this part of the Hong Kong trail. You have breath taking views from both sides and you can really get a feel for the beauty of Hong Kong outside the skyscrapers .

Nice hike. In a place as urban as Hong Kong, it is nice to find a hike where you have a great view of the bay, and can really relax away from the buzz and chaos of the city.
The hike itself is quite easy, although it could be better marked.

Best hiking trail with view. Want to go to Shek O months ago, eventually we did last Saturday. It was quite cloudy in the morning, ends in hiking in muddy road and heavy rain. But we had a good time, and definitely would come back in another sunny day.How to get there:We take MTR Island line to Shau Kei Wan, exit A3 to bus terminus, take bus No. 9 to ToTei Wan, Shek O Road.

absolutely loved the hike!!!. We did this hike without a guide. the starting point is easy to reach by bus. The trails are well marked. Absolutely loved the views from the top! Definitely a must do when in HKG.

Experience Hong Kong through its Hiking Trails!. Hiking is a past time for local Hongkongers who weave through Hong Kong's numerous hiking trails during the weekends and public holidays to get away from the cramped city and stressful life.Dragon's back is a good introduction to these trails and can be done in half a day and easy for tourists to do. The hike brings you along the eastern side of Hong Kong for you to view into the South China Sea.Take the bus 9 fro Shau Kei Wan into the hiking trail entrance and end either through the beach or back at the bus stop which you can board back to the city for your other urban activities.
Fantastic Hike. Probably Hong Kong's most famous trail. Nice for an early morning trek to work up your apetite. Not too difficult either. Great views.
Fascinating. A real Hong Kong hiking, not to be missed. Bring water with you, as you might need to drink to cope with this long walk

The most popular hike for tourists in Hong Kong. Anyone with reasonable physical fitness can do this hike. It is probably the most crowded hike in Hong Kong so beware...there will likely be a lot of people on this trail. If you enjoy hiking and especially if you are an experienced hiker, perhaps skip this one especially if you cannot avoid doing on the weekend. Find trails that are less sought after throughout Hong Kong in the New Territories, Sai Kung and Plover Cove. If you like to a bit of a challenge, I recommend Lantau Peak and Sunset Peak for some great views on Lantau. Do the research for hikes to your liking! It will be worth it! Hiking is very popular and there are four major trails, The Hong Kong Trail (which Dragon's Back is section 8) on the island, Wilson Trail which runs from the island to the Chinese border, the MacLehose Trail which is the longest and incorporates most of the high peaks in the New Territories and the Lantau Trail on Lantau (Bid Buddha is on this island). Don't be surprised to find octogenarians showing you how it is done!

Sunscreen and water. Taking one of HK's hiking trails is a great break from the city! We took the Dragon's Back trail because it ends at the beach. It's deemed "moderately difficult" and for experienced hikers only and I'd say that's a good description of the trail - it's not for the beginner, but you can do it with just a good pair of shoes. And water. Lots and lots and lots of water. Don't forget to bring water!

a short and easy walk with great view. This must be one of the most popular hiking routes in Hong Kong as it is easily reachable in the city and is just an easy walk of about 1.5 hrs. Go in a sunny and clear day, and the views up there are just so memorable. Avoid going on weekends if possible as one will literally go back to back with others.

Panoramic View of Southside and Ocean. Moderately difficult hike, need hiking shoes or sneakers. No flip flops. Reward is serene views of the sea and on a good day the outlying islands. Can be busy on weekends

A nice day out. Recommend.. An easy hike on a nice day. The 'Dragon's back is officially sections 8 and 9 of the HK trail with a distance of 9.8km from the 'start' on Shek O road at the bus stop to Shek O itself (not Big Wave Bay).Starting up from the Bus stop, actually the majority of the climbing is in the first 1.8km upto the summit of the Dragon's Back. It's an easy trail really with multiple 'get out' options. Once at the top of the Dragon's back the trail slopes down a few hundred steps to a contour trail. Turn right at on the contour trail and it's 1.9km to a paved road. At the road turn right again and follow it to the bottom of Pottingers Peak near a Gazebo (This is Pottingers Gap). Follow some 30m past the Gazebo turn sharp right (careful not too miss this) and follow a technical trail down to Big Wave Bay.Some notes:1. The trail on a sunny Sunday can get really really busy.2. Some hikers insist on using Umbrella's completely unnecessarily, so watch out.3. Do wear proper sports shoes. The number of people I have seen wearing work shoes or high heels (really!) is amazing.4. Take water.5. Careful walking down the final section from Pottingers' Gap into Big Wave Bay. It can be very slippy, and it's quite technical.There are also plenty of place to eat and drink in Big Wave Bay, but, if you want to extend your walk for 2km further simply follow the road @ Big Wave Bay, past the carpark into Shek O (straight on at the roundabout).Time-wise please allow from 40mins to 2 hours depending on your speed.

Stunning Views, Manageable Walk (Pace Yourself as Needed). Less than 20 minutes' drive from the heart of Central, The Dragon's Back is an undulating 8.5 kilometer urban oasis unknown to most Hong Kong visitors and unseen even by most locals. That's a pity. For this is a beautiful hike. From Shek O Peak you have panoramic views down to the beaches and out to the offshore islands. My buddy, a local, insisted on an early morning hike, "You'll be glad! The views are great!" My hopes he had forgotten were crushed by his 6 am call to my Central hotel...In the first place, I recommend you go early both because the crowds are smaller but also because the heat and humidity are less intense (often a factor in tropical Hong Kong).Second, bring some water. I didn't and regretted the omission.Third, bring a camera because you are in for some staggeringly beautiful views.Fourth, check the weather reports. Half way into our hike...it rained. It was sufficient to solve the heat problem but not the thirst problem. It also created a manageable problem of being soaked. On the other hand, it made for something of an adventure, especially narrated in retrospect as now.Fifth, carefully arrange your transportation. We took a taxi there but hadn't arranged one in advance to pick us up. We waited perhaps 15 minutes (in the rain) for one to come by and we faced competition with other hikers (perhaps nature puts one in a more Darwinian mindset). I understand you can take a bus here (detailed in other reviews). I imagine ride sharing, assuming you get cell reception (mine was erratic), is another possibility.
Beautiful view. The hike is fabulous. It is not very difficult but the view is amazing. Takes about 2 hours. Do visit the Shek O beach after the hike since it is very close.

A must do !. A wonderful hike. The dragon's back is not too difficult. This hike offers great scenary of Hong Kong. Be for a short stay or for someone who moves to Hong Kong, It should be on your to do list!

Breathtaking Views - Quite Literally!. I was determined not to stay inside my lovely air conditioned room and explore some beautiful areas of Hong Kong. I left my hotel at 6:30am in order to reach the starting entrance for Dragon's Back early morning, in the hope that the slightly cooler temperature would make a massive difference. You can reach Dragons Back by taking the MTR to Shau Kei Wan Station, take Exit A3 and then get on bus 9 at the Bus Terminus. Most people get off at stop 12 which is titled 'To Tei Wan' and begin the trail from there.I'm not incredibly fit and don't often hike but this was quite manageable, I did have to stop several times for a rest but I think that was more to do with the humidity, rather than the trail itself. I only walked a small portion, simply up to the viewing point before returning back the way I came, in summer the heat was just too unbearable. I wanted to head back to the bus stop and continue onto Shek O after, but I was absolutely exhausted and drenched so headed back to the hotel instead. The views were amazing and it was totally worth it. Many of the locals walk this trail every morning and elderly Chinese people will most likely jog past you!

Good hike, not difficult. A popular trail that can be a bit busy. I think it is medium strenuous primarily due to heat and humidity. Expect about two-three hours so take a liter or more of water. Rocky and some slick spots so decent shoes recommend.

Absolute must do - beautiful views !! . Take the 9 number bus and get dropped off at the bus stop from which you start the climb - please get your own water and food if needed and water definitely lots of it - there is none available on the hike and we didn't have any and were a thirsty bunch at the finish. As you descend you can take the left and go to the bus stop again to take a bus to big wave bay or you can go right and walk till big way bay. Overall takes around 3-4 hours if you do it at a relaxed pace. A great way to see a very different part of Hk and we would recommend whole heartedly. You can end it with a nice pizza and beer at the big wave bay restaurant !!

Be prepared to sweat. A lot!. This was a good hike with gorgeous views out over many of the islands around Hong Kong. It is a long way up, mainly consisting of stone or gravel stairs. Lots and lots of stairs. It is always hot and humid in Hong Kong, so take a lot of water, some snacks, a hat, and a towel for the sweat. We only got about a quarter of the way, but loved the view from where we got to. We took oranges, chips and water which were all appreciated on the descent.
worth visiting. It's a great hike -not difficult, even in summer but bring lots of water!!! Good to get away from crowds of people.

I love this hike... I live in HKG. Once a year in winter, my wife and I hike the Dragon's back from our home in Pok Fu Lam (in the west of HKG). It is a longish day, but a day we look forward to. The Dragon's Back is the end of a long day and the views are just fabulous. From the start of the Dragon's Back the hike can be done in between 1.5-3.5 hours depending on your fitness. Between April and September 2 litres of water per head recommended otherwise 1 litre.
Favourite Hong Kong Hike. The views are well worth the effort one of my favourite hikes in all of Hong Kong. A must if you have the time

Nice walk with a magnificent view of the city. It is quite a trip to get to the start of this hike, but the views of Hong Kong are worth the trip. At the end of the trip, you can choose to walk to the beach and relax. So don't forget your swimming gear.

Walk the Dragon - An Amazing Hike. Hiking Dragon's Back is a great idea when visiting Hong Kong. There are multiple entry spots to start the hike, allowing you to pick how long you really want to go. I prefer to start from the Chai Wan MTR station, through the cemetery and onto the path. This hike is very busy on weekends and days with great weather. If you can do the hike on a weekday morning to avoid the large crowds and really be able to take your time. It is a great hike to take pictures of Hong Kong, see the landscape and unwind. It is not a paved path so dress appropriately. Bring sufficient water for 2-3 hours, sun screen, and a towel for sweat. We prefer to end the hike and take a cab/bus to Shek O and have Thai food afterwards - believe me, you will have earned it.

An easy morning hike. It took couples of hour to reach the peak. I took the first bus and arrived the start point around 8AM. I took the way that ended at big wave beach. Around 11.00, I returned to the bus station, it was really crowded. So I guessed the early you start, the better.

Can't miss activity. Most people view HK as a city of concrete, jammed with skyscrapers, traffic and people (which it is!), but don't realize its special geography and climate. Dragon's Back offers a glimpse into the city's natural beauty. The hike is easy to medium and is as nice as it gets, with views of ocean, islands, hills, etc. For visitors who want to experience a side of HK but not overdo it, I would recommend starting from To Tei Wan, leisurely hike to Shek O Peak (taking plenty of time to take in the views along the way) then turn around, hike back down then spend the rest of the day at Shek O beach or Shek O village to make it a special day.

The first trial we recommended to friends who wanted to hike in Hong Kong.. When we first moved to Hong Kong in 2014, Dragon's back was the first trail we hiked and we liked it a lot! We recommended it to our friends from Thailand and Singapore when they wanted to hike here. The view is so spectacular and not too difficult for amateurs. No equipment needed, just water and good sport shoes.

Wonderful hiking experience. This place is under my list for years. Even I come to HK many times, I did not have chance to do it. Until last weekend, weather forecast said it will be shower and thunderstorm but I decided to go anyway. Fortunately, there is no rain at all for whole day. Anyhow, it was foggy at the peak, Although, I see nothing but mist, I am really enjoy hiking trail up to and down from Dragon's Back. I even walked to Big Wave Bay and enjoy brunch there.Wonderful experience.

Our favourite day in Hong Kong. This was a great day. We had great weather and though very hot, thoroughly enjoyed our walk, ending up at Big Wave Bay for a cool swim. Great scenery you could easily miss if you don't take the time to explore this side of Hong Kong Island.
Mountain biking. Whata great way to loose some weight and enjoy the scenery and fresh air. Unfortunately it can be used for hiking and mountain biking so sometimes not so convenient for the hikers.

An afternoon escape from the city . A perfect place to escape the hustle and bustle of the city. This charming coastline and villages are best viewed from the Dragons back. After a steep opening climb, the trail soon meanders across the top of the ridge offering spectacular views

Awesome view.. It's easy access to get there. The track is not as difficult as I thought, but I really enjoy the tracking. If you have more time after you reaching the end of dragon's back, you can continue another 1km to get down to the beach. Be careful of summer time, A LOT OF PEOPLE, like really crowded. Overall, worth the visit.

Difficult first kilometer, but nice coastal views. From the bus stop, it's a one kilometer hike up to the trailhead. It was the hardest one kilometer of the whole hike! Once you're up, the trail is pretty flat with a few uphill pushes. This is surely easy for someone who hikes a lot... But it was challenging for a healthy but unathletic individual like me.1st kilometer: difficult 2nd and 3rd kilometer: moderate, beautiful views at the peakThe rest: pretty easy, flat walk through a forestOnce you finish dragon's back, you can go one of two directions- a few kilometers to Big Wave Beach or a quarter kilometer to a bus stop. It's clearly marked.
nice view. was a happy route to have a nice sea pacific ocean view . so sunny. somehow so easy route if you want some challenge

Easy to reach for tourists. relatively easy hike, and easy to reach by public transportation. Offers great views of both Hong Kong urban life and the countryside. Ends up at Big Wave Beach, where you can go suring

Great Fun, Amazing views. Dragon's back is the name of the trek given from Shek O peak (which is one of the highest points of HK) to Wam Chan Shan. One of our co-hikers who is a HK resident told us that the place is a heaven for many paragliders and kite flyers (although as we went in July, when its really hot, we didnt find any).The easiest way to reach the hike is to take the MTR (HK island line) and get down at Shau Kei Wan Station. From the Shau Kei Wan bus terminus, which is close to the MTR station, we have the bus no. 9 available, which takes one to Tei Wan, Shek O road. Just cross the road and start the trail. From the top of the viewing platform at Shek O peak, one can find great views of the neighbouring islands. Being hot and sunny, we were able to take clear pictures of all the surrounding islands.June-July are the hottest months and the sun bakes down really hard. At many places, the path does not have a tree cover and hence it is imperative that one keeps fluid levels high. Also there no restrooms/ snacking places along the hike and it makes sense to use one before starting the hike. We were able to cover the route in about 3 hours and ended up at the Shek O Beach.
Easy hike. We did this hike on a sunday to have some excercise. The hike is quite easy (european standard) and takes about 2 hours. Recommended

Nice Hike. I waned to do a hike and this is a nice, moderate hike. The first part is a lot of steps and since it was July it was hot. We stopped frequently so it was fine. The second half of the hike is through a shaded forest which is lovely. Saw lots of beautiful butterflies, would recommend it. The hike ends by Shek o Beach which is alright.

Great hike. We just took the bus (9) and started walking at the beginning of the trail. Great views and a really nice hike. There is a restroom at the beginning and also halfway if you need to go.;)At the end we enjoyed the beach with a nice cold beer.
Great fun. A fantastic day out for young and old alike. A nice gondola sky ride to the attraction with great views of HK Island south!

The trail is suitable for beginner's, it's very scenic, and the trail ends in Big Wave Bay.. If you have a full day or at least 6-8 hou4s in Hong Kong, this is doable hike. I booked a hiking tour with Wild Hong Kong via Tripadvisor. My flight arrived around 8 AM... Checked in to hotel and then took the MTR from airport to Hong Kong island transfer to Shau Kei Wan station. This took about 1 hour one way, costs about $120 HKD )or $12 USD). Met my tour guide Rory Mackay at the train station. From there, we took a bus to the hike. I probably would not find this hike by myself. The hike is about 10K or 6-7 miles, up and down hills... Not a difficult hike but when going up hill... It does take a breath out off me. It is very scenic with the view of the city at the peak. At the end of the dragon back before heading down to the big wave beach, there is a public bathroom. From there, another 1-2 mile or so down hill to the beach. There are no bathroom during the hike... So use bathroom before starting. It took us about 3 hours total...So, if you have 6 hour layover, this may cut close.if you have about 8 hour layover, this is doable.*use bathroom before heading down to the beach since there is no bathroom for the next mile until you get to the beach.

Easy hike with beautiful views along the way!. This is a relatively easy hike and suitable for most ages on the east of Hong Kong island. The open views along the top are absolutely stunning and you can often see paragliders along the way. I recommend checking out the weather forecast (My Observatory is the go-to in HK) before heading over - this is a hike with views best enjoyed in good weather. The trail is well sign-posted and you end up close to the beach where you can even set up your own BBQ. Take a hat, sun glasses and sun protection as the majority of this hike is not covered and it can get very hot in Hong Kong in the summer.... Enjoy!

Start at the end!. Take the bus from the second last station of the metro going in the direction of Sheik oh. Then get on bus 9 and get out at the first stop nearby the trail. According to the map you are walking the trail backwards, but believe us, this is better! This way you walk up at stairs and slightly upwards in the shadow of the trees. At the other end you have to climb one big stairway. Once at the top the view is amazing!! Make sure that at the end you take bus 9 to Sheik Oh beach, instead of walking all the way down to a dirty beach.

easy hike with stunning views. it's easy to get here. thank god it was cool and windy on the day we decided to hike, and it wasn't too crowded. we packed lunch and spent easily three hours on the rocks, just taking in the view and that nice feeling of being away from everything else. you can end the hike at the beach where people surfed but do set out earlier, unfortunately for us it was already dark when we got there. pack a torchlight along just in case, we used our phones and ended up running at some parts in the woods! for such an easy hike, the view is absolutely stunning!

Easy and nice view. The Dragon's back is probably one of the easiest trek in Hong Kong. It offers an amazing view on Stanley. You better go in the morning to avoid the crowd. It can be done in 1h30 / 2h30 depending of your path. It's fun to do ..

Stunning views along the top . Make sure you try to do this on a cooler cloudy day. We did it last week no problem and it was definitely worth it. The first uphill climb is only 15 mins then you walk along the spine of the dragon for 30 mins. As you start to drop down on the other side you can choose to go left and shortcut back to the start or continue on the winding path for approx 4 kms where it's covered by tree canopy and you cross over a few waterfalls. Not for small kids or prams or anyone that is unfit due to the Combination of the heat and hills. Take lots of water and enjoy a lychee ice block when u arrive at big wave beach.

Not too difficult of a hike. The view is amazing and it is a quite nice hike. You can decide to go to beach after the hike so it's really nice experience you can have in Hong Kong. I suggest that you try the hike if you are planning to spend a lot of time in Hong Kong. It is still going to take you around 3-4 hours including your walk towards the beach / village, where you can take the bus down to the MTR

Great hike!. Great hike, amaaaazing view. lovely and breathtaking.You don't need to be superfit to enjoy the hike... although you might enjoy it more without all the wheezing and panting. It was well worth it, as the journey is scenic and enjoyable.Stay safe when hiking :)

Wonderful hike!!. It was great to get out of the city and experience the wonderful views. The hike itself is easy and very doable. You get some great panoramic views and the opportunity to breathe some fresh air. At the end, you can hike down to a beach right near by if you want some beach and swim time!

Very hot during summer!. My husband and I are frequent hiker, hence we have decided to do something different in Hong Kong besides the eating and shopping. We picked Dragon's back because of the nice view from the peak. We departed early in the morning at 730am from Jordan by MTR, and we arrived around 830am in Shau Kei Wan station. By the time we took Bus No 9 to To Tei Wan, it's already 9am. The hike took about 1.5 hours (To Tei Wan to the peak, and return back to To Tei Wan). We decided to turn back to To Tei Wan as the weather was very hot. The view from the peak is indeed beautiful.

A hidden gem in Hong Kong. A friend told me about Dragons Back and it was a highlight of my stay. The walk end to end (finished at Tai Long Wan Beach AKA Big Wave Beach) took about two hours from Tei Wan bus stop on Shek O rd (Bus #9). Whilst there were a few hills and slippery rocks it was a fairly moderate climb. Luckily the day we did the walk was humid but not raining. When we arrived at the beach we bought cheap towels and went for a well -deserved dip in the water.
Excellent view of HK. I recommend this as a good beginner hike. The view of HK is good. Due to the sensitivity to the weather, this requires good weather.

Operation Santa Claus Charity Hike. Beautiful views, perfect for beginner/intermediate hikers. Public transportation is available but cabs are plentiful and inexpensive. Toured Dragon's Back for a charity hike. It's fun (and I know many who hike it 2-3 times a week). I prefer the challenge of Wilson One but recommend Dragon's Back more often as it is more accessible and easier. Lots of fun casual places to grab a bite once you arrive at Big Wave Bay.

A 'top of the world' hike with spectacular view. Getting There:It is super easy to get to, easily accessible by public transport (public bus).Simply tell the driver to drop you off at the Dragon's Peak.The Hike:The starting point of the hike is at the side of a winding hilly road. I have seen young children and elderly people scaled to the top.The views are fantastic. Tip 1: Go during the winter months to avoid getting baked by the harsh summer sun.Tip 2: Climb to the top of Dragon's Peak, then U-turn back. The return route is much shorter this way.

Great hike. The HK tourism website offers very good information. The bus to the starting point is an adventure itself. It is amazing to ride on a double decker bus along narrow winding cliff hugging roads. The bus stop at the start of Dragon's Back can be easily missed so best to ask the driver or the locals to alert you. The walk is easy except for some parts and can be accomplished within 2.5 hours stopping at Cape Collinson Rd-Shek O Rd junction or 3.5 hours if you walk on to Big Wave Bay. I stopped at Cape Collinson-Shek O junction and took the bus back to Shau Kei Wan station. Bring water, food, towel and a change of cloth especially during hot and humid weather.

Hiked on a humid and hot day but well worth the effort. My wife and I decided to avert the crazy shopping crowds in the city (our hotel was in the Harbor City so you can imagine), by spending a calm day with the nature, despite that it was a humid and hot day of around 36°C in late June, and the sun was high up in the sky with no compromise.We started the trail from To Tei Wan and returned to the city via a mini bus 5 minutes walk from the Big Wave Beach. The first hour was more difficult since it ascended more quickly and the trail was unshaded. But soon we were high up on the mountain ridge and had a full embracing view of the South China Sea and the islets. It was pretty relaxing just to sit and soak in the view (if you can stand the temprature). Later the trail started to descend after some sharper ascending to the Dragon's Back platform with a signage showing a picture of the surrounding islands. The downhill trail was relatively easy and there was abundant shade. We ate our packed lunch right beside a stream of spring, which was very soothing and helped us recover some energy. Finally we got to the Shek O Village and treated ourselves with cold beer and coconuts. We regretted not bringing stuff for the beach, but just sitting there and watching people enjoying themselve in the water was also interesting. We'll be heading to Scotland and will do some hiking in less than 2 months, so this was good practice ahead.
Good hike, nice views. This is one of the better hikes in Hong Kong. Very nice views, but not much shade. NOT recommended for the summer months. A visit at Shek O Beach is a nice ending to the hike.

Great hike. This hike has a stunning views of the surrounding islands. I took this trail to get to big wave beach. Very hot and humid during the day so wear light clothing and proper footwear. There are a lot of stairs to climb and descend. Just about a 45 minute walk with short breaks. Take lots of water!

Lovely hike. This is a great hike and easy to get to from the hustle bustle of the city. We got the MTR to Shau kei wan and then the number 9 bus. The trails are all well kept and marked and the route takes around 4 hours all the way to Shek O beach. I would just say the terrain is quite hilly and quite hard going so possibly not for beginners. The views and scenery are amazing though and well worth the effort.

Great hike for a hot day. When it is very hot in Hong Kong you will be happy with the beach at the end of this hike. At the beach you have good facilities like showers! Also there are a few small restaurants that offer not only food but also lockers for your valuables so you can have a swim. They also rent out towels and inflatables.nb.During the hike (on a hot day) don't worry to much about not making it until the end. The beginning of the hike is tough, so enjoy the view and take breaks, the second part is easy and in the shadow.

Great City Hike. Just as everyone has already mentioned here, its a great hike really close to the city. All paved and maintained paths. We followed advice from other reviewers on how to get to the starting point. We got off at Shau Kei Wan metro station, and took the number 9 bus from the bus terminal just outside the station. Getting off the bus at Shek O stop. Just to note, we had to pay extra fare for the bus ride from the metro despite having an unlimited tourist Octopus card. Definitely a worthwhile activity to do while in Hong Kong!

Hiking the 'Back'. Not for the average 'Sunday strollers', no self-respecting hiker would leave Hong Kong with tackling Dragon's Back. This is a hike of modest difficulty that offers wonderful views and a few logistical challenges, mostly associated with getting their and getting back when you are finished. Taxis and buses are the best options for transport. For those who have their appetite whetted for more action, the 'Twins' (also known as the 'Vale of Pain') offers a 'step up' in physical challenge. Both of these hikes are achievable in a morning or an afternoon.

A hideaway hike so accessible from the city. The Dargon's Back is the section 8 of the hiking trail, Hong Kong Trail. Hiker usually start their hike by riding Bus no. 9 from Shau Kei Wan station to the Shek O entry point of the trail, up the trail and descend to Tai Tam Gap. I reversed the hike, starting from Chai Wan station. We walked up though a huge cemetery up a lot of stairs and reached the trail entrance, which is through a small metal gate. After that it was just following the trail and signs. It involves quite a lot of steep up and down hills. The trail gets muddy and slippery after rain and there are some narrow places to get pass.The view of the southern part of Hong Kong Island on Dragon's back is fantastic and mind-blowing. You see three beaches and some scattered green islands and the vast pacific ocean.Mountain biking is allowed on the trail.Worth visiting

great trekking area. this is a great place for escaping from the 'so modern- hongkong'.I use this trekking route from To Tei Wan - Shek O Peak - Dragon's Back Peak - Mt Collinson - Pottinger Gap - Tai Long Wan.It was really a great time... This is a 'have to do in Hong Kong'..
Nice to get out. Nice afternoon hike with great views once you get up on the ridge. Bring enough water, it can get hot.

Good trail even for begineers. Went with friends and this hike trail and was not so tough as expected. Beautiful scenery. It leads to a lot of other smaller paths so be sure to prep well where you wanna be. the final destination is also a gem.

Alternative way to see Hong Kong Island. Easy to get to and not a difficult trek as we followed the instruction of Hong Kong Toursim Board. We finished the trek within 3 hours with lots of photo taking but min stops as the view is wonderful and amazing but the sun was scorching hot even early of May. The best view is on the Dragon's Back itself (hottest part as well) as the last stretch which ends at Big Wave Bay has nothing much to see.
the views!. amazing to get out of the city, super views and it's worth the hike to the beach too. Defo a highlight in Hong kong
Amazing views and hike. Hong Kong's parks are under-rated by most. Had a great hike here, great views over Hong Kong, and away from the crowds. Highly recommended if you have half a day.

Beautiful views and a trip to the beach. A few points:- Very easy to get the MTR and Bus #9 to the start of the walk- Starts off with some uphill, but after that it's pretty mellow and then downhill all the way to the beach. Signposting is excellent- If it's a hot or humid day, take a sweat towel and a spare shirt to change into afterwards- Big Wave beach at the end of the walk is a great place for a swim and a relax in the sand, bring a towel to lie on and dry off- If you don't want to wait for the #9 bus to take you back to the MTR, you can pay a little extra for the smaller public bus to take you backOverall, a great day out exploring the south-east corner of Hong Kong island, highly recommended.
Great trek!. Were there with friends last year. Good place to relax from the big city. Trek is not too hard, so everyone can go there. Fantastic view from the top!

Probably the Best View You Can Get on Hong Kong Island. The view from the dragon back trail is spectacular. There is a really good view of the city, beaches and the sea which we get to look at the busy island from a very different perspective. It would be best to come here on a sunny day with clear blue skies for the best view! What makes this trail imperfect is that the path from Big Wave Bay to Dragon's Back is really boring with minimal views on a cement road. We also find this path to be stuffy and hot.
Wow, views to die for. What an awesome walk, great for all fitness levels, and views to die for of beach, mountains, islands, city and ocean.

Enjoyable but Tiring. We had a lovely sunny day for our walk across the Dragons back. We caught the MTR and a bus to the beginning of the walk. The first three or so kilometres were uphill or up steps so a bit challenging but after that it was a lot easier. Once up the top the views were lovely with a light breeze to cool you down. When the walk went through the forest it was a lot cooler. For us the last 2 kms were probably the hardest even though it was relatively flat, I guess it was a fairly long walk around 8.5 kms. It took us about 2.5 hours to walk the whole track. There were alot of other people walking the track as well but this didn't bother us at all as everything just flowed along. At the end there is a nice clean beach where we had a swim.There are good facilities to have a quick shower and get changed again for trip back. There are buses back to the MTR from here or to Shek O. Also there are only toilets at the beginning and the end of the walk.

Nice escape from Hong Kongs shopping malls. . Very nice hike, not challenging at all unless your completely out of shape. Most of it is actually flat, easily done in half a day. I got off the bus at 430 and was finished at 630.

Picturesque, lush and green.. Picturesque views from a lush green path. Initially the path is quite steep but very achievable, then gently ungulates along the top and then down to big wave beach. Beautiful views over hongkong and out to small islands. Lovely to be so close to the city in beautify country side. As it is hot and humid make sure you take plenty of water.To get there we took the metro to Shau kie wan station then followed signs to the bus station right by the exit. We took bus 9 to Tei Wan (the bus terminates at Shek O). The path is right by the bus stop and there is a toilet and map. We got the mini bus back form big wave beach, walk from the beach through the little town and the bus gos from the top of the park by the car park, 10HKD per person. It will drop you back next Shau kie wan metro station.

Scaling the Dragon's Back. We have been on many tracking holidays before but this was our first in Hong Kong. We heard that there are many challenging tracks here but being our first, we chose Dragon's back so that we will not be overwhelmed or complacent in our approach.To get there, we took the MTR to Shau Kei Wan Station, leaving through Exit A3 and boarded bus 9 at Shau Kei Wan Bus Terminus to To Tei Wan, Shek O Road. On the bus we could feel the ascend as the road became narrower and the views along the way absolutely gorgeous. Many locals even the elderly, walk the trail daily for exercise and will greet you with a "Cho San" or "Good Morning" along the way. We were at the peak after approximately 50mins of uphill walking along the undulating path. The view along the way and at Shek Oh peak is beautiful. The downward journey is just as good and we continued to the Tai Long Wan or Big wave beach was a welcome sight. We got to one of the little coffee shops, ordered our beers, chips before we headed back to Shau Kei Wan bus terminal on a minibus and MTR to the city. Hope you will enjoy this trail and many others in Hong Kong, on our next visit it will be the Tung Chung to Tai O and the Sai Kung trails!

Tough but worth it... Took the No9 bus from the MTR station to To Tei Wan stop and started there... went on a Sunday so the bus was packed with people travelling to a local temple nearby to worship...The trail was busy, but about as crowded as expected.It was an overcast / humid day (90%) and thats what made it hardest... the first 45 minutes or so is up and down hills and would be very tough for unfit people... the rest of it was relatively flat or downhill... total time for this 8KM section was about 3-4 hours, at a regular pace, we were passed by people and also went past people, so it would differ in time from person to person.Big Wave Bay at the end wasnt that great (and had no waves), we got some refreshments and sat by the water for a rest, coming from Australia, its hard to beat our beaches and waves.... so we enjoyed the walking part of it.The whole trail goes for much longer and if I had the time it would be great to spend a few days doing it all...
Great hiking in a 8 M city. Easy to get here. Take the subway and then a double decker. Fantastic hiking especially considering your are on Hong Kong Island.

Not really hard for beginners with amazing view !. I'm not really go for trekking that much but this hike is not so hard to finish. Nice view from above and also going down and enjoy the beach on the other side of mountain.

Great trek with excellent views on a clear day. You can walk the whole length or join along the way. The walk is undulating and through some areas of bush but nothing too hard. Will take 3-4 hours depending on the person. At the end you go down into a small beach area, great place to relax and have a drink. You can just jump on a local bus back to the main city
Fantastic hiking trail. The views from the trail are stunning. It does require a little bit of hard work, but most people should be able to manage it.

Classic trail - the short version. Dragon's Back is a classic HK hiking trail which you don't have to be super-fit for, although there are a lot of stairs. The official route starts at a village and ends at Big Wave bay beach, but we did a shorter version just for the view. It took about 3-4 hours, accounting for the stopping and taking photos. Pack sunscreen even if it's cloudy and the UV index is high; several parts of the walk are not sheltered and we still got sunburned through the cloud cover. Portaloo toilets are at the start and end of the walk only.Following the advice from some local hiking friends, we took the No.9 bus from Shau Kei Wan MTR exit A3, and got off at Cape Collinson stop (the screen on the bus announces the name of each stop). I think doing the route from here works for two reasons. 1) you get the boring bit out the way first, where it's through woodland, flat and you can't see much. The view can only get better. 2) there are fewer uphill steps to get to the top. You'll still need to hop on the bus again at the end of the walk if you want to see Shek O and the beach, and there's a bus stop right at the end of the last flight of steps as you finish the trail. Buses are every 20mins either to Shek O, or cross the road for a bus back to the MTR. As we were waiting the red minibus drivers were a little aggressive in trying to get you to take their bus instead of the double-decker, but beware - their fares are more expensive (more than double!) and they don't take Octopus card - cash only.You get a fairly good variety. Some of it is concreted walkways, but a lot of it is knobbly compacted soil/clay, rocks/boulders and stepping over tree roots in the woodland part. Not sure what the soil/clay sections would be like in heavy rain. There's shaded woodland, windy hilltops, exposed paths, and the views are stunning from the top. If you see signs for the 'Adventure Trail', don't bother unless you've packed a machete - even though the trail is a shortcut, it's too overgrown. Apparently you can mountain bike up/down the trail; some stairs have slopes along the edges but they're narrow (only a few inches) and the shrubs are overgrown so won't be much space for handlebars. A cyclist we met said he ended up walking most of it, carrying his bike over his shoulder. At the top of the peak there's an information board so you can pick out landmarks. Definitely an enjoyable day out!

Easy 3 hrs hike. Started at To Tei Wan at Shek O and ended at Big Wave beach, took about 3 hrs for slow hike and relax quite awhile at the peak. Very windy as well as beautiful sea view at the top but no shelter at all, worth a visit if in HK.

beautiful hiking, beautiful views, not too difficult. If you have at least 3 hours time take a bus to Shek O and step out at the top of the mountain (ask the driver). Take a tour on Dragons back - great views on the sea, Stanley and Hong Kong itself.

Challenging yet manageable hike. Easily accessible from the city. The initial hike is uphill, traveling along the "dragon's back" with breathtaking view of the South China Sea and the coastal buildings of southern Hong Kong Island. As you descend to "Big Wave Beach", the walk becomes a lot easier with the hike ending at the sandy beaches with nice cafes and eating outlets

Great views, nice hike and a refreshing swim at the end. I tagged along with a few friends of a friend. As they knew where they were going it was relatively easy to find, but If you don't then it might be a bit tricky.Nevertheless, once you begin the hike, it's a fairly short but sweltering climb to the top. Once there you will be treated to panoramic views of the surrounding islands and city. The hike on the ridge is very hot in the summer as it is exposed, but eventually enters a shaded vegetated section that you continue along as you descend. This is cooler. But the route ends on a nice beach complete with changing rooms and showers, and in our case, a much needed beer!The hike is fairly easy going, the most difficult ascent is soon over and done with. Families could manage this in my opinion.
Hiking. Beautiful coastal view besides the hills. Easy to reach from urban area. Remember bring along bottles of water and some snacks.No shops all all.Enjoy.

Relatively easy trek, Stunning View!. if you do not trek often, or have yet to do any treks, this would be a good place to start! Recommended to start early in the day and! It's quite hard to take photos if the sun is too glaring when you're at the peak

Trekking in Hong Kong. A quite demanding trek but well worth it - lots of spectacular views followed by the chance to chill out with a few beers etc on the glorious Sheko Beach. Highly recommended if you like walking and are reasonably fit.

Great hike and views. We have been told that this is a great hike to do and so it is! Loved it ( although realized i might be a little out of shape) we got lucky as it was fairly nice on that day since we haven't had the best weather lately. Def recommend it but make sure to bring enough water if it gets hotter.

Beautiful Hike. I had a day to kill by myself, and I would highly recommend this hike. The views were spectacular, and the hike I would rate easy to moderate. It's easy enough to get there and home via public transit, and is a great way to spend the day. You can also take a swim at the end in Big Wave Bay.

If you're gonna visit one hiking trail in HK, Dragon's Back is the one.. An easy walk with gentle slopes, located right on HK island and is easily accessible through MTR and minibus. The view is just unbeatable (I've tried most of the trails in HK) and the only drawback is that it gets crowded in public holidays.

Great hike. Not sure I agree with reviewers who say this trail isn't challenging, but it was do-able even for me (60 years old and not a regular climber). There are a lot of stairs, and not all of them are well-defined, so you really do have to choose your steps carefully sometimes. But it's worth it for the fantastic views. On the way down, visit Big Wave Bay and chill out with a well-deserved beer.
worth the effort. climbed on a hot humid day but made it down just as the rain fell. wonderful views rewarded us for a tough climb that gets the lungs working. we loved this walk
Wonderful views. Did this last year, fine for reasonably fit, I did it easily in fitflops but would advise more sensible footwear. Great beach at end

Dragon's Back ....in the mist...from North to South. Starting out from Chai Wan MTR exit A, over the Wan Tsui Rd overhead walk way, then southwest up the road , turning left up Lin Shing Rd to the junction of Collinson Cape Rd. Cross the road into the cemetery. With a new building construction on your left , take the staircase on your left next to the new building, up through the cemetery grounds. There are a few stairs to the top with might take about 20minutes to climb to the top. About half way up, the stairs come out on a switch back of an internal cemetery road. Follow road thru the switch back for about 80 meters, then you will see the restart of the steps upwards again. The last section of the stairs is less used and going into the tree cover but continue to the top where you will come out on Section 8 of the Hong Kong Trail at Pottinger Gap shelter and guide map. You can go left to Big Wave Beach/ Tai Long Wan Village /or head off in a West by North West direction along a well formed road to Tai Tam Gap to walk across the Dragon's back. The road winds a bit passing some picnic shelters until you come to a 3 way sign post showing the way to Shek O Peak and Dragon's Back . Continue up walkway. A short while later you pass a large above ground water reservoir and that is where an unformed dirt track begins. There are some uneven surfaces and slippery earthen trail/tree roots and rock sections in places, so wear appropriate footwear and clothing. The track is well sign posted from there onwards, right through the descent to the To Tei Wan Bus Shelter on Shek O Road, where you catch Bus 9 back Shai Kei Wan Terminus. As I had only one free day to do the walk whilst in HK, the weather was far from ideal, overcast, light rain, with heavy fog/mist once on mountain and down the southern ridges. Walking in the damp mist/fog is ok, with appropriate gear, but in my whole journey across the Dragon's Back, visibility was limited to about 80 meters or much less in some places, with high buffering winds from the South, which were at mountain peak locations or along (unseen) exposed ridges. It took me just over 2 hours from start at the cemetery gates to finish at the To Tei Wan Bus Shelter. Wear appropriate footwear, clothing and take adequate water and snacks as you will be on your own most of the journey(unless you get a brilliant day and everyone decides to take the walk.)On the day, I would have come across about 30 other hikers(in small groups) enduring the conditions but all were heading in the opposite direction i.e. South to North. As a consequence of the poor weather, it was probably one of the worse days for taking in the scenery, I missed out on the fabulous views that others may have experienced or captured with their cameras..... so next time in HK, I'll have to pick a better day to walk the Dragon's Back.

Could have been better. My hike was on a day which was pretty foggy, so the views were not that impressive. I did a tour via Viator, and was a bit disappointed. The tour guide was basically just there to get us from point A to point B, with minimal information. I would have liked more commentary about HK culture, flora/fauna, and some of the sights we saw. He also walked quite fast and it was tedious to keep up with him since the paths can be quite rocky. So while the hike was fine, I felt the guide could have been better, so just rating this "average".

impressive views. on a clear day, impressive views, allow a few hours for the hike. is very busy at weekends, especially in the afternoons, ends at Big Wave bay where there are places to eat and chill

Go early to avoid large crowds. This is a lovely walk that is best done before it gets too hot, as there are a few exposed places on the ridgeline. The trail can get exceptionally busy on the weekends, so leave a little earlier and you'll get the lovely views to yourself.

Hiking trail at our backyard. One of the most popular hiking routes in Hong Kong. It's easy to get to from the city but once you are on the trail, you forget that you are just 10min from the city. The trail is not too difficult with lovely trail hike and great view of the south side of Hong Kong. At the end of the hike, you can reward yourself with a swim at Big Wave Bay.
You could see the famed mansion of the Lees!. it was a 3 hour hike up & down. lots of greenery, great air, when you reach the peak you will see the beach too. beginners recommended too.

Amazing view with moderate hiking difficulty. This is one of the best ways to see HK from a different perspective. The difficulty is suitable for all ages too! We went in April during the rainy and foggy season, so our views weren't the clearest but the weather was perfect. Go on a weekday and it won't be too crowded. The views are the best. Bring along some snacks to enjoy them while taking a rest.

Take the high road and we'll see a better Hong Kong before you. See a greener and different perspective of Hong Kong on the fabulous but easy enough walk. It gets you away from the hustle and bustle and noise of the city and let's you appreciate that it's not all about shopping and eating! Go on a nice day and a lay on the beach awaits you at the end.... Bonus!

Great hiking experience!. This is a great place for hiking! Overall, we took about 2 hours to go up to the peak and came back down to the starting point at To Tei Wan. Actually we planned to end at the beach area below the mountain but it seems like we took a wrong turn and ended up back at the starting point.The weather was very cooling and it was very foggy. It was an experience we will never encounter back in Singapore.I gonna say the hike was quite tiring as there are a lot of uphill and down slopes which can be very slippery and it can be quite dangerous if you were to fall. Please wear proper shoes with extremely good grip for the hike.To get there, simply take bus 9 from shau kei wan bus terminus and alight at To Tei Wan. Worth checking out when you are in Hong Kong.

Excellent view but prone to overcrowding. As the best urban hike in Asia, Dragon's back attracts international visitors from all around the world. If you travel during public holidays, be prepare for overcrowding.

Very crowded but good views. Decided to escape Hong Kong and the crowds but realised that we weren't the only ones with the same plan when most of the bus disembarked at the same stop!Toilet at the beginning, just close your eyes and nose to the smell and sight! No facilities on the walk so take drinks. Good views but so slowwwwww. Lots of walkers some walking painfully slowly. It's a reasonably easy walk if used to exercise, just need comfortable shoes, fluid and sun protection.You can watch the para gliders and extend your walk to a beach before heading back into the city.

Hike with Viator. I booked the hike through Viator, but it is possible to do independently. The hike was moderate activity, excellent weather and views, most enjoyable to see Hong Kong from a different aspect.

One of the best in the world. I think I wrote about this, but Tripadvisor's telling me I haven't. I will try to upload photos later, but this place has the most incredible views and isn't very difficult...but enough to call it a hike. It ends on the beach (what an incredible ending - better than a "happy ending") and there's food (minus really busy parts of the year where they shut down - so do be sure to check before you go). Love it. Love it. Love it!
nice and not challenging. nice place for gathering with friends and family, not too challenging for beginner level. good view.

Accessible, scenic, but a bit crowded. This hike is easy to get to, and you can't get lost. Its well sign-posted. There will be a fair amount of people on weekends and holidays. I recommend continuing the walk to Big Wave Beach, where you can have a meal and a beer, and even try the surf! From there, take one of the small buses back to the MTR.You don´t need any special gear -sneekers and a bottle of water will do! Its a perfect afternoon for exhausted HK shoppers in need of some scenery and peace! Even kids can do this, if you take your time.
Moderately difficult hike. Moderately difficult hikeBeautiful scenery while hiking along the higher areas. Therapeutic to hike among the vegetations and trees.

Dragon's Back. Hong Kong is not only known for their sumptuous delicacies and plentiful shopping but also their plentiful, scenic hikes! We got there by MTR then short ride on bus to To Tei Wan bus stop using the suggestions from other reviewers on here. If you get the chance sit at the front of the bus up the top for the view. After a few minutes heading up you can start to see the view, it gets better as you walk. I could see islands and make out the city skyscrapers in the distance. It was a Sunday morning, quite a few other people on the track but a lot of the time we couldn't see or hear anyone else, so peaceful! The sights and air are just amazing! A different view to Hong Kong away from the hustle and bustle of city life. But you need to eat some food first before hiking. Because there are few street vendors in there. The scenery at the top was breathtaking. Worth the climb. I strongly recommend Dragon's Back to anyone who wants a short break from the city, without having to travel too far away from civilization. Totally recommend this if you want to see another side of Hong Kong, and see Hong Kong from a different view!

Easy, accessible and very scenic. The walk is easily accesible via the MTR and the Number 9 bus. The route isn't very challenging at all but will likely make you a bit sweaty. The views offered on both sides are excellent and certainly not something that you would expect in Hong Kong. Shek O is worth a visit, the beach is pleasant and the nearby restaurants serve good food.

Nice hike. We started from Chai wan MTR through a steep cemetary to start this hike which was a little odd but saw other people doing the same thing. Nice hike, not to hard mostly flatish once we got on the path with a fair ammount of shade. only took a couple of hours too. Coming to the end there was some nice veiws over Shek O beach, which we later got the bus to for some well earnt food and a beer. Nice day!!
Fantastic Hike. We really enjoyed hiking Dragon's Back. 3-4 hour hike that was relatively easy for us 50+ year olds. View from the top worth the effort.

Great Hiking Spot. The views one experiences while hiking Dragon's Back are breathtaking.
What seems as a trivial trek through the Hong Kong wilderness quickly gives way to a glimpse into the nature that makes up Hong Kong. A best for outdoor enthusiasts while in Hong Kong.

Wonderful Hike. Great view points on the way. Peaceful and relatively easy hike.
Be on holidays or be a resident, this hike can be done more than once :)

Too Easy!!!. I was very disappointed with this trail. I found it extremely easy and boring. It was very flat, there were some ups and downs but nothing to make you breath hard. When I go for hikes I prefer something a bit more strenuous. I think it is good for those who wish to enjoy nature but not do that much work for it. For those like me I suggest going somewhere else but for others it could be a worth while trip.

Knackering but satisfying!. Great walk, amazing views, fresh air, very steep in places and more like a scramble so wear sensible shoes and take water!!! You can end up not far from Shek o so the trail ends with a bus to Shek o with well earned beach and drinks :-) very popular with tourists and localsAlike - ask someone who lives here for more info re the larger walks you can do too! Well worth it!!

Beautiful scenery, break from the chaos down below!. We got there by MTR then short ride on bus to To Tei Wan bus stop using the suggestions from other reviewers on here. If you get the chance sit at the front of the bus up the top for the view. After a few minutes heading up you can start to see the view, it gets better as you walk. Not that clear for us today but still fantastic, you could see islands and make out the city skyscrapers in the distance. Such a contrast. Kites or eagles swirling overhead. It was a Sunday morning, quite a few other people on the track but a lot of the time we couldn't see or hear anyone else, so peaceful! We walked through lush vegetation, some areas with tall trees other areas quite open, a few small waterfalls. Views for most of first half, less for second half as you descend. Trail was a mixture of steps and paths, some of it quite rocky and some parts quite steep, need proper shoes/runners. We were looking forward to dipping our feet in the water at Big Wave Beach but were very disappointed to discover that there was a "red tide" and so the beach was unsuitable for swimming. Another unfortunate consequence of the pollution. We had cold drinks and hot chips at the beach side cafe and chilled for a bit before catching the small bus up the road to Shek O. Again the beach no good for swimming but we sat out in the rocks overlooking the water for a while. Much bigger selection of restaurants and places to eat here. Found our number 9 bus and headed back. You need to be reasonably fit, our 7 and 10yo kids had no problems. No toilets or drinks/food available on the track. Totally recommend this if you want to see another side of Hong Kong, and see Hong Kong from a different view!
Hong Kong at it's Best!. Some of the most amazing views you will ever see! Worth the trek and something everyone that comes to Hong Kong must do!

A beautiful walk with lovely sights. It was an ideal day for a hike to Dragon's Back; a sunny but yet windy day.Took a train all the way to Chai Wan and hopped into a taxi. The taxi ride was about HKD60 and was about 10minutes. The driver stopped us just at the start of the trail. The climb along Dragon's Back trail is a relatively mild trek (which you can do with kids from 10). We stopped a few times to admire the coastline and views. Depends on how long and how many pit stops you make, the whole expedition should take 2-3hours. We took the route that led us to Big Wave Bay. This beach is located at a small village. The waves are good for surfing. There were a few surfers and sunbathers on the beach.We ate lunch at a small coffee shop that served a good beef brisket meal. Walked out to the bus-stop and waited for a shuttle that took us to Shau Kei Wan.

A Great Hike, Fantastic Views. 5.5 miles on a clearly marked track up hill and down dale. Dry weather, good footware essential, and not for anyone who is not 100% mobile and flexible. Beautiful views, enhanced by kites (birds) swirling around us.

Best Trekking Experience Ever..Loved it!!. This is a must do activity. Take my word on this one. We were a group of 6 and we all loved it. Its very natural and fun. The views are Photogenic and you would love to sit on the top for a while. On the other side of the trek theres a beach. Its worth visiting. Don't miss on the coconut water there.

A bit of wilderness. We had ideal weather in that there had been heavy rain for 2 days & this had cleared the air so wonderful visibility & a cooling breeze made it easier. The beginning up to Shek O Peak was a bit of a slog for us nearly sixty somethings but as the name implies, the ground undulates as it ascends, giving relief along the way. The views are stupendous , the flora lush but sometimes ones way is impeded by the Hong Konger's desire to selfie at any opportunity. Although well maintained most of the way,there are some hairy moments, especially on the descent, were one is climbing down hard uneven rock, crossed by little streams, making it slippery. The Hong Kong Tourist Board describes the 8k trail as moderately difficult & with that I would concur. But the rewards are great.

Comfortable Walk with Beautiful Sights. Hong Kong is not only known for their sumptuous delicacies and plentiful shopping but also their plentiful, scenic hikes! We took a MTR to MTR Shau Kei Wan Station and then flagged a cab to one of the starting points of the trek at Shek O village. Cab ride takes only about 15-20min. Upon reaching the starting point, you would see signs that indicate which direction to get on the trail. The whole trek should take you no longer than 2-3 hours at a comfortable pace. The hike to the mountains would take about 30min and once you are walking on them, the sights n air are just amazing! A different view to Hong Kong away from the hustle and bustle of city life.Those who are preparing to go should wear proper shoes and please bring your own water as you will not find any stalls along the trail at all.

Beautiful walk. Fantastic walk with some beautiful views over the different beaches. Don't go on a public holiday or the weekend because I think most of Hong Kong was up there as well. Very busy, huge crowds.

Beautiful and relatively easy hike. Dragon's Back is definitely one of the most beautiful and relatively easier hiking trails in HK. You can finish the trail in about 3 hours, which ends at a lovely beach.I strongly recommend Dragon's Back to anyone who wants a short break from the city, without having to travel too far away from civilisation.

Tai Tam Gap Correctional Institution >> Dragon's Back >> Shek O Beach >> Food!!!!!. - A pair of sport shoes with nice grip or hiking boots is necessary.- Not a bad decision to bring a collapsible hiking stick with you.- Bring water and snacks as well.- Not making a joke here. But I saw a bunch of people wearing long dress, heels, suit with a tie pushing a trolley/carrying a baby go up and down hill. Climb over creeks with a small dog in their hands. Force their 4 year old children to walk on uneven mud road because the parents too tired to hold them....... This is a 3 stars trail out of 5. I would say more suitable for kid start from 8-9 year old.- I saw many people coming from Shek O Beach direction, end in Shek O Country Park. But personally would recommended going the other way around. Starting this trail from Tai Tam Gap Correctional Institution to Shek O Beach via Dragon's Back. So that the better view will come along to you. Plus the road is quite steep once you enter Shek O Country Park. Better to walk up hill then down hill. (2 hours walk)- Don't miss the chance to have a meal in "Black Sheep" restaurant. Near by Shek O Beach. Good food! Good wine!Visited 26 March 2016.

Fun and free!!!. This is a good walk with a nice view of the islands of Hong Kong. I believe it's called the Dragon's Back because of its many humps.It's not the easiest thing to get too on public transport so take a taxi for ease or experiment with the buses.Not a tough walk but it is fairly touristy and many people have kids which can hold you up when they start getting tired and go slowly, but just relax and enjoy. Bring water and snacks.Also we had the pleasure of witnessing a failed paraglider take off which was very amusing (although not for the paraglider who landed in the bushes).

A wonderful track to walk and beautiful scenery on the way.. This is a lovely walk. You will need some good walking shoes and you will need to be able to walk the distance on a track that is not always even. It is uphill in some parts of the track but not too steep. The ocean scenery end route is just beautiful especially on a clear day. We loved this activity and finished it off with a beautiful sea food lunch.

what a great way to see spectacular views & staying fit at the same time. Its a really great way to get some exercise & at the same time (if the weather is good) get some of the most spectacular views in Hong Kong.Please make the effort to do this but make sure if the weather is hot you are properly prepared with plenty of water , etc

A classic hike worth trying. People say it is too classic and crowded etc. Yes, true. However it is one of these hikes that got popular for a good reason. Not too hard for a Sunday expedition, nice views and a cool landing if you opt for Check O ending. Do it at least once, when the skies are blue.
Great easy hike with beautiful vistas. A must-do for anyone staying in Hong Kong for a couple of days and wishing to see the countryside of the city, just minutes away from busy downtown

Fabulous walk. Bit of a climb at the start but well worth the effort for the wonderful views you get, We walked from Sui Sai Wan over Big Wave Bay and from there you can catch a bus for another scenic view. There are several restaurants in Big Wave Bay where you can take a rest. Needs a nice spring or Autumn day.
Dragon's back end off at Shek O beach. Climbed up the back in 3-4 hours and lazed at the beach till 4pm. I took a mini bus for 10 HKD since the public bus was said to resume its service at 10pm.

Great Trek!. I love how theres so much nature around hong kong. Dragon's Back trail is an easy hike. I even saw a lady with heels doing it. A couple of little kids as well. The view is also spectacular! Definitely worth the hike!

Best hike in Hong Kong. Me and my wife hike here regularly. We normally catch a taxi to the start near the prison entrance up from Chai Wan (taken from gmap.. 石澳道110號). From there you walk up and down 2 peaks and end at a bus stop towards Shek O. Great view all the way. Catch the bus on the same side as the trail and itll take you to the beach. Great day out.

Must do Trek for any abled body. Weather needs to be good to truly enjoy and appreciate this trek. Wonderful views of Shek O and the Ocean with its small Islands around. Finish of the trek at Big Wave Bay beach and reward yourself with a refreshing swim in the sea.
Great hike!. Relatively easy to get to, great views, appropriate length. Only thing is it is pretty known so you'll definitely wont be there alone.

Suprising large area of nature so close to the city.. Very easy to get to the start of the trail by MTR and bus. Just use Google Maps to find your way. The trail is easy to find as well. When the weather is nice the views are amazing. It's just an easy climb to the peak. Very worthwhile trip to start your day. There are no facilities, so bring some food and drinks.

Great hike, nice end at Big Wave bay for swim. Highly recommend doing this hike. In early March the temp was perfect, the sea was 17c but warm enough to swim without wet suit. Stunning views on a clear day.
walking in the back of the gragon.. amazing spot in the high lands of Honk Kong. the view is breathtaking and shows you the really landscape of the region.
Beautiful views of Hong kong. Took us 2.5 hours to finish the entire hike which ended at big wave. Very doable with young kids. Beautiful views and fun hike.

Nice trip. We found some tips here in Tripadvisor before going. It told to take the MTR to Shau kei wan and take the bus number 9 to Shek O at the bus terminus. But it wasn't quite true. Shek O is a village nice and cosy. If you want to go to the Dragon's back you have to go off the bus before Shek O. The stop named To Tei Wan. The view was amazing. Enjoy! My 3 children at 11 had a great time.
Part of the 50km HK hiking trail. One of walk Hong kong's most popular hikes. Really recommended for the hikers. The glory of it all is that you are so close to the city

Must-see views after a 2 hour trek. One of the best activities at HK for me ever, we started at the beginning of the trail on Shek O road and came out of the trail via Tai Tam Gap correctional institution (!!). Both places were right next to a bus station with buses to / fro Shau Kei Wan station. About an hour's walk uphill that got us to the top of the hill for some of the most beautiful sights seen in HK, looking down upon Shek O beach, and a golf course in the distance. Best done early in the morning, or early evening, to beat the heat.Remember to carry some water and food as there is absolutely nothing other than natural beauty all around!
Beautiful trek. An easy, winding trek with beautiful views of the ocean in the distance. Many locals go paragliding here when there's enough wind.
Fantastic views. After a fairly complex bus and train ride we enjoyed the walk up and then on down to Big Wave Bay. It was great

Beautiful scenery, can be a challenging hike!. Did a hike with friends. The route we took was not a paved route (for part of our climb) which makes it challenging. Also cuts down the time of hiking. The scenery at the top was breathtaking. Worth the climb for those who can ....

One of (if not) my favorite hikes on the planet. Just go do it. Love this hike - it's perfect. Amazing views, decent but not too tough, doesn't take up the whole day - and then you can catch a bus to Shek O after and have lunch and hit the beach. Dragon's Back is fantastic

Simple beautiful. Been here four times and it's a great hike. I live in Hong Kong and would come here when I have friends visiting from a different country. If you hike a lot then you'll find this place quite simple, however if you're out of shape, this place will definitely put you in shape. Do not go here if you have hip or knee problems because you'll experience lots of up and down hills. The hike is about an hour or two going one way and make sure you bring your own food and water because you won't find any stores along the trail.
