A must if active. Good walk you do need to fairly fit, but some 70 year olds were doing the climb and walk, Must have water with you

A truly remarkable hike. Once you finish the initial climb, most of the rest of the way is fairly even. We began the hike just off the Chai Wan MTR station and climbed through a tall cemetery, and then walked for a while through a tree covered path until we got to the open area with views of the water all around. It was very pleasant and the path well maintained. After walking down, we took a bus at the bottom of the road over to shek-o beach to have lunch, lots of good places to eat there. A wonderfully beautiful view - you will not regret a minute of this hike.

Awesome hike. We went hiking on one of the hottest days of the summer. It was brutal but the views were amazing! Make sure you take plenty of water with you. I would love to do it again in the cooler months.

Excellent views, moderately challenging trek. Excellent Trek. I personally reccommend taking Bus 9 from Shaukeiwan to the bus-stop and then hiking up to see the views. After you pass the peak (where there is the lonely bench at the middle of nowhere) you will reach a fork where you can proceed on for the full trial or walk back to the busstop. I reccommend you walk back as the rest of the trail does not have such scenic views. After the walk, i recommend taking the bus to Shek O for a leisurely walk and for food nearby.

Great hike despite the rain. Hiked the Dragon's Back despite a forecast of potential thunderstorms and rain. Following the well detailed instructions on how to get to the trailhead by other reviewers I started out. I was lucky to have reached the peak of Shek O right as the rain and thunder started. Knowing that I could either turn back or continue on I decided to continue. All in all it was a wonderful hike. Make sure you do have good hiking shoes or hiking sandals. I found that the path in various places was quite slick and could use some attention and maintenance. If you are a bit more unsteady on your feet while hiking, carrying a retractable pole may not be a bad idea. As other reviewers mentioned from the road to Big Wave Bay it does take about 2 hours. When you reach the jogging path where the bathroom is, there are 2 options: 1) to go to some gap or 2) to continue on to Big Wave Bay 2.5 km away. The first km of this will be hiking on the jogging path with whatever runners happen to be out and about. Once your reach a little park, you veer to the right through the park. Right after the park the path does split into 2--I forget where the other side went, but to get to Big Wave Bay you continue down a little side trail with steps to the right for the final 1.5 km. Once in Big Wave Bay, if you keep walking straight effectively, you will reach the bus stop. As it was still rainy I opted not to spend any time in Big Wave Bay. I did end up having to switch mini buses but a local helped me with that.

Top 3 things to do in HK. If you have a nice hot day or a day with clear skies then you must go and do this trek.It´s a pretty easy trek about, but make sure u have some decent shoes as there are some spots with lose stones. Also take some sun protection as there is not much shade on the ridge. The views you get on the ridge are simply stunning as all the other reviewers tell.After about 2 hours you have a split to the left to go back to the bus station or to the right to go to a village and the big wave beach where you can reward yourself with a nice little swim and fresh drinks in the village.To get there take the MTR to Shau Kei Wan station and then from there take Bus 9 to To Tei Wan bus stop (the bus displays the stops as well)Enjoy
Most beautiful landscape in hk. Easy to get there. The most pretty landscape I've ever visited in hk. It's easy to walk and I took 3 hours to finish.

Nature gem in the super busy Hong Kong. I've been to Hong Kong already 5 times and the only time I saw blue sky it was in December, so I decided I have to go for a hike. If you are ever in HK please do this amazing route! You won't believe your eyes that there is such a beautiful hike just on the other side of Hong Kong island. Along the hike you will see great beaches from the top, lots of greenery and if you are lucky with the weather, blue sky with warm sun:) After you finish this hike you can take a bus and go directly to Stanley beach which has a big art market, and if you are in a good shape you can continue a hike to a Repulse Bay beach, which is one of my favorite places in HK.
Amazing!. Get the minibus from central ub to the base of the mountain, then conitnue walking over the dragons back (sign posted) untill you come down to a nice village with an amazing beach to relax.
Great Hike you can do again and again. I've done this one in both directions and highly recommend it. I prefer starting at To Tei Wan so you can walk to the beach at Tai Long Wan.

Wonderful day away from the city. This was a wonderful walk my partner and I did. It wasn't too crowded and the views were beautiful.We are seasoned hikers so we thought the track was a little bit short for out liking. But it was still a nice day out.

Well worth it. Not a killer - but a damn good workout!This hike is definitely not for the faint-hearted, but this is a hike you can do on a hangover and you'll still be ok! I could walk ok the next day, although my muscles felt worked.Stunning views from the top - like no other. A nice beach to relax on once you're finished, if you're not too hot. There were open parts and shady parts, but it's called the Dragon's Back for a reason - lots of ups and downs!

Really one the BEST hikes in HK. Beautiful hike with multiple exit options. The start can be a bit difficult to find. The bus stop is the one with blue toilets and/or where half of the bus alights :-). The first 20 minutes are uphill and can be daunting but maintain pace and don't give up as beautiful views and fresh air awaits at the top. After reaching top, its usually downhill or flat. One of the exits leads to big wave way (with a downhill through what feels like thousands and thousands of steps, but is actually much less than even one thousand steps)

Nice, not too strenuous hike. I wanted to see a bit of the nature of Hong Kong while I was here so booked myself a guided hike along the Dragon's Back. To be honest I could probably have done the hike without a guide as it's a well used path and there is good signposting - the only bits that aren't too well marked are the bus stops at the beginning and end so they might prove a bit tricky to find. Saying that I am glad that I did have a guide with me, I'm travelling alone so, as well as getting me to the right bus stops, it was great to have someone to chat with and someone to point out what we could see as we were walking (my guide was Rory at Wild Hong Kong and I'll be giving him five stars when I review my tour with him shortly.) It was a nice, not particularly strenuous walk - although there are quite a few steps to climb in parts. Quite a bit of the walk is shaded and when I did it there was quite a nice breeze on the ridge but it was still very humid so make sure you take lots of water and sun lotion. Oh and give yourself a spray of bug spray before you to, I didn't and came back with a few bites in my legs.At the end of the walk you get to Big Wave Bay which has a couple of shops, a nice cafe and a lovely beach if you want to cool off after your walk. It was nice to see so much nature and tranquility so close to such a huge hustling bustling city like Hong Kong.

Gorgeous Views!. I've been to this hike a couple of times and it has always been amazing! It gets crowded during the weekends so try to do it on weekdays if you can! Trails are clean and signs are clear, so don't worry about getting lost. Great hike for beginners! A visit to ShekO village before or after is a must!

Great Hiking with magnificent view. Went here for a hiking, a big change to normal shopping and eating trip in hongkong. Be sure to bring lots of water. the terrain is not hard but the humid weather of hongkong easily wears you out. The view from the hiking trail is very beautiful and worth the effort.

Great hike and fantastic views. All of the directions and instructions provided by TAs were spot on and it was easy to get to the start of the hike. Take the MTR to Shau Kei Wan station and then from there take Bus 9 to To Tei Wan bus stop (the bus displays the next bus stop so it's pretty easy but if in doubt, ask the driver). I got to the To Tei Wan bus stop around 9am and it was already pretty hot. The hike was tough at the beginning (particularly due to the number of steps involved and the heat) and I had to sit down twice as my vision started swimming. If you're hiking around this time, make sure you take plenty of water. I would recommend you go with someone else. I did it solo but it's nicer and safer with someone. I saw two guys running the track in the heat! Keen or crazy, you decide. Once you reach the Shek O Peak, it's pretty flat going until the descent to Big Wave Bay. It took me just under 2 hours and I wouldn't call myself particularly fit. Thanks to all the TAs for your very detailed and accurate directions.

A nice getaway from HK city madness. We decided to do this moderate difficulty hike to Dragon's Back to spend some time outdoors and to mix city stuff with some nature stuff during our short stay in HK.I think its a fun to do! If you are sick of the crowds, you can spend about half a day on this activity.The path has a trail in most places but good sports shoes is a must. Apply sunscreen and carry shades and water.

Great Views, easy hike. Very easy to get to the starting point. Hop off the MTR at Shau Kai Wan. Bus number 9 takes you to the starting point. Easy hike up the hills. A mixture of rocks and stairs that are slowly eroding away with every down pour. Follow signs for "Dragons back /Hong Kong trial" and not for "the gap". A part of it is through Shek O country park. The view from Shek O peak is lovely - surrounding islands and bay. Hike ends at Big wave beach. Didn't take more than 4 hours, and we stopped for a lot of pictures.Buy food and water at the supermarkets outside the MTR station. The stores at the beach rip you off. It does get quite warm. Would recommend doing this hike early in the morning.Bus number 9 from here back to the MTR.
Nice hike. Easy nice hiking trip with the big wave beach at the end. Make ure to take enough water and sunscreen.

Beautiful views and a good exercise. This was the first time I went hiking and I loved it. The hike will take about 2,5-3 hours and around 3,5 hours if you take breaks often. At the beginning there are a few steep parts, but if you can walk a few stairs without a problem, you're fine. Make sure to bring at least 1,5 liter water and a snack per person on a hot day, as you won't find any water or food on the hike. -Toilets:There are 2 toilets at the start of the trail and there's one when you have finished about three quarters of the hike, it's somewhere on the pavement part of the hike and there is a sign that can not be missed. -How to get here:Take the MTR to Shau Kei Wan station and take exit A3. From there you will find all the buses, take bus 9 and get out at the To Tei Wan station. There is usually a sign in the bus which displays the next stop so keep checking it. The bus drive will take about 15-20 minutes. It will cost around 9 HKD if I remember correctly and can be payed with the octopus card. When you get out at the bus stop, just follow the signs of the trail and you will walk correctly. If you want, you can also walk the trail until you end at Big Wave Bay beach. For this, follow the signs to big wave bay beach which appear halfway in the hike. At Big Wave Bay beach there are some restaurants where you can eat. The beach has also lockers, toilets and changing rooms. - How to get back to the MTR from Big Wave Bay beach:Just walk past all the restaurants, all the way to the top. There the mini buses stop, which will take you straight to Shau Kei Wan MTR for 12 HKD. You have to pay in cash when leaving the bus, you can't pay with your octopus card.

A ride on Dragon's Back. This was one of the most beautiful hikes closeby Hong Kong. Make sure to start at Shek O Road and take a direction towards Big Wave beach - you'll end up in a little paradise. There is nothing better than refreshing swim after few hours hike!

Awesome views, average hike. Dragon's Back is one of the best hikes in Hong Kong! The views are great and the option to end at the beach is a huge advantage. It's not the toughest hike in the area, though, so if you are looking for something difficult, check out The Twins.

Great Place for Hikers. Hike to the top of 284-meter-high Shek O Peak and you will be filled with panoramic views of Shek O, Tai Long Wan, Tung Lung Island and even the distant Hong Kong skyline. It can take around 8 hours and without any food stops, it can be an arduous task for a novice. It’s best to stock up on supplies as no food stations are there on the trail.

Great hike--do not miss when in Hong Kong. Hard to find the starting point. We tried to do it ourselves, but the we had to bring down and find a taxi (which was not easy either). We were rewarded with a wonderful two hour hike culminating in the views over Shek O and a lovely seaside lunch. While anyone in reasonable shape can do it, there are many places to twist ankles, so step deliberately.

A very pleasant surprise in HK. Beautiful , relatively easy walk with great view , the only trick is to get the bus driver to drop you off at the correct spot !! Did not walk to the fishing village , went up and came down on the Stanley side if the Walk. Great sunset vistas

Fantastic Hike.. It was a very hot day and the beginning of the hike is mostly in exposed areas. It is really important to have sunscreen, a hat and sunglasses. I would also recommend bringing a hand towel because you will sweat on this walk. The middle and end of the hike is through bushland and is not exposed, so the walk gets easier, as far as heat is concerned. The walk isn't too challenging, so medium hiking experience is probably all you need, but if you have any issues with walking it is probably not the walk for you. It took me 4 hours to complete the walk which ended at a beach on a public holiday, so it was teaming with people and colourful umbrellas. Remember to pack your swimmers! The water was warm and so refreshing after a great experience. There is toilets, changeroom and showers available for use at the beach, along with eateries and a pub of sorts. You can also buy beach items (swimmers, boogie boards etc.) if you have forgotten to bring your own. The walk itself introduces you to the local flora, and even some fauna - we came across a snake which looked like it had gotten its head caught in a hole, probably trying to eat a mouse or something and unable to fit its head back out again; and I wasn't willing to help it. Loved everything about it, especially the feeling of accomplishment. I DID IT!! One less thing off my bucket list.

Senior Challenge. During the many years we lived in Hong Kong we heard often about the Dragon's Back, a scenic hike along a ridge in the south of the island. In February of this year, now in our 'twilight 'years, we finally got there and I found it was not nearly as difficult as I had imagined.You need a certain level of fitness. If you can walk about 4/5 miles and climb several flights of stairs without collapsing then you can manage this trail. If you are a senior citizen just take it easy on the steep part at the beginning.Fortunately we were accompanied by a friend who hikes the trail on a regular basis. We started from near Cape Collinson and walked towards Shek O where we could reward ourselves with lunch and a few beers.We have been told that there are magnificent views from Dragon's Back. However, we saw nothing due to the heavy mist that descended that day! At least we did not have to worry about heat. Guess what is on the agenda for the next trip to Hong Kong?

One of the best hikes in HK. For a first timer hiker in HK, Dragon's Back is definitely recommended. Easy to get to the start of trail (you would need to know where to get off by taxi or bus, but should be easy, just follow the herd of hikers/tourists!), nice view and terrain throughout the hike, and you end up somewhere with food and beach!

a perfect half day out of urban space. great hike, suitable also with families, amazing views and easily reached by public transport i recommend to end with the great Tai restaurant at the center of shekO
Brisk HK hike. This is a short and simple hike to do in HK without too many inclines. Enjoy great views of HK and finish in shek O big wave bay

overview of Sheko Country club. The dragons back is a must do trek in Hong Kong. You really feel like you are on the back of a dragon. But be warned in summer it gets very hot and is not for the novice walker

Great Hike. This is a fantastic urban walk taking you through beautiful scenery and revealing views of the beaches and coastline of Hong Kong. You can follow the trail to Big Wave Bay. Shek O Beach is also nearby. Both nice beaches, although Big Wave Bay was quieter. Get the MTR to Shau Kei Wan, then the 9 bus to Tei Wan. The bus stops at the beginning of the Dragon Back Trail. Take plenty of water!
Rarely seen Beauty. A side of hong kong i didn't expect to be thereTruly beautiful mountains and lovely wildlife Not too difficult to get too with public transport and truly worth it

one of my favorite hike's in hong kong!. i love hiking in hong kong and dragon's back is one of my favourite trails in hong kong! it's about a 15 minute cab ride from central if you leave at 5:30am, which is around the time to go if you want to see the sunrise (it's a pretty spectacular sunrise as far as sunrises go in hong kong). the trail covers everything from mountains to ocean, from large steps to pebble paths...it varies enough that it never gets boring (having gone twice in the last 6 months)! the trail ends at shek o beach....which is the perfect to place to grab a few beers, eat some chicken wings and just wind down. if you have time, stay at the beach, people watch, soak up the sun before you head into shek o village where you must grab a bite to eat at the black sheep! it's cute little joint with excellent food (really great pizza, pavlova, etc).

Beautiful view and nice walk. I did this trek during very hot day. The only disadvantage was that it doesn't have any drinks shops or something like this. Take a water with you or you will dry up. At the end of the route is a beach so you can refresh after heat and sweating.The view is very nice, sea is very blue and the air is very clear. It is easy trekking route so it is more like a walking then a trekking.
Awesome view. Awesome vies from the top of the hills in HK looking over South side. With clear skies you get to see some beautiful scenery over the beaches
Amazing view on the south of HK Island. Chose a day with a good visibility2:30 hours of hiking at the top of the hills around Shek OGood views on Shek O and Stanley bay

Every hiker's must-visit. The trail is popular and well maintained. Since the trail passes at the top of the hill line, the elevation might be a bit challenging. The weather in HK is always hot and the trail does not offer a shade. There's a parallel trail (see the maps) that passes at the mid-height. You do not get very good view, but the path is flat and the shade is nice. I took half of the way using the lower path and then switched to the top trail.

It'll prepare you for more!. One of Hong Kong's most popular and scenic hikes. Conveniently on the main island, ending at the picturesque town of Shek O with plenty of food options. It'll prepare you for more!

A beautiful mid level hike that makes you feel far from the city.. I wouldn't recommend doing what i did - following this trail during the hottest most humid time of year with insufficient water. However, peak after peak offered stunning vistas. It was moderate level challenging, really the unrelenting sun and lack of shade through most of it were the hardest parts. But oh so worth it! Bring an umbrella if you go when it is hot.

Great hike with beautiful nature and views. It was hard for us to find the beginning of the hike, but we had such a great time on the hike. we went to the top and the views were awesome. Steps are challenging on the way down, but overall , it's an awesome hike.

Short hike with decent views. Pros: short (finished the trail in less than half a day), easy to get to, free, tranquil environment, decent views. Cons: arduous in the summer heat, parts of the trail were not very well-maintained.NOTE: beginner hiker.

Great run, minus the humidity!. On my first visit to Hong Kong, as I was living at the bottom of Dragon's Back, I decided to go running there very early in the morning but the humidity was so high that I had to rest a few times before reaching the top...

Best hike in HK!. We regularly do the Dragon's Back. It is the pre-eminent hike in HK. Great views, good exercise and ends at the beach - perfect for a swim.Make sure you start early in the summer to avoid the heat and the crowds.

Nice trekk in HK jungle. One of the only trekks on HK island, really nice one !
You arrive in Big Wave Bay so it's pretty convenient to relax there after and take the bus back to the city.
Easy hike and amazing view. This is a beginner level hike, very easy and good for newbies. The view is amazing and is a very popular hike among tourists. It was my first hike in Hong Kong.

worth the view. gorgeous view. it was also my 1st time on a hike. did 10k!! you can continue with a variety of hikes while on this trail. however, dragons back itself is a short hike, the stairs at the beginning was a killer, but the scenery at the top was so worth it.

nice short hike, very strenuous when hot!. Being an experienced hiker, I was surprised what a difference scorching heat and high humidity can make to a hike. Be warned and bring a hat and plenty of water. Also, while the views are great, don't think you'll get more than a glimpse of the city center. All in all a good hike, could be better if one wasn't forced to walk back.

Hiking in Hong Kong is great!. Obtained hiking book from HK ferry near HabourCity for list of places to hike. Else download from Internet Take bus 9 from the bus terminus beside Sheu Kei Wan mtr station and alight at To Tei Wan at Shek O County.The initial flight of stairs were moderately difficult but the view that one gets to see along the way is breathtaking! WORDS can't adequately describe till you see it at its peak.As you continue the route you will come to Big Waves Beach where you can enjoy the cooling sea water or a suntan if you are prepared. Leave the place by minibus waiting outside though slightly more pricey at $10 which saves you the walk out to the main road to take bus 9 back to mtr.Dragon's back is definitely worth a visit! Choose a cooler season like autumn and winter. Bring lots of water and food as well as insect repellent as mosquitoes abound in summer. Protection like sunglasses, arm miffy, wide brin hat and a brolly definitely helps if you choose summer hiking.

Hot . We got dropped off by the no9 bus ,found it a bit confusing at first went up a path that was steep and difficult and not maintained at all and omg the heat it was so intense ,the views where amazing just think we that the first part was probably not where we should of started once we got into the dirt path it was a lot easier( except for the heat!) we did this in the morning and by lunch made our way up the big wave beach and then it was all worth it ,beautiful burger beautiful beach !took our togs and had a well deserved swim , took us three hours even with sunscreen got burnt take water at least a litre per person

Best part of Hong Kong. This is a relatively easy hike but with the heat bearing down on you can be pretty intense at times but the view alone is worth it. Just make sure you bring enough water and head to Big Wave Bay after so you can take a dip in the ocean and get a beer, makes it that much better!

Amazing Hike. It was an amazing hike despite the hot weather as we went there in June. The starting part was quite tough with steps and fairly steep slope and no shelter from the hot sun. However, it is worth going as the hike provides unobstructed and great views. For the hike it is important to bring along water and hat to protect against the hot sun. Sunblock is a must. Of course don't forget the camera.The trail is easily accessible by public transport.
Breathtaking views. It is interesting to see how you still have a lot of natural spaces devoid of building in such a dense city.The 3 hours walk is really enjoyable, and the view beautiful.

Great hike with amazing views. What an amazing hike, very easy to get to and from by public transport. The start of the hike is a little tough and gets very hot at midday, but you will survive. Good views all along the way and gets a little easier closer to the end. It will take roughly 2-3 hours, i would recommend a medium fitness level. By the end of the walk I was just about dying, but was rescued by a bowl of instant noodles, 2 coconuts, a beer and a quick swim at the beach. They read me like a book. The transport back to the MTR station was also very well organised.
Good hike. Nice, scenic views. Unfortunately went in June which was super super hot and humid. Quite easy to get there and there are clear signs along the way. Trail goes up and down so not too tough
Not to be missed. This is a not to be missed experience the views are as good as the reviews , not always the case but certainly true on the Dragons Back.

Beautiful views. You need to be reasonably fit to do the Dragon's back, but it is well worth it. The views are impressive once on the top, though once you drop the trees limit what you can see. We started from the Shek O Road (No 9 bus from Shau Kei Wan - get off at To Tei Wan, but probably best to ask the bus driver where this is) and finished in Tai Long Wan (Big Wave Bay) - bring your swimming costumes for a swim at the end! A different No 9 bus then takes you back to Shau Kei Wan (mini-bus). Take plenty of water and food, since no places to eat along the way.

On a good day this is an excellent walk.. A superb walk over the hills to Shek-O. Remember, you're in the hills, exposed to the weather so dress appropriated, especially footwear, not suitable for flip-flops. Take the MTR to Shau Kei Wan, leave by exit A3. Bus terminus is on the LHS, go to stand 9 and take bus 9 to Shek-O. Get off at To Tei Wan, stops are indicated, on the bus, well in advance. Dragon's Back is marked as Hong Kong Trail. Follow the path and enjoy the views. I would advice going in good weather and during the week. At the weekend and public holidays it will get very busy. Cloud and rain, don't bother. However, on a good day you'll be rewarded by superb views and an enjoyable hill walk.

A really great experience. The start of the walk is pretty tough but it definitely gets easier as you go along. The views were great and it was definitely a nice change from the big city. Pack plenty of water, sunscreen and a hat! Shek O is a great place for lunch and a few beers at the end.

A great walk. This is an undulating 8.5km-long hike, through Shek O Country Park along the Dragon’s Back ridge on Hong Kong Island. It's a quick train ride on the MRT Blue line (Chai Wan) to Shau Kei Wan Station. From Shau Kei Wan Station we use Exit A3 to the Bus Terminus, then take bus 9 . The beginning of the Trail is on Shek O Road, near To Tei Wan village. We were a bit anxious about how to know when to get off the bus but several other people were doing the same thing and the bus driver also seemed quite used to helping uncertain tourists. We took our time on the walk and really loved the view far into the distance on both sides after we climbed up to the ridge and began walking along the top. The path is very well marked and maintained but the wind was pretty strong that day and at some spots almost blew us over. The total hike is said to take 6hrs (and probably does if you walk slowly to appreciate the view and have a break along the way for a picnic). However we were a bit pushed for time and took the opportunity to do only the first 5km exiting down towards Cape Collinson Rd from the toilet area at the northwest section before Pottinger Gap. This shorter section took us only about 2hrs. From here it was easy to pick up Bus 9 once more, back to Shau Kei Wan Station. The full walk looked a bit more confusing about where to go when you eventually get to the end! It was great to escape the hustle and bustle of urban Hong Kong for a few hours and the views were spectacular. We really enjoyed the walk. It's not very challenging and so is assessable to anyone with just average fitness. We met lots of families along the way and the kids were really enjoying the scramble.

Moderately difficult hike. On the HK visitor guide, the hike was said to take 6 hrs. Our friends told us it would take 3. We came in right around 3, but it was a lot of hills and uneven ground. I'm in fairly good condition and there were some steep inclines and some slippery areas. The views were outstanding and we got in some exercise during vacation that made the trip pleasant. We did get a few mosquito bites on our legs. The map and arrows on the trail aren't always clear and we should have headed right on the paved area to get to the ShekO beach and instead turned left. The arrow to the right pointed to the Big Wave beach, but we heard it was further, so we turned the wrong direction.
Nice Hike. Great views as you come over the hill and look down at Shek O. Bring your dog and your dun tan lotion!

Good views, but busy.. We made the mistake of doing this walk on a public holiday. There are some amazing views to take in but, perhaps because this is a well-known route and a not-too-challenging one, it gets incredibly busy. If you can do it on a non-holiday weekday I would recommend it. Finish up in Shek O with a beer on the beach. Plenty of restaurants here too.

Great walk. Dragon's Back is a rewarding walk. Not hard, but be sure to take water and snacks as there is nothing along the way apart from nature and stunning views. Plan for a swim at Shek O or Big Wave Bay at the end of the walk.

Absolute killer of a hike in Summer. It's an absolute killer of a hike on the way up, although I did do it at 32 degrees, midday, 100% humidity having not quite acclimatised. The way down after such an upheaval is a glorious ramble through forest covered footpaths ending at Shek O beach.

Beautiful Views and a Great Getaway from the City. The trail is hard packed and relatively easy to walk. Anyone who is in reasonable shape can enjoy this hike. The views are fabulous - islands, golf courses, boats, etc... Ended the hike at Big Wave Beach to have a late lunch at a "burger shack" on the beach. Fun day!

We loved it.. Top of the world . We followed the instructions our fellow trip advisor reviews posted so we found it easily.I know lots of people have called this hike "easy" but I don't think it is. I walk allot normally plus I do Crossfit 5 times a week so I'm quite fit, but I found it intermediate at least. I mean it's not hard, but it's not easy. Be prepared to be puffed a bit and to get hot. Some steps a tricky especially on the decent where it's wet and slippery as well. If your not comfortable walking on rocky surfaces this isn't for you. Either way we walked it and just loved the views and the nature. Worth a half day out there..

Great hike in Hong Kong. Caught the bus to the start of the dragons back. In May its hot and humid but the hike is really great. Good views and worth the walk. We continued down to Big Wave where we had lunch and a swim and bused it home.

Unseen view in Hong King - highly recommended. the dragon's back is a gem of hiking place in Hong Kong. You can choose to walk half way or full way. I started from Tai Tam Gap and walked back to the starting point. It is a good idea to starting walking from Tai Tam Gap if you are not so fit. The way back to the starting point is not too steep and you can enjoy the same view. It took me 2.30 hr walk but depends on how fast you walk.

Humid hike . Fantastic day out, if you decide to go in May don't forget about ambrela. It's very easy to get to from bus station taking bus line number 9. And after 8.5 km and around 250m of elevation have a dip in Big Wave Bay, life can't get any better ;-)

Gorgeous Hike on a Clear Day. Having hiked most of the options in and around Hong Kong, Dragons Back is the best hike with the best views in Hong Kong. On a clear day (the ONLY time to go), you can see a wonderful view of the bay and other mountains in the distance. Simply stunning!

A world away from the city. This very manageable collection of walks gives people the ability to see the very rugged side of natural Hong Kong. It can be challenging at times but for even the most amateur walker, it is doable. It shows a different side to HK and lays to rest the view that the city is nothing but concrete and neon. Not a sign or corporate slogan in sight, just natural landscape and terrain. Start early and go till lunchtime or spend the whole afternoon walking then venture to Shek O for the beach life and then bus back. Bus service from Shek O country park is good and regular.

Great experience. The trail is very interesting with some amazing views. It isnt very difficult - although there are parts wherein we have to walk carefully. I had gone there with my two children (aged 9 and 7 years) who enjoyed it and didn't find it difficult. Remember to carry lots of water, a cap and sun-screen. I would suggest that it is better to do the trek early morning or atleast complete it before noon - else it can get very hot post 11am.

Easy and accessible hike. Great for an early morning run to the beach or just a casual stroll to appreciate the views.Nice to get out of the city and see a bit of nature. Can get a bit busy on the weekends on a nice day though.

Phenomenal views! Worth every breath.. Been to Hong Kong twice and have to say that this is still my favourite thing to enjoy there. The views are incredible (even on an overcastish day). Would strongly recommend.

Great views, not hard. Dragons Back is the last part of the Hong Kong trail which crosses the island. It is not hard or long and finishes at the "surf" beach of Big Wave Bay, so take your bathers and have a swim at the end. The distance is 8.5km and is accessible by public transport at the start and finish of the hike so is very easy to get to and from.To get to the starting point take the MTR to Shau Kei Wan Station, exit A3. Take bus 9 at Shau Kei Wan bus terminal to To Tei Wan on the Shek O road. The bus will pass the Tai Tam Rd roundabout and turn onto Shek O Rd. Along the road there will be a car park with a view point, (there were lots of cars and mini vans parked in it when we went so you cant miss it), get off at the next stop. This is where the trail for the final section of the Hong Kong trail starts. There is a public toilet there. We had printed the map from the Discover Hong Kong website and showed the driver where we wanted to get off. He knew exactly where is was and stopped for us.The first part of the hike has steps as it climbs away from the road. It walks through forests and bushy vegetation. You will come to a trail split where you can take the Dragons Back section or keep walking through the forest and bypass the mountain climb. We chose the Dragons Back. It keeps climbing and crosses the spine of a couple of peaks. The views are great. The path is a bit rugged but not difficult. From there you will descend back to the forest level and meet up with the easier path. Many people use this path for jogging. Follow this path around through the forest and you will eventually get to an asphalt road with a public toilet. We turned right and headed to Big Wave Bay. This was easy and took us to a small park with a pavilion. Follow the path through the park and the path to Big Wave Bay turns right and descends through the forest via steps all the way to the small village Tai Long Wan. Keep heading straight through the village and you will end up at the sea. There are big clean change rooms, toilets and showers at the beach. The water is clear and pleasantly cool. For those timid about swimming the beach is netted and there are lifeguards. The hike has markers along the way and the final marker just outside the village is H100. This is the final marker of the full Hong Kong Trail (50km in distance) To leave just walk out of the village on the road along the coast. At the top of a small hill there is a big bus stop/car parking area. We grabbed a small public bus which took us back to Shau Kei Wan. It cost $10 HKD and does not take Octopus cardIt took us 2 hours to walk the distance and we stopped to take many photos. It is not a hard hike but the ground is uneven in places and has steps to climb up and down. Saw a couple at the start of the trail only 100 metres in. She was in thongs and complaining bitterly. I doubt they went much further. Sunscreen and water are needed. Bathers, towel and camera are a must as well. After reading about the crowds that walk the trail on weekends we decided to do the trail on a Monday morning. Saw only 4 people on the trail proper, but about 20 people on the easier section going through the forest. These were joggers using this part of the trail for exercise.We found information on this hike - and others, at the very informative www.discoverhongkong.com and also there are a couple of really good hiking books that could be found in any bookshop in HK. I think this hike is in the Serious Hikers Guide to Hong Kong.
Strongly recommend. I have heard a lot friends talking about Dragon's back before I was going. All of them strongly recommended there and it really did not disappoint me.
great view. Bring water and snacks, have sunscreen, and camera. those things should be carried bcoz of the hike and avoid the hike in the afternoon coz of sun
An easy hike. This is an easy trail with good views, but very crowded for this reason. If you're lucky, on a clear day, you might catch some parachuters sailing by!

Yes!! There is hiking in Hong Kong. Excellent view. Bring water, weather is hot and humid. Make sure your wear good walking shoes. A h Ike can take anywhere from 2 hours or more depending on your start and end point. excellent views throughout. I would hike it weekday morning only. Get pretty crowed during the weekend.

Great views and not too difficult ... great for a few hours in the morning or early evening to avoid the heat. Dragon's Back is one of the best hikes / walks in Hong Kong for all ages. While there are quite a lot of steps, you don't have to be in great shape to do it (just don't take your kids in strollers as I saw a lot of people carrying strollers up the steps which is crazy). A good pair of shoes, water, and maybe a picnic lunch should be perfect. What is Dragon's Back?"Dragon’s Back" refers to a hike along the ridge of Shek O Peak. It is 284 metres high, with great views of Shek O, Tai Long Wan and even Tung Lung Island. Also, it is Part 8 of the Hong Kong Trail (a 50km trail that has 8 parts). It will typically take 2-2.5 hours to hike and enjoy the scenery.How to get there?There are a few different ways, I chose to take the MTR to Chai Wan (Exit A).then walk there through the Cape Collinson Catholic Cemetery entrance(take the first set of stairs on your left). There are a lot of stairs this way at the beginning but I enjoyed it. I took the bus 9 back to MTR Shau Kei Wan Station (you can also start this way if you prefer). You could also take a bus into Shek O or to the beach.

Do this! Most enjoyable. What makes a good hike? Wonderful companions, great weather, interesting and picturesque trail, good distance and reasonable challenge (though to some this may be an easy trail). The Dragon's trail delivers perfectly on a windy, cool and overcast weather just before summer kicks in. The trail has lots of greenery including bamboo, steps, uneven stones, views like Shek O golf course, eagles, butterflies, the dragon's back and ends with Big Wave Bay! What more can one ask for? We did the hike on a weekday and passed by more than 30 hikers. It is a trail for all ages - we saw hikers of different ages including young kids and older people in their sixties using hiking sticks. Lots of picturesque spots, the start and the end of the route is easily accessible by public transport. There's a toilet at the start of the trail. We did a lot of photo stops and the whole hike including stops took us 3 hours. I did not finish my 1 liter of water.

Great hike. Great exercise. Bring water and snacks, have sunscreen, and camera. The whole hike takes about 2 hrs (can be 3 hrs if more leisure-paced). Bus 9 will drop you off at an entry point (other hikers will likely be on the bus with you). The initial 2-3k i mostly uncovered, next 2-3k is tree-shaded and the last 2-3k is mostly on pavement or cement steps until you reach Big Wave (not really) Beach. If you are in a group of 3-4, might be better to call for a taxi to come pick up to get back to train station (about 90 HKD). Otherwise, wait for Bus 8-10 or 9 to get you back to the MRT.

Nice hike with lovely views. This is a nice way to spend an afternoon. It's a hike that'll take several hours but there are many picturesque views and you can walk to the small 'big wave bay' beach if you keep heading in that direction.

Stunning views for relatively low effort . Dragon's Back, an undulating ridgetop trail between Wan Cham Shan and Shek O Peak, has been nominated as the Best Urban Hike in Asia by TIME Magazine. Follow Stage 8 of the HK Trail, and if the weather's clear along the way you will have great views of Tai Tam Harbour, Stanley, Redhill Peninsula, Mount Parker, Mount Collinson, and Shek O.Is a must-do hike in Hong Kong.
Dragon's Back Walk. We walked a small section of the Dragon;s Back. Be prepared with sensible shoes and suncream. The views are fantastic over the bays. Its amazing how green Hong Kong is.

Breathtaking Views, Good Exercise. Fans of breathtaking views from a hill/mountain must visit Dragon's Back.The terrain is comfortable. Not too steep nor too extreme.Quite manageable even for the uninitiated.Advice:- Start early, if possible commence at 8am to avoid the sun and crowd.- If you want to contain the stress to your knees, you may want to consider use of the hiking stick- if it rained the night before, suggest to give it a skip as the clay laden track would be slippery.- bring along water to hydrate- bring a hat, sun shades for a comfortable climb/hike- take note of the blue painted spots along the way. They seem to be directional markers, quite like the modern-day Hansel & Gretel marked trailDirections:- Take a train and exit at Shau Kei Wan MTR station- Cross over to the Bus Terminus & board service # 9 towards Shek O- Alight at To Tei Wan ( you can look out at the LED display board at the front (top) of the bus- To get back to Shau Kei Wan, cross over to the other side to board service #9The views are breathtaking.Not only do you get some exercise, you are also rewarded with views of the east of Hong Kong Island.Enjoyed every minute of it.

spectacular view. you should try once in your life to visit dragon's back. the view is awesome. luckily, i visited there at a little cloudy day. recommend to visit on weekday because on weekend there are many locals visit there.
Dragon's Back.. Dragon's back is good place to visit. Its like you have to do some tracking also to reach there. Some facilities also there like food and all that.

Stunning. Great trail that takes about 2.5hrs. Taxi to the start from Hong Kong city, walk the train, dip in the sea, grab some lunch & plenty of taxi's waiting to take you back 120HKD each way.Great day out from the city. Suggest robust shoes !
Fabulous hike. If you want to see the real nature side of Hong Kong,take the time to do this walk. Go early in the hot months

Fantastic Short Hike and excellent views.. Really breathtaking walk with fantastic scenery and can end on nearby beach. Easy to reach using transport and conveniently marked .Went there with my wife on HK visit. Takes approx 3 hours to finish it, but totally worth it,

Not as long as they tell you. After reading the information about this, I prepared for a 4 hour walk, took less than 2 hours!Really beautiful walk, fantastic scenery.Easy to get to & no problems finding the start.
Stunning View!. I went there with my friends on weekends, and quite a lot people. For the beginners, you need more than 4 hours to finish it, but worth it, coz the view is so fabulous!

Get away from the city, right in the city!. It's incredible that you can just head up, away from the hustle and bustle, and find yourself walking along a mountain path. The climb was light to medium difficulty and the views were breathtaking. As an added bonus you may see Paragliders at the top. It took us around 3 hours to do the whole walk. We felt that the last bit before Deep Bay beach was mostly walking along a path with vegetation on each side, but not really a great view. Next time, we would walk the first half, then hop on the bus down to the beach instead. A great way to spend an afternoon.

Beautiful Urban Trail. This trail is so easy access, only the first km is uphill and the rest is pretty flat. Scenery was amazing, only after the first km we can enjoy beautiful scenery. Signage was clear, you will never get lost here. I would love to go there again
Gorgeous views....Bring Water!. This hike is well worth the trouble of getting there and getting to the top for the views! Be sure to wear sunscreen, bug repellent and bring water.

Stunning view. A nice little hike, that will take you 2 to 4 hours depending where you start. On a nice clear day you can see Shek O peninsula and take beautiful pictures. I did that trail few times and enjoyed it each time.

Stunning views whilst walking on Dragon's Back. We went on a clear sunny day and it was a magnificent walk on the Dragon's Back trail. The views were fabulous and we were definitely delighted to find this nature walk in the midst of a busy metropolitan city. This review is particularly long as the information I found prior to the walk is scant and directions not clear, so it may only be useful for people who wants to know about this magnificent walk and whether they are able to do it physically.This walk is suitable for all ages with reasonably good fitness and agility. A walking stick helps, especially if you have knees issues as there are no railings on the slopes and some steps are far apart and a bit steep. The tracks are natural paths with stones, dirt and roots. Some portions are shaded, but it's open on most on the slopes and ridges of the mountain, so sun shade and care is important. Also bring enough hydration for a 2 hours walk and maybe some snacks.There are two ways to do this trek - for the young (and young at heart with strong lungs and legs) start at To Tei Wan (土地湾）bus stop - there is a steep climb up to the top. Immediate gratification once you clear the endless flights of natural stairs up as the views are fantastic. From then just follow the track and it winds down towards Tai Tam Gap direction. You can either take the public bus back or continue your way down to Big Wave Bay (there are directions at the break point near the portable toilet. It's a cement paved road till you reach Shek O Country park, then there are stairs down to Big Wave - if you have enough energy, follow the signs to 小西湾 from the park. It's a pleasant walk through shady trees and there is a road leading down to Big Wave Bay as well)Alternatively you take the more gradual way and start from Cape Collision bus stop, walk up the flight of steps beside the Tai Tam Gap Correction Facility (looks like a prison), and follow the road up. There is a public portable toilet at the beginning of the trail and take the slope up to Shek O Peak. The first 20 mins walk is on mostly flat, natural and shady trail that skirts round the slopes before reaching the stairs to Dragon's Back. Walk up the stairs and a few natural slopes, you will reach the top. Take a short break and you can walk along the undulating slopes and drink the views on a clear sunny day. Walk to the end and just follow signs down to To Tei Wan, Shek O Road to take a bus - either down to Shek O village or back to the MTR. Note that this route is good in the morning as the sun is on your back, however it's pretty demanding on your knees as the way down is long and steep. Walking down sideways helps to lessen stress on your knees.Directions : Take MTR to Shau Kei Wan stop on the blue island line and take Exit A3 to get to the bus terminus. From there, take bus no. 9. The stops are reflected on board the bus. it is a fairly regular bus, with 15 mins intervals so you can have your breakfast at the market opposite terminus. (photo of bus stops attached below) From there, you have a choice of which route (as described above) you want to do the hike on Dragon's Back.Nb - don't miss this stunning walk, we misinterpreted the signs and blogs research - and took the route to Big Wave however were lucky to meet a group of Hong Kong walkers and they lead us back to Dragon's Back. The leader of the group is 82 years old - if he can do it, so can you.

Best Hike in Hong Kong. This hike gives you a great view of Hong Kong's fancy areas (stanley bay road etc) The trail is well designated with a good amount of space to cater for busy days. There are a lot of picture / video moments, even suitable for young children to do the hike. On the way down, the terrain is flat and goes through the forests. It passes through several dried out waterfalls and finishes near the cemeteries on the hill. This place is easily accessible using the pubic buses to and from the bus terminus.

A nice hike for beginners. The hike was very beautiful and gave a great view of the ocean, but if you are hiking for the view, there are many others in Hong Kong that offer better ones (ex. Sunset Peak or Lions Rock). The hike is half on top of the mountain, and half completely covered by trees and dirt paths. It is not very hard so it is great for those without much hiking experience, but it can get very crowded (especially on the weekends), so if you are like me you may spend a lot of the hike being stuck behind crowds of people. However, the hike does end at Big Wave Beach, a small beach that is not very crowded located in a cute surfing town. Therefore, if you're also looking to hit the beach, this hike is a perfect way to start your day.
Hike Paradise. Hong Kong is very busy. A lot to do. As soon as you take the right subway exit you can reach this hike. No one around- Nature and yourself. Great time to calm down and have a relax.

Wonderful hike, offering great views over HK.. We picked the Easter weekend to do this hike, so it was quite busy. But, the weather was perfect with sunny, clear skies and a welcome cooling breeze.The hike begins on the Shek O road (easy to get to using the #9 bus from Shau Kai Wan MTR to To Tei Wan stop)The hike starts with a short climb which is quite easy hiking, up to the Dragon's Back. There are some great views of Hong Kong island at the top.Some great "photo opportunities" all the way along.When you descend from the Dragon's Back, you are left with an easy shaded hike to Big Wave Bay for a refreshing dip in the ocean and a cold beer.The hike is quite easy, many young children and some school trips were doing it easily.
Great views. We did this hike, and ended up on a beach. It's moderate level of fitness is required and mixes up a sun, forest, miuntains and water views.Take a taxi from subway station.

Most Challenging but enjoyable!. Having read about the Dragon's Back, we thought we could pay a visit. We started at To Tei Wan which was a steep hike up to the top. Once at the top do not be mislead by the distances shown! Going back the way we came up seemed shorter, however, we bumped into a couple of locals who told us to head towards Tai Tam Gap, although a longer distance it was a more gentle descend!Note there are no toilets along the route or stores, so be prepared with supplies particularly sun cream and water.It took us 4 hours (had an 8 year old with us) to complete the hike between To Tei Wan and Tai Tam gap on very hot day (29 oC)
Excellent hike. little travel needed to get there, but worth the views and hike. It is full sun so summer will mean sunscreen, hats and water. But the sea views will give you a new perspective on HK

Awesome hike. Dragon's Back is the most popular hike on HK island. It offers breathtaking views of the sea and beaches. It's part of the Hong Kong Trail (section 8), which can represent the first or last section of the total trail, depending on where you'll start it. It can also represent an excellent choice for a day hike including Dragon's Back and an afternoon at the beach, at Big Bay Wave, just at the end of the trail. Expect a little crowd during weekends and holidays.

My favorite part of the whole trip. Make sure you know exactly how to get here or you might end up lost. We started at the end that was a pretty vertical climb but took you straight to the awesome views. I think the more traditional route would be to start from the end that is mostly covered and gradual and then do the steep decent rather than climb all the steps (this might be more 'rewarding' to get the great views at the end of your journey). However, if you don't mind stairs and you're pressed for time you could always climb it, hike until the views are exhausted, and then double back down the stairs. It was a beautiful and hot summer day so bring water and some snacks. We probably crossed a total of 3 other groups our whole time out there; it was very peaceful.
Heaven on earth. Take a walk in the morning hours, before it gets too hot (in the summer), do it on a sunny day to get breath taking views of Hong Kong Island South.

Beautiful half Day Trekking with finished at the beach. Even with younger kids not a problem, easy up and downs on top, later shady walk downwards to ShekO beach, absolutely beautiful, just sometimes to full with fellow weekend walkers.

The Dragon' Back from Shek O to Big Wave Bay. We picked a beautiful though busy day to do this hike. The weather was perfect - sunny with clear views but a cooling breeze.The hike begins on the Shek O road (easy to get to using the #9 bus from Shau Kai Wan MTR to To Tei Wan stop)It begins with a climb up (pretty easy hiking) to the Dragon's Back. You the get some stunning views of HK. When you come down from the Dragon's Back, you are left with a nice shaded hike to Big Wave Bay for a refreshing dip in the ocean.Our 7 year old was easily able to do the hike.

This should be the number one thing to do in Hong Kong with the beach.. Ill write my review in some detail because this attraction is a little bit out of town and can be tackled a number of ways. I'll tell you how first and then why it's so good. Believe me, it's beautiful. First, is it for you? This is not a beginners' walk. It's an intermediate walk. If you have mobility issues it will be difficult, although many elderly people give it a red hot go with some assistance from sticks, so it can be done by many, but it's not beautifully paved all the way. You will have to overcome rocks, uneven ground, there are drops of about a foot and a half, as well as steps of equal measure. It is both exposed and covered in parts which makes it hot and cool. There's a lot of clay, so weather would be a consideration if wet. There are lots of people at different levels of fitness doing this walk, but everyone was sweating and needing rest from time to time. It's not a very difficult hike, but it's not easy. You won't need hiking boots, sneakers will do, but I wore boots and I think it was better to do so if you have some. It was sunny when I went, yes I got burnt on the back of my neck. It was cloudy at the peak which limited views but every now and then the clouds cleared, also on the other side there were views because the cloud was a bit detoured by the hill itself, so it can be worth it even if a bit cloudy. The views are the best I've seen in Hong Kong. It was my favourite thing to do. Definite nature satisfaction attraction. People here have written two hours. I'd say give yourself three and go from one end to the other, more on this later. Did you know you can mountian bike here? You'd want to be an expert though, there are tight corners and steep runs and frankly too many people to get in your way. If you are hell bent on doing it fair enough, you'll need a permit though. Ok, so now if you've decided it's for you, there is the how. Directions1. Take the island line train to Chai Wan station. 2. Downstairs there are lots of buses, go there. Get the 16M bus. However we got the 16X bus because it was a public holiday and things got confusing. You could check the timetable and bus websites but it's of little importance because should there be no buses you could get a taxi it's only 5 mins drive away. 3. Have exact change for the bus or a proper octopus card. The daily tourist card is no good. $7 HK per person. So, like $1 US4. The bus winds around and takes you up a hill. You're looking for the crematorium. Our bus stop was missing due to a public holiday and the Ching Ming festival, so everyone was out and about. Here is what you will really see. A war memorial in white on the right. A Muslim graveyard on the right. A prison on top of the hill on the left. Directly opposite a big view of the graveyard and city buildings to the right. At this point you are wanting to get off. 5. When off the bus, there's a steep uphill that meets with a t intersection. Go left. You want to be on Cape collinson road. 6. The sign screams at you! It is so clear and obvious that if you are considering approaching anywhere else and trying your luck I would advise against it. It will have some portaloos, and big signs saying Hong Kong trail, Dragons back and other stuff. 7. Walk up the stairs. If you aren't sure, ask someone, I asked a police guy in English and he knew exactly what I wanted. Now you're on the path. There are a few ways through it but this is what I'd do, which isn't ezac,t how we did do it. Follow signs to the dragons back. Huff and puff sweat and swear look and see and enjoy. Now, no matter if you entered where I said or not, you can continue through to the other side. If you went the way I did, you'll find the 9 bus on the other side. Follow the signs to Shek o road. I think it was about $7 HK for the bus but I only had a $100 HK note and no change so I got a taxi instead. Taxi to Shek O Beach $40 HK and we had traffic, between two people this was ok. After a hot hike and all sweaty, and seeing the beach from the views, it's the best way to finish the hike. You can get the 9 bus back to the train station for another $7 HK. The beach has showers, change rooms, restaurants and street food. So, I like nature, I like seeing amazing views. I like the beach. I think it is so different to the city in Hong Kong that you should go to see what else Hong Kong has to offer. It makes me think of what other nature attractions there are. All up I'd say you need 3 hours to complete the hike up and down (2 for faster walkers, 1 for runners - yes, there are runners). Then add 15 mins to the beach plus 2 hours for swimming and eating. Then another 20 minutes back to the station. Get on a double decker bus and see th views again from the top. The bus stop at the beach is clear, there's a terminus sign and people everywhere. Really, it's half a day if you leave early, or the main part of your day if you leave later. Take water, nowhere to buy although I think you can refill before you go up. sunscreen, toilet paper in case you need to go bush, only portaloos at the bottom, snacks. Maybe not the bananas I compressed in my backpack. You'll need some small change for the bus. There is no entry fee to the park, none for the beach, but maybe you'll want to eat at the beach or at least want an iced tea. Transport $60 HK for the daily tourist cardBus x 2 $15 HKemergency taxi money $120 HK if you need three rides if your bus isn't running and you want to go to the beach Meals $60 each and drinks $20 each so maybe $80 HK$300 HK total to keep it easy but hopefully you won't need that $120 taxi money. So about $200 HK for lunch and most of the day out. It really was a must see, confirmed for me that there is more to do in Hong Kong, worth the effort. I hope this review helps you.
nice trekking with wonderful views. do it if u are in HK, the way is -+ easy about 4,5 km with amazing views. sport shoes are more than enough for walking

Proper hiking, but only 2 hours long so a morning or afternoon is enough.. Great walk for sorting out jet lag. You need proper shoes as the path is Uneven in places. It goes from sea level to almost 300 metres and up and down, think walking along a dragons spine. The views are fantastic, both sides, as long as you have a reasonable head for heights. Lots of the trail is through the forest so a lot of trees and wildlife. A major and wonderful escape from the city.

Most Awesome trail in Hong Kong. This trail probably has the beast view in Hong kong. Overlooking the Shek O beach is just awesome. Be sure to alight after Cape Collison road or else you will miss the trail jumpoff. The trail has trees for shade for about 2km, after that you will get a sunburn. better bring an umbrella.

Dragon's back trail. This trail is locat at the southwest of hongkong island.take mtr to Shau Kei Wan then take bus9 to To Tei Wan.there are about a hundred or more meters of steep steps up the hill.the trail is about 8.5km and took me around 2.5 hours at moderate pace.on top of the hills u get to see beaches,mountains,south china sea,forests,urban areas,villa complexes,sea villages etc.after the dragons back.there is a steep winding walk surrounded by only bushes and trees,then a bit of road and finally ends at a beach .nearby is a minivan stop which takes u back to Shau Kei Wan mtr station.i highly recommend and enjoy!

Beautiful hike, nice beach at the end. The hike is quite intense...a LOT of stairs, and very narrow in some places (check the local running club schedules to make sure there aren't any races at the same time, or you will have problems). However, the scenery at the top is totally worth it. There's also a lovely beach that's a 10 minute bus ride away from the end of the hike.

Great hiking. Take the MTR till Chain Wan and climb the steps of the cemetery in front of you, quite steep but in a while you are on a trail path and it seems you are so far away from the city. Keeping going on the trail you climb the Dragon's back with great view of HK island and you can even end the hiking taking a swing on the beach of Shek O.Higly recommended .

Great Hike!. This hike has amazing views. You get to see the islands, the jungle, and a beach at the end. Just be careful for the spider webs! It can get pretty humid and there are limited places to buy water. Bring plenty!If you continue on the Dragon's Back you end at a lovely beach. After spending a few hours on the beach, you can catch a bus back from the village back to Hong Kong.
Place to visit in HK. The view over the beaches is great and the hike i pretty easy actually. Takes only on hour and a half to hike the path and it its easy to reach with minibuses.

Great hike with stunning views. this hike is a bit steep in the beginning, but you will enjoy the scenary later on. It can be crowded during the weekends. Before going down to Big Wave Bay, go around the bay and come down with the steps. That takes about 30 minutes more, but the views are good. And you can relax from the walk with a good drink at the bar (even some food is available)
Easy hike with great views. We did the Loop. It was an easy hike...we took 2.5 hours for entire hike with photo stops along the way (we are beginners). The view is fantastic.

Great afternoon spent. Started at Shek O entrance and ended at Big Wave beach . Took 3 hours at a leisurely pace . Only 1/2hr of uphill walking at the beginning . Was well sign posted and the view was wonderful . Not a difficult trek but would be good to have good trail shoes and a walking pole at least as there are many rocks and steep downhill portions .

Beautiful!!!. It was such a beautiful walk and the views were well worth the effort. We walked the trail quite early in the morning so there was very little traffic on the paths. As we were coming back there were certainly more people making their way up the track.

This is a nice hike that it is moderately intensive.. This gives you great views of the ocean. The elevation change is gradual and it is not long to the top. Also, you will see the peoples of Hong Kong out and about.

Fun Hike Just Outside the City. Beautiful and someone challenging hike, depending on your pace. I was hesitant, but very glad we ended up going on this hike. Some parts were windy, and the weekend was a little crowded, but the views and the lunch at the beach at the end made the experience well worth the trip. Perfect nature get-away after a few days in the city. Make sure you wear proper shoes as there were rocks, roots and steps where one could trip.
Good hike. Beautiful view on Tam tam bay. Bring some bottle water because it's hot and not so easy :) If you like walk in forest, take amazing pictures, you should do it. I recommande to you

Walk rather than Hike but offers beatiful sceneries. Dragon's Back trail offers a great way of escaping the daily rush of the city. If you are visiting HK just shortly I wouldnt say this trail is a must but for I would defiantely recommend it for everybody else.

Excellent hike but be careful. Dragons back is a great hike for both the experienced and beginner level hikers. The views are amazing and the path is not very demanding. However when coming down the path can be very very slippery so one should make sure they have appropriate footwear and should be very carefully. The best way to get there is to get the Island MTR line.

Excellent trip, but hard. My wife and myself travelled the Dragon's back and enjoyed it very much. We're used to hiking and we loved the views and the road itself.However, I must mention that it's not an easy walk and for my wife, in the beginning of second trimester of pregnancy it was difficult.

Probably even better when it's not foggy. Great hike. I missed the bus stop for the regular starting point, and had been concerned about the fog at that point (it was very dense on the road), so I rerouted and started at Big Wave Bay. No views thanks to the fog, but great hiking and environment, I would definitely do again even foggy.

Amazing!!!. It's hard to believe that this incredible hike is just 40 minutes from downtown Kowloon. We took the ferry to HK Island and then took a bus up to Dragon's Back. It is not a difficult hike and it has great views along the way. The paths get more crowded on the weekends, so go during the week if you can.

Great Views. This is an excellent way of getting some great views of Hong Kong. It is fairly steep at the start and then once you are on the 'Dragons Back' the superb views can been seen. Many bays and even a golf course can all be seen from high up. At the finish it is down hill all the way to Big Wave Bay. For your well deserved drink get a taxi to Stanley. Just ensure you can wait for Big Wave Bay for a toilet stop!
excellent views. It just shows that there is more to see than just Skyscapers in Hong Kong. Th etreck is quiet hilly and steep at times but just go at your own pace. The views are simply stunning.

Wonderful hike not far from the city. This is a wonderful hike that forms part of the Hong Kong trail. The full length from Big Wave Bay to Shek O Road is about 8km but if you want to save yourself some climbing and are not interested in the bay you can start half way. We did the walk from north to south, in the opposite direction to which most people do it. We took bus no 9 from Shau Kei Wan metro station and got out near the junction of Cape Collinson Road and Shek O Road near the Rehabilitation centre. After a steep set of stairs we commenced the walk. The first 2km are a flat trail and easy walking and offer nice views over Tai Tam Harbour. We ascended a natural staircase which got us to the top plateau of the walk which forms the Dragons Back. From here were excellent views although it was very windy down to Big Wave Bay and Shek O. It was a well formed track and the whole walk took us about 2 hours. There were growing numbers of crowds on the walk so it is best to do it early. The number 9 bus has a stop at the end of the walk.

Good hike, nice day trip. This is a great hike for the first section. The dragons back itself gives a decent challenge with many steps, good views over Shek O and clean air.But it is busy with noisy locals, many wielding the obligatory selfie stick and playing loud canto-pop from their phone. The back section of the trail is a little dull, but the climb down into Big Wave Beach is scenic and worth it. Take a detour through the Country Park for the reservoirs, peaks and forest trails. You could easily spend days exploring around here
A great hike on HK island with easy access. I have done this hike a couple of times, and it is a very nice trip, with varying scenic views, ending up in the cosy Big Wave Bay.

Great Experience. We hired a guide to lead us through some less traveled paths on Dragon's Back. There was so much to see and experience. Where we went the paths were sometimes challenging, but this what we were anticipating. I would not go on a group tour, but would highly recommend getting a private guide to lead you to your areas of interest.

Great Walk in a Busy City. Did this on Chinese New Years day. Walked along the footpath rather than the touristy path. Worth going off the main track however the entrance to the footpath is hard to find and a bit overgrown in places.

Lives up to it's name. I did this walk during a recent visit to HK. The start of the walk is bit hard to find-you need to take the MTR (Island line) to the second last station and then Bus 9 to get to the beginning of the walk. The first half of the walk is fairly steep and pretty rocky but he second part is a bot downhill and fairly level (although still quite rocky in parts). The views from the top of the walk are expansive and you can see pretty much both sides of HK Island. Parts of the walk are fairly exposed and if it is windy it can be a bit of a challenge. The walk takes a couple of hours to do going at a reasonable pace and ends up at Big wave Bay were you are able to catch Bus 9 back to the MTR.The track would be very difficult to navigate if it has been raining.

Great hike!. This was a perfect day trip to escape the busy and crowded city. We took the number 9 bus from the Shau Kei Wan subway stop and it took maybe an hour from Mong Kok. The stop is not the last stop, but you will probably see a bunch of other hikers, so get off when they get off, or ask the driver. The hike was great, the trail a little crowded but the views were beautiful.After the hike we got back on the bus and went into Sheko, which was really interesting.

Fantastic vies, great exercise and not too demanding. There are plenty of steps to get up onto the dragon back - particularly if approached from Shek Oh, but it is worth it as the views are spectacular. Good trainers or walking shoes are essential as the path is uneven, steep in places and quite slippery when damp. It would also be a good idea to take water. We started from the Tam Tai end (the bus stops outside the correctional institute) and it took about 90 mins to get to the exit onto the road into Shek O. We had been told that the last bit of the walk into Shek O was not nice so we caught the small local bus instead. All in all a great walk.
Great afternoon hike. A must hike with family and friends. Lunch afterward in Big Wave Bay or head back to Stanley. Great views from multiple spots and take your time.

Lovely hike. I went in miserable, windy weather but still had a great time. I walked from Chai Wan MTR station (but should've gotten bus 9 from Shau Kei Wan up to the Shek O / Cape Collinson Road intersection!), up and along the Dragon's Back and down to the south-western part of Shek O Road. Superb views and good exercise. An easy to moderate hike if you are relatively fit.
Fantastic hike. Very nice change in scenery along the hike, the trees offer a welome shade on sunny days. Can get crowded though.

Rewarding views. This is not an easy trail, One has to climb mountains and negotiate steep slopes, and it takes more than three hours (maybe even much longer for some). But there are stairs in many places and the path is always well marked. The views of the sea on both sides are magnificent and at the end of the trail you are at Big Waves Bay, so when the temperature is reasonable you can take a dip in the sea. For unknown reason, the description in the Hong Kong information booklet does not mention that once you are at Big Waves Bay you can take bus number 9 to Shek O and from there you have bus number 9 back to the MTR station Wan Chai. My wife and I thought we would have to walk all the way to Shek O after we finish the trail, as we wanted to also be in Shek O and we did not like the idea of walking the uninteresting part. One can find taxies at Big Wave Bay and also there are minibuses directly from there to the MTR station.

Perfect ending. Follow directions on previous reviews. It's a great hike, nice and easy, with great views, hard to believe you're in HK if all you imagine is the busy metropolis with skycrapers. End at Shek-O with inexpensive thai lunch. Note that if you're the first on the trail in the very early morning, you might be fighting spider webs, but you'll be clearing them for the rest of us!.

Excellent views. Easy walk. Bit of difficulty finding the path to start, but the effort was worth it. Amazing view over eastern HK. Wide open and no shade on a hot sunny day, so take a hat, sunscreen and water.

Hiking in HK. A great start to someones introduction tomHiking in Hong Kong. this trail takes you up to the top of a mountain ridge so only hard part is the beginning after which you walk along the ridge with fantastic views either side of Hong kong and islands

Relaxed Walk, great view. This walk is quite relaxed, at leased compared to the view that you are getting. The walk starts with a medium-steep uphill track leading to where you walk over the ridge of the mountains tops and after the many photo-ops you can continue on to Big Wave bay. The only minus is the route to Big Wave Bay, which is quite boring and disproportionally long, however worth it when you get there. Bathrooms at the start of the track and at Big Wave Bay and the bus stops just at the start of the track.Ps. when you get to big wave bay, walk up the hill and take the PLB (3min) to Shek O. There is a great restaurant there "Shek O Thai & Chinese Seafood".
Easy hike. easy trail and excellent scenery. ends up at shek o beach where we barbecued. short minibus ride from the city and a nice day out for those who want to get away from the hustle and bustle

Awesome Views and a Break from the City. We really enjoyed hiking Dragon's Back and would definitely recommend it. We had a group of 6 people - traveling from Central, we took an Uber there and decided to take the bus to the MTR on the return. The bus / MTR was an easy option.We saw a number of conflicting sources regarding how long it would take to hike various distances. We had a limited amount of time and wanted to keep our hike to 2 hours. Our group was of an average to above average fitness level (ages 26-55) and we hiked at a moderate pace, stopping to take photos, etc. We ended up hiking from the "Starting Point" near Tei Wan Village to Shek O Peak and back and it took us roughly 1 hour 20 min.

Great break from city crowds. Did this walk in a Thursday, so missed the crowds. Great instructions on how to get to the start on Hong Kong Tourist Board's web site, so easy to get there. Fantastic views and a breath of fresher air after the city. Although there are plenty of steps to climb, it's not difficult. Couple of hours sees it done. End in Big Wave Bay for easy return to city.

The "LOGISTICS" from Central HKG.... We took the MTR to Chai Wan, then just jumped into a cab and asked for Shek O Rd Lookout Pt. He dropped us at the start for HK$54 for 3 people. Followed the route round to Pottinger's Gap then took the "maintenance steps" down via the cemetary toBack to the MTR. Ignore the "private" & "unpassable" signs. Simples.

Fantastic views!. We caught the express bus from Central to Stanley, then a taxi to the start of the track of the way to Shek O. It is not a difficult walk, very steep in parts and the views amazing. Make sure you pick a clear day as the constant HK haze limits the view.

THE WILDERNESS MUST BE EXPLORED!. Fantastic experience, I loved every minute of it.I was in HK for just over a week and this is how my girlfriend and I spent our last day (I had a lot of persuading to do).We did the trek the opposite way. Get the MTR to Chai Wan and take a walk to the graveyard, trek up a lot of steep steps and follow the signs.The Dragon's Back is part of the Hong Kong trail! It goes on for over 50km so be sure once you reach Shek-O road grab a bus or taxi. We stupidly kept walking towards a beach and ended up putting an extra 2 hours on our walk back.A taxi back to our hotel in Wanchai was around 120HKD which was fantastic.My girlfriend and I are not experienced at hiking. I thought the toughest challenge was going up the steps in the beginning. The rest was ok!Some spectacular views from the top even if it's cloudy! :)To check out my photos of Dragon's back have a look on my instagram page: __fightoffyourdemons

Alternate Route. Most people walk south to north taking the No. 9 bus from Shau Kei Wan to To Tei Wan village...alternatively you could start the hike at Chai Wan MTR Station by climbing the stairs in Cape Collision Cemetery. It's about a 500 step climb and more strenuous than the normal hike. Passing through the cemetery is a different experience. When you reach the end of the trail at To Tei Wan village, I'd recommend catching the No. 9 bus to Shek O instead of heading back to Shau Kei Wan. You can "hike" out to an island off Shek O or grab a beer along the beach depending upon the day / time of year. Doing in the hike this way takes about three - four hours from the MTR Station to the Bus Stop.As for the hike, it's Interesting although I thought the views from the top would have been a little better and shown more islands. There's a hike that goes from Discovery Bay to Mui Wo where at the peak you have much better views of Kowloon, Hong Kong, Lamma, Cheung Chau, etc. Even if it's sunny, it may not be clear and you'll barely be able to make out Lamma Island or Stanley Peninsula. The best views are of Big Wave Beach and Shek O.
