Beautiful Hike. Loved this hike,absolutely a must do, better in the winter! Probably you can have the best scenic views, and it is definitely not too hard.
Beautiful haven right outside the city, amazing views. Try to avoid Sundays if you can, it gets crowded with tourists and locals. However, the hike and views were amazing.

Meh. This was a very easy place to get to, but I think calling this a hike is totally misleading. Yes you are outside on not sealed paths, but when you see people with their toddlers and little fluffy dogs on the trail I would be more inclined to refer to this as walking path. There were some nice views of the coast and the like and it was nice to take the extended walk through to Big Way Bay, but there are better places to go if you want to have some outdoors time. Be prepared for a lot of people who may not share your walking speed.

Stunning views, but crowded and no shade. Good things about the trail:- The trail head is accessible by public transportation!- You get incredible views, and countless photo ops; I went on a misty day and everything still looked great- The trail passes by several cute towns that you can explore- The trail is relatively well maintained and not difficult, plenty of signsNot so optimal things about the trail:- It will probably be crowded, especially when you near a trail head; we had to politely bump our way past lots and lots of groups- It's not very shaded at ALL. Despite tons of sunscreen and hats, we all got mildly sunburned. This isn't a trail with lots of tall trees and shade, so be prepared for tons of sun!All in all, definitely worth checking out! It's an oasis from the city madness, and probably not what you'd expect to be doing while in Hong Kong.

Awesome Hiking Location. The start of Dragon's Back Trial is easily accessible by public transport. The climb up to the summit is relatively safe and easy to climb, good for both the young and old people. Love the cool weather and the breathe-taking scenery atop the trail. A must visit place for those who love hiking or doing trails.

Spectacular views!. Despite the misty day, i was absolutely stunned by the beautiful views of HK. Once you get up there, it is a moderate hike and you go through a variety of terrains. I would recommend for all ages!

good for an urban hike; crowded. for a hike close to a major city, it's great. trail in great shape, well signed, and lots of viewpoints. on a day of great weather, we were almost always in a long line of people. great to do as a loop with excellent bus services to/from trailheads. be prepared to wait a bit if you end up a the bus stop towards the end of the day.

A different view of Hong Kong. This hike was on my to-do list when planning my most recent Hong Kong trip. TA reviews were a great help, but I also consulted the concierges at the 2 hotels I stayed at. Interestingly, the Mandarin Oriental recommended the hike in one direction, starting at Cape Collinson and ending at To Tei Wan, while the Four Seasons advised the opposite direction, as does the Hong Kong Tourism Board's "The Inside Guide to Hikes and Walks in Hong Kong".I ended up doing the hike the Four Seasons' way for the following reasons: 1) Shek O Peak, the highest point, is nearer to the To Tei Wan start, so you're doing the hardest part of the hike first. 2) At Cape Collinson, you have the choice of ending your hike here or turning right and continuing past Pottinger Gap down to Big Wave Bay Beach, which is what I did.As prior TA reviews and everyone has said, you can access the trail by taking the MTR to Shau Kei Wan, crossing the street to the SKW Bus Terminus and taking Bus 9 ("Shek O") to the To Tei Wan stop along Shek O Road. I did this hike on a Sunday morning and was off to a late start, so I ended up taking a taxi to To Tei Wan (trying to avoid the inevitable weekend crowds). The taxi cost $123 HKD. There are 2 porta-potties at both ends of the trail--the flushing feature did not work in either of the ones I used. And bring your own tissues just in case. Plus bring water and a jacket in winter, and possibly sunglasses and a hat. It gets very windy on the crest in the winter.From this end, the trail immediately goes up, up, up. Steep parts of the trail can have paved stairs, rock stairs, dirt stairs framed in wood, just rocks, or just dirt. First you see views west of Tai Tam Bay and Harbour, then you see views east of Shek O Beach, Village and Golf Course. Then you see Big Wave Bay and Beach. Again, it was very windy this time of year. After the peak, it's mostly downhill (but a few uphills) until you merge with the Hong Kong trail section of the hike. This is a mostly flat, lower-level trail through woodland, crossing a few small streams, only one of which had water this time of year. The trail was PACKED with an almost continuous line of people of all sorts going the other direction, some talking VERY LOUDLY in Cantonese. About 2 hours had passed by the time I reached the fork at Cape Collinson. From here, I turned right, following the signs to Big Wave Beach, following a pave road to Pottinger Gap (there's a small park here, but no restrooms), then down a mostly all rocks trail to Tai Long Wan Village and Big Wave Bay Beach (about 45 min.). The village is small, all-white, with several shops selling snacks and rental surf equipment and wetsuits. There's a nice park and playground, with good restrooms. Then I caught first site of a new type of human for me--the Chinese surfer. There were lots of Caucasian/expat surfers as well. But the Chinese ones--it was like I was in Hawaii!--so different from the frenzied all-business Chinese running around Central, smartphones in hand. The beach itself is small and rather narrow, but with decent-sized waves breaking very close to shore. Along one side is a snack shop with a viewing deck and tables. An area with stone barbecues is on the other side, with restrooms and showers at the rear. There is an ancient rock carving near the barbecues. Someone was flying a drone over everyone. From the parking area here, you can catch the 9 bus again, but not on Sundays. A mini-bus that holds 16 passengers takes you back to the MTR station for $10 HKD. This is what I did, but after a little confusion. There is no specific time to pay--some paid when they got on, others when they got off--the driver somehow remembers faces and if you paid. Also, an English-speaking passenger confirmed the bus went to Shau Kei Wan, and pointed out the station entrance once there. Alternatively, you can walk along Big Wave Beach Road and then Shek O Road past the golf course into Shek O Village and Beach. There are apparently some nice restaurants there, as well as a bus 9 stop. Shek O Road is a narrow, winding mountain road with narrow shoulders. Many people were walking along these shoulders, single-file, while cars and especially buses nearly clipped them.This is a nice hike to do, at least once. I'm not the fittest person, so the uphill hike was rather strenuous for me, but some athletes were running up the hills. I laugh at the TA reviewers who call the hike easy or leisurely. Certainly a nice look at a different side of Hong Kong, with nice views and beaches to boot.
awesome views. A great walk and a great way to see some other views of Hong Kong. Its not a difficult walk and you end up at a beautiful beach, Big Wave Bay!

Most Eastern Ridge on the Hong Kong Island with Lovely View. The Dragon's Back is in the middle of a foot trail, which stretches from the right foot of the frog-shaped Hong Kong Island to around the middle part of the East side of the Island, is one of the most pleasant and scenic hikes in Hong Kong.The trail starts at Shek O Road, just off To Tei Wan (a bay). Aftering a gentle climb, you will get on top of the ridge of a hill which runs all the way northward along the small peninsula which forms the right foot of the Hong Kong Island. It is the ridge which gives the name 'Dragon's Back'. Once on top, you can have, on the left side, a very good look of the other foot of the Hong Kong Island where the Red Hill Peninsula. On the right side, you can have a bird eyes' view of the beautiful Shek O beach and the lush green golf course adjacent to the it. The plaque in the picture above tells you which is which when you look out from the Dragon's Back. Further on, you will have the opportunity to have a good look of the Big Wave Bay which is reputedly to be best place for surfing in Hong Kong. You can deduce the reason from its name. At about two-third of its length and two hours into the journey (if you walk leisurely), you will arrive at Cape Collison, where the trail takes a right turn and begin its descend into Big Wave Bay. You can exit here if you want to end the hike early. If you continue and embark on the downhill path, you will arrive at the scenic Big Wave Bay in about half an hour. It is much smaller than Shek O Beach and has much less swimmers (because of the big waves), but it is a tranquil and clean little one with fresh air blowing in form the East straight from the Pacific Ocean.There are a few eateries there where you can have some snacks or a cup of coffee on the beach. While there, you may take the opportunity to examine the stone carving on the rock surface on left hand side of the beach. It is believed that the carving might have been done about 3,000 years ago in an effort to calm the rough sea just outside the bay and to ensure good catches from the water!Transportation is easy. For the start, takes the No. 9 bus from Shaukiwan to To Tei Wan (just watch out for the name of the stop name ("To Tei Wan") displayed before each stop). For the return, you can either hop onto a red public light bus which will take you back to Shakiwan for about HK$10, or you can take the No. 9 bus to Shek O, before taking it again on its return journey to Shaukiwan. Just one last word of caution. Shade is limited on the ridge. So avoid hot summer day and be sure take your sun-glasses, hat and plenty of fluid with you for the trail. You will not be able to find any food kiosks or drink vendors until you reach Big Water Bay.

Dragon's Back Trail. It was a nice trail. We hiked for a good part of the afternoon and then went to Big Wave Bay and Sheko. The trail isn't very difficult to hike on and has rest stops/picnic places at regular intervals.
Fantastic Walk. Dragons Back is my favourite walk. The viewsf the sea and little islands is wonderful .You must do this hike!
Enjoye.d our walk very much. The walk started with lots of climbing of steps through the cemetery. The weather was good and the views from the top was totally worth it.
Great hike with amazing views. Great views along the ~3 mile hike. Points in the jungle and on the edge of a cliff. Grab the bus at the end to get yourself a deserved cold beer
Nice view. Moderate to difficult hike. Rewarding view at the top. Fresh and breathtaking air. Hike during the winter period. Summer is brutal here

Nice hike. We took the kids for a 6km walk over the Dragons back while visiting Hong Kong. A great walk with some uphills and downhill. We took the "slightly overgrown path" over Mt Collinson. This was a fabulous walk in the jungle. The junction is some hundred meters from the Dragons back peak to the right and marked with red stripes. In the end there is a steep downhill to the Pottinger gap, so you have good balance to manage it. But it is worth it. Total length was about 6km and it took us three hours.We took a taxi to the starting point and the local bus from Tso Tui Wan back to HK. Convinient.

Nice hike. Take the Metro line out and then a bus with tremendous views will drop you across from the starting point. Wasn't much signage ahead of time, but fortunately a couple of other riders appeared ready to go hiking, so I jumped off after them. Once across the street, the trail ascends briefly, and is well signed. Had fantastic weather, even better views. Fair number of hikers on a mid-week morning. Must be like a freeway on the weekends.

Do Not Miss This Fabulous Walk. The Dragon's Back is a walk of about 3 miles giving awesome views of the coast of Honk Kong and Shek O in particular. There is a fair climb to start with but it is well worth the effort.
Great Family Hike. Took kids on this hike frequently while living in HK. Pretty easy with only a few areas of incline. Finished by catching bus at end of trail into Skek-o for Thai food.

Good Leisure Trek. Its an easy trek...beautiful view all along..Can be clubbed with a swim and an evening dinner.The Ridge walk is easy and simple.We had an extremely good weather on our side..The view over the harbour is breathtaking..

Great time trekking!. The Dragon's Back is a great place to do some trekking. We did the route from the start all the way to the Big Wave Bay Beach. It was about 8.5km. The initial section was mainly a climb, and then going from hill to hill with ups and downs. You will eventually come to a part where you can either turn left to go back to Shek O Road, or turn right and continue a long trek to the Big Wave Bay Beach. We chose to go to the Big Wave Bay Beach. Right at the end, there is a section of over 1km of downhills.To get to the starting point, you take the MTR to Shau Kei Wan, take exit A3, go to the bus terminus and take bus 9. You get off at To Tei Wan along Shek O Road.When we finished at Big Wave Bay Beach, we walked to the nearby bus stop and took a small bus back to the MTR station. Depending on your pace, you can take from 2-6 hours. We took a leisurely walking pace and finished around 4 hours. It is good to go prepared with water, a cap, sunscreen, and a good pair of shoes.

Shau Kei Wan, Bus 9, Big wave bay!. Shau kei wan is all you need to know. My one worry was getting to the hike but knowing that shau kei wan is the MTR stop. As you go up the stairs you will see an exit for the bus terminal then you are look for bus 9 which is sign posted easily! Biggest queue all with huge bag packs. There are no drink or food stops so stock up well. When you reach the sign dragons back follow it and you cant get lost as its one route. Where you may get confused is where you see dragons back sign showing you finished it then you will have a choice of sheik o road one way or the other way, went went the other as we didnt want to see the same views back to sheik o so we followed the other way which led us to another 50 50 sign. We then followed BIG WAVE BAY. That then takes you to the Beach! Shuttle buses are there and taxis. A taxi back to star ferry for £6. Great day. We are camera lovers and it took us exactly 3 hours! I hope this makes sense and helps you as this worried me the most. Enjoy Hong Kong!

an easy track with open view of greens.. an easy hike and have open view, you feel like you climbed up a hill and get a 360 perspective. a few hours and you are there, a good hike for burning some calories with a little sweat.

Wonderful view very fresh air. The directions are easy to follow to get to Dragon's Back hike. http://www.discoverhongkong.com/eng/see-do/great-outdoors/hikes/dragons-back-hiking-tour.jsp take the mtr the sheung wan and the bus stop terminal is right there. Tell the bus driver you want to drop off at To Tei Wan. The start of the hike is at the bus stop. Not easy to get lost, wear comfortable sports shoes or hiking shoes. Remember to check the weather before heading there, if it's rainy or misty the view wouldn't be as great but do bring a raincoat and a windbreaker if you are going in winter. It wouldn't be cold but it would be windy. Highly recommend this hike.

Amazing hike with fantastic views. You have to do this hike when you come to Hong Kong! My personal favourite part of the trip. Easy to get to by bus, just be aware that there are several hikes around the area. Dragons back is about 2 hours long and fairly easy (steep uphill at points) but the Hong Kong trail is much longer, around 8km and finishes at Big Wave Beach. We personally did the loop of Dragons Back and finished at Shek-O beach which was beautiful and well worth a visit with loads of places to eat surrounding it. Buses take you back to the MTR station or you can get a taxi easily. Well worth the hike for the incredible views over the bay and see, especially good on a clear day.

An easy peasy walk. A brochure that I picked up at the airport suggested 6hours for the walk. Was quite excited that I could getaway from the hustle and bustle of Hong Kong for few hours. However, my husband and I finished it in 2 hours and spent about half an hour at big wave beach. It was chilly and windy. So couldn't enjoy the beach wither. However, I strongly recommend the hike as it is impressive for a city like Hong Kong. Great views during the initial few km. Take a bottle of water and a snickers and everyone would be able to do this.

Must do for outdoorsy types!. Went today, great afternoon walking and enjoying the sights. Awesome to get out away from all the mania and overcrowding in the city too!Took the MTR from Central- take the blue line to Shau Kei Wan, then at the end of the line, take the number 9 bus from bus terminal. Very straight forward!Dragon's Back was quick for me to get to but it was quite steep. I then spent the rest of the afternoon wandering the footpaths and ended up at Big Wave Bay.Very nice there too.Walk up from the beach and you will get to the main car park where the number 9 bus will stop and take you back to the MTR.Thee are some toilets dotted about too but they're proper Chinese style and not too clean when I went!Enjoy!

Best hike in Hong Kong . If you enjoy hiking this is an absolute must. Totally worth it for the trek for the breathtaking views and scenery. If you go during the warm months you can cool off at Clearwater beach after before busing home

Nice way to see the Island. A nice way to spend a few hours hiking away from the hustle and bustle of Hong Kong. Was easy to get to - MTR to Shau Kei Wan then the number 9 bus from outside the station. It is useful to get an Octopus card, even if you're only in Hong Kong a few days. Then you don't have to worry about the right change and you get a refund for the card when you leave. The walk has great views of the Island and access to the beach. The day I went we didn't go down to the beach as it was cold and overcast. However it didn't hinder the experience and it's definitely something you should do in HK.

If you didn't know, you wouldn't know. A view and experience of Hong Kong Island's natual beauty. No hustle. No bustle. The hike is a little strenuous at the beginning. After that, it's an easy walk with wonderful views of a bay on one side of the hill and the South China Sea on the other. Easy bus transit to the trailhead and back. If you're lucky you'll get one of the 16 passenger buses. That ride is an experience all by itself.

Must do. A great walk well worth doing. Get the MTR to Shau Kei Wan, then get bus #9 from the terminus outside the station to the start of the walk. If you don't have an Octopus card, the cost of the bus is HK$7 - be sure to have the correct fare as no change is given. Almost everyone will get off the bus at the same time, so don't fret about not knowing where to get off. Bring plenty of water and wear good hiking shoes.

Should be first stop!. Easy access from TST via MTR and city bus. I visited on a Sunday early morning and was perfect! If visiting on a weekend get an early start to avoid getting stuck behind slow walkers and families. I've been to HK 5 times now and in my opinion this is something that should not be missed on any trip here! It is really a shame that more people who come here din't venture out and experience the natural beauty of the island.

Great break from the busy streets. Dragon's Back is a great way to get out of the city and enjoy a bit of nature with some great views. It is an easy trail to walk and can be done within a 2-3 hours depending on traffic both there and back and on the trail :)
One of our favorite hikes in Hong Kong. This is a classic favorite. The views are amazing. Not too difficult of a hike. Fun to grab thai food in Shek O afterwards.
Nice walk, nice view. It is way to discover another side of HK island. You can see the beautiful sunrise and sunset on the peak of Dragon's Back.
A must do if you like to walk. We did over 100 miles of hiking while we stayed in HK and this was the best combination of views, friendly fellow hikers, and wildlife out of all our treks.

Best thing in Hong Kong. Wow. Well worth the effort, a great part of Hong Kong I had never been to before. Took my two kids 8 & 12 who did it easy, and were equally impressed by the scenery ... helped by a glorious blue sky day and cool weather (ideal hiking weather). Some of the streams were still flowing, but the track was dry and easy to follow.

Scenic Views and a Great Hike Near the City. The hike was a great break from the bustle of the city. Going all the way out to Big Wave Bay and its beach definitely lengthens the hike, but is worth doing if you have the time, as you get to see a nice surfing village with a couple tiny restaurants where you can grab a snack. It was a bit tough to navigate, but very rewarding. It's easy to travel by MTR and bus, and there's a 10 HKD shuttle from Big Wave Bay to Shau Kei Wan MTR station, so you don't have to worry about returning if you continue the hike. I would recommend bringing snacks along if you want to rest at the multiple picnic stations when you get down from Dragon's Back Peak.
Easy hike w great views. I've done this hike a few times now and the views are so beautiful. Also like ending up on the beach for a meal or drink.
Awesome view. Awesome view. Worth going for a trek. Feels like heavenly view. Good place to retire and relax and unwind.

Fantastic exercise. Having sat on a plane for many hours, it is fantastic to do this easy hike and see a beautiful part of the Hong kong landscape! Easy to reach by train and bus. The path a bit slippery, bring good walking shoes.

A great way to get out and about in HK way from the skyscrapers.. MTR to Shau Kei Wan, then a taxi to the start of the walk. Walked up the path to the top of the ridge and then along, accompanied by great views over the Shek O peninsula and across to Tai Tam and Stanley. At the north end of the ridge descended into Big Wave Bay before getting a taxi to Skek O and a bowl of noodles at the noodle shop next to the Tin Hau Temple. Then a bus or taxi to Stanley for some shopping.

Fantastic hike and breath-taking views!. I hiked the Dragon's Back trail with some friends at the beginning of October and I honestly think it was the perfect time to trek as the weather was windy but still warm!The trek is very simple and does not require any type of expertise, the views are amazing and breath-taking, especially on a sunny day, and the trail ends at Big Wave Bay, which is a fantastic beach!Definitely recommended!

Get set Go!. Most of the people who visit Hong Kong generally do not have this in their itinerary. Mostly because they either come for shopping in HK and / or visit the usual places like Disney Lang and Ocean Park. There have been some of my friends who have visited HK couple of times and still ask me "is this in HK?" However, you really need to do some homework before visiting this place like, charting the transport plan (if not travelling by taxi/car, the time to visit and atleast 1 litre of water per person. Please bear in mind that you need to be in decent fitness for this as this is almost 5 kms of trek. From my opinion, the best time to start the trek is at 3:30 PM (if you are in HK island and travelling by MRT, it will take atleast 40 mins to reach here, check different sites for exact direction). You can start the trek from a small Bus Stop (be careful to watch this bus stop if travelling by bus, as it is very easy to miss out). At 3:30PM, you are shielded by the dense foliage till you reach the top. At the top you are greeted by awesome views on both side of the bays. At top the trek is flat and long, since you walk along the mountain ridge with gradual inclination, hence the name Dragon's back. On the way down, if you are just after the monsoon or rainy season, you will be greeted by rushing small waterfalls. It is quite refreshing to splash water on you. I was advised NOT to drink the water, hence be careful not to give in the temptation. Towards the end of the trek, the path has sharp stones becomes heavily enveloped by foliage cutting off much of the sunlight. Hence, make sure you are wearing good athletic shoes and have a small torch just in case you are delayed and are still trekking down by 6:30 PM as it gets quite dark due to the dense foliage. You end the trek by entering a small community next to the beach. There are couple of restaurants opened till I think 7:30 PM and you can have water / soft drinks and even it of the meal. The Beach itself is more of a creek and hence has good sand. This is quite welcome after a hard 2 - 3 hours of trekking.If you are adrenalin junkie, this is quite an experience on a Dragon's back.
good exercise with excellent views. easy to get there via public transport.. most of the path is shaded by trees.. end of the trail gets you to the big wave beach..

Get out of the beaten track. Amazing attraction, beautiful views, easy walk of 5.5 km (ish).This is 5 stars urban track, easy to reach by train/bus combination. You start with a relatively steep walk on a narrow rocky track with some steps and then a couple of up and down hills with stunning ocean views. Must do in HK..

Great hike. This is a great hike offering tourists a fantastic opportunity to see the other side of HK. Going to the start point is easy - just head to Shau Kei Wan bus terminal (either via MTR or bus), and take bus no. 9 at the bus terminal (a double decker bus). Just tell the bus driver you are heading to To Tei Wan or just watch out for the location indicator flashed in the bus, once you alight, the track is just directly in front of the bus stop. To head back to Shau Kei Wan, just take the bus on the opposite side (else, if you want to explore the beach and its surrounding area (good laidback option), just continue in the same direction of the bus journey from SKW to the bus terminus).Went there in Dec and the weather was cool, dry and perfect. Weather can get pretty cold on some stretches, but the view makes it worthwhile.

Great Hike. One of the more scenic hiking routes in HK away from the bustling city. The route is fairly easy so everyone can enjoy the hike at their own pace. You will be able to see the many different parts of HK island at the tip. No (clean) toilets available around so make sure to relieve yourself before coming. Also, you will sweat so be sure to wear proper attire & clothing.
Best hike in Hong Kong. Favourite hike in Hong Kong.Make sure you catch the bus or a taxi down to shek o beach afterwards for lunch and a swim.

Awesome Hike. We started this at Section 8 and our taxi driver had no idea where this was. I had a good map so we found it. This is an awesome hike with spectacular views of Hong Kong. We ended in Big Wave Bay and took a bus back to our hotel. The trail is very well marked.
Great views. Nice hike great views, leisurely couple of hours. Bus stop available at the start and end of hike so easily accessible.

Worth your time. This was on my list of things to do in Hong Kong while on holidays from Australia. I was not disappointed.Caught the MTR to Shau Kei Wan from TST (13.9HKD) and then bus #9 towards Shek-O, to To Tei Wan on Shek O Road (6.9 HKD) and set off to walk Stage 8.It was a little drizzly and windy on the day but I didn't notice this until I was well and truly walking the trails on the top of the hills.It is a great walk, I found it mildly tough at the start because it was all up and down steps and trails to start, just a little slippery with the weather and my age. However all said and done it is a wonderful, worthwhile walk. I started at about 8:30 and did not encounter anyone until the end (about 10:30) when the weather had fined up.It offers great views and a wonderful sense of Hong Kong's natural bushland interspersed with views of Stanley and other urban enclaves. I was a little started at one point when I heard the grunt of a feral pig close to the track, but hey, this gave me something to talk about!I would do this again!

The perfect intro hike. This is a perfect hike if you're just visiting HK and likewise if you have people to visit. It's fairly short and well paved and has awesome views over both sides of HK Island. On a hot day, you can walk over to Shek O or Big Wave Bay for a swim then get the bus back.

Best urban hike in Asia. Allegedly the best urban hike in Asia. Water off both sides of part of the trail. Moderately difficult -- some parts are steep, but mostly flat. The front third of the trail is kind of open and therefore HOT. Suggest a) do the trail backwards to the guidebooks; b) go early to beat the slower walkers that show up around 10am; c) take cab after hike into Shek'O and have the veggie pasta at the pizza place. Yummy!

Amazing view, priceless value. Most people know of Hk as a place to pig out and shop. But Hk offers a beautiful and gorgeous view of mountains too! Enjoy a hike (albeit long one) at dragon's back. Check out Shek o beach while you are there too. Pretty! Gives you a different memory of Hk. Enjoy!
An easy trail. The most easy and famous trail in Hong Kong bringing you to Shek'O.The trail needs 2 hours, Not accessible for strollers.

Dragon's Nature Trail. The Dragon's Back is a day of nature tripping experience in the southeastern border of central Island, beginning with a steep ascend from the Shek O' road about 200 meters to the top, then hike towards Shek O Peak where you see the spectacular view of the island below, followed by an easy trek on a mountain trail - while enjoying beautiful scenery - for more than 2 hours that ends at Big Wave Bay Beach in time for lunch, cold bottles of beer, or take a dip into the warm sea water. Highly recommended family outing, go to Shau Kei Wan MTR station and took bus 9 from therefor half an hour ride to Shek O road. Try to go on weekdays or early on weekends to avoid the crowd and noisy tourists from the mainland.

Hard work, but worth it at the top. walk through the cemetery quite boring, but very hard work to get to the top, walking through camelia forests with little view. Climb upto the top very hard with lots of steps, but worth it. Fantastic. Climb down steep.

Don't miss it!. It's a really nice hike but quite a lot of climbing at the beginning. Very many buses run through the Shek O road up and backwards. An alternative to take bus 9 to the MTR stop is taking bus 16 or taking a taxi to Stanley. From there you can catch a bus to one of the beaches at the south side of HK Island or to Aberdeen for instance.

Beautiful hiking in Hong Kong. This is a very nice trail and realitively easy compared to other hikes in Hong Kong. It took about 2.5 hours from the start of the trail on Shek O road to Big Wave Bay. Took a cab to the beginning of the trail and the bus / MTR back into Central.
Nice nature, easy walking and nice wiew. Nature is amazing....and hiking there is relatively easy....and nice to go up first and down to the beach later.

a awesome hike with a rewarding end. The start of the hike can be a bit hard to find if you don't know what you are doing. We entered through a no long maintained trail by accident... once on the real trail it was love. We enjoy a great and long hike to a beach. Good food and beer on the beach made for a great day.
A great walk. If you do not know Hong Kong you may be surpised to find such hiking opportunities on the island. Off you go!
Easy hike with great views. Nice easy HK hike for the whole family, Try to go on a weekday or early on a weekend since it can get busy with very noisy people.

Perfect Escape from the City. Great walking trail, very close to the city. The sign says 2 hours and 45 minutes, but I ran it in under an hour. The first section is a little steep but the rest is very easy. The view is incredible and the trail ends at Big Wave Bay Beach, perfect for grabbing lunch or walking around the beach. Definitely will be back!

Hiking at dragon's back. Strongly recommended by Times Magazine, it is THE hike you have to conquer in Hong Kong - Dragon's Back Hike. Despite the cold rain, this hike had too many good reviews to give it a miss! I dragged myself out of my super comfortable sofa (I was watching Step Up 3D) and pulled myself out of the house. Being at home is so comfortable. When was the last time I lazed at home during the weekends? (not complaining. I love going out). Met my friends (and new people) at Shau Kei Wan MTR and took bus 9 from there. I love it when we meet on Hong Kong Island instead of going to the Kowloon side or New Territories ;) We took the bus up the hill and stopped somewhere (I really don't know where. Our AWESOME guide kind of knew where to stop. It takes faith to trust him⚇ ).one of the best hikes that ended with a chill by the beach. great day! read more here: http://www.trevellers.com/2013/11/20/dragons-back-hike/

Zen in the middle of the city. Just a short bus or car ride away from the hustle and bustle of HK. We only went to HK for 2 days and knew this was something we could not miss. You will need to carve out a good portion of your day to allow for this activity. Depending on your starting point, the hike can take 2-3 hours alone. Hike up to Shrek O Peak, a viewing/rest stop with the most incredible views of the islands below. Would love to come back in the Spring/Summer and take a dip in Big Wave Bay. Definitely a must do and some great opportunity to stretch your legs after being cooped up on airplanes.

Great View of Hong Kong Countryside. Just half an hour bus ride from the Shaukiwan MTR Station and you can watch the most beautiful scenery in the eastern part of Hong Kong Island. The hiking trip is not difficult and most of the trip is level ground once you are uphill just above 200 metres. The view from the top is most spectacular in summer afternoon although it may be hot. Meals are available when you are down hill through many long steps at the Big Wave Bay wih a magnificient beach.

Nice views and breezy walk. The start of the walk is the most tiring, but the rest is really pleasant and easy. Arriving at Shek O you can either take a swim, eat at the good Thai restaurant, or take the minibus back to Shau Kei Wan. Getting to the start point is probably the hardest part of the day, so best is to get there by taxi!

A good walk. Decent hike over the top of the island, well marked out from the bus stop, we got off the number 9 and then walked towards the beach, three easy hours, clear day so views around the south of the island were amazing. Other reviews are spot on concerning the ease of access, the quality of the scenery and the chance of a swim or a beer at the beach at the end.

Great walk. We went on a weekday afternoon while the weather was unpredictable. The place was quite deserted, and we only met a few fellow hikers along the way. However despite the intermittent drizzling, strong wind and often muddy tracks, we made it to Shek O Peak. We couldn't see any scenery because of the fog, so made our way back to the main road. Verdict: it's worth the time and no words can describe the fun we had.
A must go if you like hiking. It is so convenience that you can take public transports to get there. The scene is magnificent and is welcome by many locals for rest day activities

Great views, in easy reach of the city.. My friend and I took the MTR blue line from Central to Shau Kei Wan from where we took the number 9 bus. After a short ride we reached the start of the steps up to the Dragon's Back. I am 55 years old with a bad knee following an unsucessful cartilage operation. I'm also pretty unfit. Sensible shoes are a must, there are countless steps and the occasional tricky rocky slopes but, as I say, although not in peak condition, I was fine. We stopped several times to allow me to catch my breath and to take pics. After the rocky climb and dreaded subsequent knee-aching descent, there was a relatively flat 30 minute stroll through shaded woods before we turned right to walk to the Big Wave Beach, in Shek O. This started as an easy stroll along a road before turning down a rocky descent, with some more of the dreaded steps. (My knee only took a couple of days to recover). It took us just under two and a half hours to complete the walk from the bus stop to the beach, where we stopped at the westernised Eric's Kitchen for a welcome snack. The mini-buses from here back to the MTR station run every 15 minutes and cost $10. This was an easy, inexpensive, healthy and beautiful half day adventure, away from the bustle of the city. Amazing views and a welcome breeze at the top.

Step It Up. Great views and a nice respite from the big city bustle. There are A LOT of steps, especially if you go straight after the small park on the descent and take the second right toward Big Wave Bay. We did this on the recommendation of a local who was in the park, and after a winding flat trek along a narrow paved trail, we emerged from the trees to stunning coastal views. Probably not for folks with bad knees but otherwise a moderate 2+ hour hike.

Beautiful views. I did this hike recently with friends. I didn't think it was particularly difficult. We did have a false start getting there by bus and getting off too soon. We waited for the next bus and got off at the next stop. We took water with us and some snacks. The hike took us 2-3 hours. The views are amazing. There were plenty of rest stops along the way for enjoying the views. I can't believe it has taken me 35 years to get around to doing this hike. I have heard so much about it. Not to be missed!

Fantastic walk!. Really great view and very enjoyable - there are a lot of steps so not for bad knees but otherwise great. Do not go - as we did - around midday over the summer, gets very hot! Also beware of spiders - stick to the path and watch out - apparently September is particularly bad and we saw some monsters!

Nice hike close to downtown. The hike was quite a bit shorter then I was told. It only took me about 2 hours instead of the 4-5 hours I anticipated. I love hiking, so it was a bit short, but the scenery is very nice.I walked quite a bit faster then anyone else though. As a single walker and not taking pictures every turn.It wasn't to busy on a week day, but there are some "louder" groups every once and a while.But it just passed them quickly and as soon as I went around a corner, I had the trail for my self again.The first part has quite some incline to the top of the dragon's back. Lot's of steps. But after that it is mostly downhill and you can cruise it down to the beach. The beach was nice, get in the water and feel far away from the hustle & bustle from the cramped city.Thoroughly enjoyed my self. Recommend the trail to anyone except the very unfit.Tips: Bring food/drinks and correct clothing/shoes. Weather can always change rapidly and expose you to the elements. Even on a "Sunny" day bring a jacket for protection.

Fun Hike. Had great fun with Martin from Walk Hong Kong doing the Dragon's Back Hike on 31st October. It gave a totally different perspective of Hong Kong and certainly helped highlight the lovely geography and scenery of the island and its surrounds.

Beautiful HK scenery. This only took about 2-3 hours gentle hiking for 2 people of average fitness, but the views are spectacular. You have the ocean on one side and Stanley harbour on the other. Just beautiful and well worth the hike!

Amazing hike!. Great view from the top, good workout for the legs. Wear trainers!
Can't wait to do this hike again. Chill out at Shek O beach after the hike.

Moderate hike. Started from To Tei Wan, took abt 1.5hrs to reach the highest peak. There are a few peaks, some moderately steep with rocky terrain, so its best to wear durable shoes. Good view of the island/sea with cool winds throughout.At the downhill section, I took a wrong turn (sign said shek-o road), and trekked the backside of the dragon back, back to To Tei Wan instead of ending at the beach.It was a easier trek back, mostly straight path, with denser vegetation. I took 1hr to arrive back at the start point and took a bus back to the mtr station.
Great mini hike!. Some lovely views and scenery. Make sure you take your camera. Public transport easy to navigate to trail head.

Cool little hike. We had a great time on this hike. Not very intense but a great way to get ones heart pumping and see the sights of Hong Kong Island. Just be sure that you don't expect much once you reach the end at Big Wave bay... It is a pretty touristy beach with nothing to offer, also make sure that to get a taxi one needs to walk up the hill to a large parking lot

One of the best hikes in HK. Dragon's back is an easy, scenic hike. It's hard to get to the start but there are sufficient directions online to understand where it starts. Take it from the penitentiary going to Shek O road, so you can then catch a bus into Shek O beck for lunch.The trail itself is not too demanding. I have seen people wearing sandals on the trail, however do wear sports shoes to fully enjoy this. The trail starts in the woods, but then opens up, following the crest of the mountain (hence the Dragon's Back). On a clear day the view is truly spectacular over the water.Distance 5km.start: right after Cape Collinson Road, at the Lai Chi Rehabilitation Centerend: Shek O road,take a bus to Shek Otime: anywhere from 45 minutes running/fast pace, to 1+ hourselevation gain 178 metersIf you do this hike in the morning, you can get to Shek O beach in time to eat Thai food at one of the establishments at the start of the village, and then rent a sun umbrella and deck chairs to relax.

Excellent distraction away from the city. Getting there was easy. Instructions can be found online. #9 bus has a scroll text display showing next stops, also in English, so just watch the display to know where to get off. The hike itself was not difficult though if you are thoroughly unfit, it might be a bit of a struggle but I assure you, you will get there even if it takes a little longer. Carry a backpack with bottled water. Leave your hands free in case you need them to help you along the steeper slopes. Thankfully there were clear skies that morning I was there so the view was really good at the top. Small nuggets of info: Before boarding #9, I saw a traditional market just across the road. This was my third trip to HK but I have never been to a traditional market. It was small but it had most things one would need for a home cooked meal. I bought oranges from a vendor, 3 of 4 were quite sweet and juicy. By chance, while waiting for the bus back, I decided to take a look around and spotted one of Hong Kong's well-known cemeteries with very neat rows and rows of tombstones. Moving.

A patch of green in a concrete city. Took a bus in the city to the starting point, within just 30 minutes we started the hike. It's quite steep at the beginning, and lots of steps. However, it's worth the walk and energy when you're up on the ridge, where you could see the Shek O beach and the beautiful landsccape.

A great hike with unparalleled scenes. You can either hike half of it (2-3 hours) or the full trail (4-5 hours). It is not a too difficult trail so it's suitable for most people. You will see fantastic sea views as well as mountain/forecast views. It's really nice to have such a place in Hong Kong. Strong recommendation!

Nice fly & paragliding @ Dragon Back. Dragon back is the most beautiful and longest hiking path I've walked and had my tandem paragliding flight there with my pilot! Beautiful sea view with long walking path on mountain! People like to do paragliding there too! I saw many paragliders to fly on top of the mountain! I had my experience flying there once! Very very exciting! I have joined the tandem paragliding service from X-Fly Hong Kong Paragliding Club. If you guys want to see the view in Dragon Back in a different way, it's highly recommend to try on flying there to look at the sea and view from the sky in different view! Haha! Very very nice! After landing the flight, you could walk the path down to catch the bus to go to Shek O for dinner or go back to town for something nice to eat!More information for flying experience, please see www.x-flyhongkong.com and people can do booking with the pilot there!

Well worth the trip out .. It took us just over two hours to complete the walk. The section over the dragons back gave some very good views. On the walk you will be confronted with three path choices.. In each case take the right hand path if you want to head down to the beach. Once you make it to Big Wave Bay there are some decent toilets there. Also look out for the shuttle minibus that leaves from the car park on the way out. It costs an extra 100 each but will take you straight to the MTR. If you prefer to catch the no 9 back, you don't have to walk all the way to Shek O. The bus stop is on the road about 15 minutes walk and is about 50 yards along on the right hand fork .

A great hike with a fantastic view. To get on the dragons back is a bit of a steep climb but then it is a moderate hike following the undulating path. At the summit, there fantastic views of the bay and a lovely breeze. I highly recommend this nature walk.

3 hour hike with great views. This hike takes about 3 hours. You start in Tai Tam and then make your way to Big Wave Bay. There are ups and downs, but nothing technical. The views from this hike are phenomenal. You can see down to Sheko beach and also Stanley beach.

A very different view of hong Kong. A group of us (4 to be exact), decided to find out a different Hong Kong, so we decided to go trekking. We started off at the To Tei Wan Bus Stop (no.9) and began our ascend. Along the way, the tracks were all well marked and no problems with walking. There were also sign posts to show you where to proceed. Weather was fine and highly recommend to go in Late october or November where the weather will be much cooler. Once we were at the top and started our descend, came the wrong decision. After you follow the route and descend, you will come to T-Junction. If you turn left, you go to Shek-O, if you turn right, you will head to Tai Tam Gap. Please remember to take the Tai Tam Gap. The Shek-O route, which we took, willl bring you back to To Tei Wan starting point. However, the main problem was that the Shek-O route I believe is less travelled, so the vegetation can be quite dense at certain parts. It was a good 2 hours walk which did help us burn off some fat from all the eating we did.Note: Please bring plenty of water as there are no shops to burn anything nearby.
A good walk. We did the walk when the weather was just turning to cooler after the summer heat, but it was still hard work. A great holiday workout!

A must hike (if you have the time). I was tipped off by a friend about doing this hike when I was planning my trip, so I was pretty eager in trying it out. I didn't really plan all that much in going (and not expecting much), so in my last day at HK, I decided to take some time off by myself and decided to hike up Dragon's Back - it did not disappoint!To get there, I would suggest taking the MTR to Shau Kei Wan Station => Exit A3 => take bus 9 from Shau Kei Wan bus terminus to To Tei Wan on Shek O Road. Once there, you just follow the path to Dragon's Back. From there, you can take the path and loop all the way to Big Wave Bay.Unfortunately, there isn't much to do once you get there (if you are not much of a surfer or swimmer like me). From here, you can actually take the bus back to Shau Kei Wan Station. You just need to walk a little down the path down the surfer rentals. If all else, you can ask the locals for directions! This website helped me A LOT:http://www.discoverhongkong.com/eng/see-do/great-outdoors/hikes/dragons-back-hiking-tour.jspTips: 1.) Bring at least 2 water bottles 2.) Get enough sun screen! 3.) Bring boots 4.) Be prepared to hike for about 3 hours 5.) The first half has a couple of rocky trails followed by gradual descent in the middle. The last half has some rocky parts so that's where your boots come in handy. 6.) I met a lot of elderly people with walking sticks, so if you have bad knees, bring those!All in all, a great place to go to when you want some time alone from busy HK Island. The bus ride up and down Shek O is enough for the trip to Dragon's Back!

So easy to escape to for some time out.. Wonderful contrast to the city frenzy. So quick and easy to get to on the bus and then just forget about the traffic and the bustle as you climb up and into the hills. Surprisingly lush, green and fresh with lots of sea glimpses followed by beautiful panoramas - beach and city harbours nestled together. The path is steep in parts however easily walkable being well laid out and easy to follow - only one place where we needed to decide whether a right or left turn was needed to complete our planned route to Big Wave Bay beach. Recommend early start in the warmer months before it gets too hot. Although there were some very fit runners who passed us at almost full tilt most people we met were taking in the view nice and easy.Makes a good half day excursion with some time spent at the beach swimming and relaxing afterwards.

The best hiking trail in Hong Kong. Among all the hiking trails I have been to in Hong Kong. Dragon's Back should be most attractive one. You will never get bored since the view is just breathtakingly incredible! Have no doubt that it should be on your bucket list if you want to get away from the hustle!

A must-do, if only to get away from the relentless retail opportunities. Visited on a Sunday so quite crowded. For the first time managed to find the start of the walk without getting lost or thrashing through bramble! "From MTR Shau Kei Wan Station, Exit A3, take bus 9 from Shau Kei Wan bus terminus to To Tei Wan on Shek O Road. The entrance to the hike is on Shek O Road near To Tei Wan village." (By the way, a big shout out to the HKTA who are BRILLIANT.... Those were their directions!) Double decker bus so not too queasy a journey. This time, after the ridge, we went toward Tai Tam Gap then down to Big Wave Bay where a shuttle bus (HKD10 cash, no Octopus card) took us back to the MTR station. Please note that the walk does not get any easier on the way down. There are a few stone steps but many many tree roots and uneven slopes. You need to be vigilant, especially when you are tired or you can easily hurt yourself. If you have a choice, try and do this on a week day and wear swimmers under your clothes so you can chill at Big Wave Bay at the end. Very very crowded at the weekends.....

Amazing View, Amazing Hike. In the hike leaflet on Hong Kong tourism board website, Dragon's Back is promoted as The Best Urban Hike in Asia. I never tried other urban hikes in Asia, so I can't compare Dragon's Back with them. Nevertheless, Dragon's Back is amazing.I suggest to start from the point on Shek O Road. Because from this starting point, you will reach the hill top after 1.5 hour of hiking, and enjoy the fantastic view of bays, sands, sea, mountains and eagles hovering above. The view is breathtakingly stunning. And you can clearly see the hike trails on mountains behind and in front of you.We hiked on a weekday, so we only met a handful of hikers during the 5 hours of hiking. Carry litres of water with you because there's no fresh water refill along the way.

Beautifully calm. We walked the trail on a Sunday and it while it was hardgoing in places (if you, like me, are not fit), the views are definitely worth it. The shaded areas are cooler (welcome) with little waterfalls dotted about. Rewarded ourselves by going for a dip at Stanley Beach afterwards. A must-do, to get away from the hustle and bustle, but I would avoid if strenuous exercise is not your thing!

Very enjoyable. Whilst visiting family for a couple of weeks, my Uncle who lives in HK took me on this walk it is great taking you over the ridges and dropping down into a little village where we had noodles and a bottle of beer it was a great day out. Make sure you wear appropriate footwear as some of the terrain is uneven. There was a French couple wearing high heels :-) and struggling no surprise. A must do if your in HK for a period of time.

Must Hike if you are outdoor person in HK. Initially saw the booking button here, and thinking if I should join a tour as I have done it before. Then found the price being way too expensive giving how convenient to get around in HK and don't feel like needing a tour guide. I found all the information I needed throughout HK Tourism Board (http://www.discoverhongkong.com/us/see-do/great-outdoors/hikes/dragons-back-hiking-tour.jsp), and able to finish the hike without a hassle. Def worth trying giving the view, not a easy city hike, but def a easy outdoor hiking, all the signs are very clear and easy to find. Pretty much everyone you met during the trail speak English, won't get lost for sure.

Beautiful views, stars at night, and quite long. Despite what everyone else says here, the hike is actually quite long and can last for as much as 5 hours. It's easily accessible by public transport and has quite a few entry points. We were so engrossed in enjoying the views and the sunset that it soon got dark and we suddenly found ourselves in the dark with another couple of hours to reach the exit.This is when some of the critters like bats, spiders and snakes came out but they don't get in your way. Overall, we felt like we were far away from Hong Kong and could even see the stars clearly in the night sky. It was a great experience and we wouldn't mind doing it again.
Nice and easy hike. Short hike at Shek O (an hour or so, depending). Really nice views along the way. Try to choose a time for your visit so that you don't come across hordes of other tourists.

Great view!. 50min from Sheung Wan to the starting point (Tei Tau Wan) but it's worth the travelling time. Total of 3 hrs hike (relatively easy) with great views of western hk and of partial hongkong island and lanma island. Ended off at a beach with beautiful waves. Must come!

You have to do it.... I had my hesitations of hiking Dragon's Back, since I received information that it was a 6-hr hike and hiking isn't my very favorite thing to do, but after being here for 1-week now this hike has been the highlight of my trip!!! The hike is easy-moderate, with the toughest parts being at the beginning where you climb the trail to the ridge line, and from there you have spectacular views of the ocean as you continue up--but mostly down--on the mountain ridge. Plus, the surf village at the end is so worth it. I'd recommend exiting bus no. 9 at the highest entrance to the trail since I believe it is more enjoyable that way.

Easy, relaxed, stunning view. this is a short trail that very proper for family and friends to spend the morning to hike, easy to walk but all stunning view you can find, don't miss the beach at the end of the trail at big wave bay, clean water and sand which is very rare in Hong Kong if you don't where to find, can't miss it! tourist's lover! *tip: at big wave beach there is showering and changing area, even you don't feel like swimming at the beach, still can take a shower after hiking if you want.

Fun hike in the middle of the city!. Love hiking in HKG. This is an easy 3 hour hike for anyone. Lots of other trails in that area so feel free to split off and check them out. Ends at the beach so bring your suit if you want a swim afterwards.
Amazing. This place was so spatecular. The steps were not difficult to walk. The atmospherr was so relaxing and comfortable and you can get an amazing view when on top.
Best place for hiking. Good scene, trial not too difficult, good place of hiking for whole family. The trial was not too long from the Shaukeiwan to Shek O.

This is a hike. This is a hike that some might describe as strenuous, but at close to 70 we found energizing. The view on the summits overlook the bays surrounding Hong Kong and you get views into the city. There are no facilities along the way, but at the end it is a short walk to the beach were there are facilities.

Beautiful views. A beautiful hike with a moderate level of difficulty. Lovely views of the bays and water surrounded by mountains. Lots of lovely flowers and different areas of vegetation. It all ends at a lovely beach.

Best hike I've done!. I'm relatively new to hiking/walking but this one was by far the best I've done so far - an easy walk with incredible views and some superb vantage points. I went at sunset which was stunning. If you do go at this time, go prepared with a torch (unlike me!) as the sun goes down quickly and it's much harder to walk in pitch darkness. Definitely worth making the effort to see this. I was surprised how few people knew about it.
Best urban trail. Along big wave bay, nice view from the beginning to the end. The trail is no difficult, good place for family hanging, even babies and pets.

great walk. We missed the start point at the To Tai Wan turnoff and ended up in Sheko on the bus. Not to be defeated we walked back to Big Wave Bay and did the walk in the other direction which I think may be a little easier. There is a steep climb up steps to begin and then you are on your way. We started out at 3.00pm from the Sheko village and I thought we may run out of time but we finished the walk at 5.30pm at the To Tai Wan bus stop, waited 10 minutes and headed back to the MTR. Fabulous views and a great walk. Certainly worth the effort and I would suggest starting at the end is not such a bad thing to do !

It's a gem!. It's got everything right: gorgeous view over the stretch of islands, surfing beach, well-maintained track for both mountain biking and hiking.Close to town and there's public transport to and from the starting/ending points.I had a great time here in my last morning in Hk. On the way you will bump into fellow hikers - majority is local who's really very friendly. Feel free to talk to them or enjoy their Canto songs at the resting areas along the way.Do pack swim suits if you wanna surf or chill at the beach at the end of the track. A bit more crowded here with families and surfers. But the waves are quite strong as the name suggests.My route: Shau Kei Wan MRT - Bus 9 to To Tei Wan Village - Shek O Peak - Big Wave Bay -

Best HK hike. This is the quintessential Hong Kong hike. Everytime I have a friend in town I take them on this hike. It's the best way to see gorgeous views of Big Wave bay and Shek O, and then you end up at the beach! Do it!

The other side of Hong Kong. If you have the impression that Hong Kong is all skyscrapers, overcrowded streets and air pollution, this walk in Shek O Country Park will definitely change your perception. Alongside the many other green spaces in the city, this offers dramatic landscapes, amazing views, fresh air and peaceful escapism – in fact, there was rarely another person in sight in the few hours I spent here.Needs a bit of initiative to find the start of the trail which is hidden away near a bus stop on the road over to Shek O from Shau Kei Wan MTR, but it’s well worth spending a half day here to break away from the hustle and bustle.

A great place for a hike. I am not a regular hiker and this term was particularly challenging but reaching the top was well worth it with amazing views of different sides of HK. It's a refreshing change to the hustle and bustle of the city.

Dragon at typhoon time. I think I was the only one stupid enough to make this track during typhoon. But the feeling is good. Btw is there any one who made this cross country by bike?Don't make my mistake, choose good weather and your hike will be georgeos. I think it's no. 2 must see and go of Hong Kong. Especially for outdoor types.
Good Hike. Great view of the countryside, south China sea, and skyline from the trail. Be sure to take plenty of water, the majority of the hike is in the sun.

pretty easy route to explore the nature. we started hiking from the entrance of dragon's back, the whole hiking journey took abt 2hrs. The view is quite scenic just that the weather is really too hot!! There are some rocky paths along the trail, make sure u wear comfortable shoes :)

Worth a visit. If you have done all the standard touristy attractions in HK then I recommend to do the Dragon's back hiking. It is a nice walk through the mountains with a nice view of both sides of the peninsula which finishes at an organized beach where you can take dive in the ocean, do a bit of surfing and have some food. I did the Hong Kong rail from Skek O' road to Big Wave Bay. It took me around 2.5 hours one way in a really hot day and the first few hundred meters are uphill so I definitely recommend plenty of water (1.5-2 litres), sunglasses, hat and a change of clothes. The hike is not too steep or dangerous of any kind but requires a decent level of fitness and a few stops. I got a taxi from HK island to Shek O' road where the hike starts and costed about 120HK $. As soon as I reached the Big Wave bay I got a public bus back to the MTR (Shau Kei Wan) and costed 12 HK $

A highlight of the trip. My journey to the peak was uneventful and much like other reviewers. However I must be one of the only people to have actually not made it to Big wave bay!! My partner and I reached the peak and experienced the beautiful views along the way. We then took a wrong turn (as we didn't do much research) when we arrived at a T-intersection point in the track shortly after on the way down. I got excited and took the direction of 'shek O' rather than continuing to big wave bay. This took us back to where we started which I suppose is an option if you don't want to do the whole trail. I am definitely going back to complete the whole hike.

hike. great hike with super views of beautiful beaches. We started at the end and hiked up until we got a good view and then went back down, that way it was a shorter adventure. Easy bus stop available

Easy Hike with Stunning Views. We started the hike from the MTR, which wound around the cemetery. Not the fittest of the group I was lagging behind but the actual Hike was a pretty breezy stroll up the mountain. We were greeted by the crisp, fresh breeze and stunning views. The juxtaposition of the apartment blocks and the rolling valley reminded us that we were still in an Urban Jungle. Highly Recommend!

Nice easy walk for the weekend. A nice weekend walk. Start at Cape Collinson Cemetary then it is an easy walk upto the top ridge. From there its a nice walk along the Dragons back, max one hour. You can turn off north and go to Big Wave Bay for lunch ( only a few basic restaurants), or carry on to the end of the ridge and then the trail turns down to the road. Its a boring walk eastwards along the road into Shek O. Better to take the right turn towards Cap D'Aguilar. Where the wall on your left ends look for the trail which will take you into Shek O where you will find a large selection of restaurants and a nice beach

Great view. Very good hike spending about 2 to 2.30 hours starting from "To Tei Wan" to Big Wave Bay. It can be reached by taking mini green bus from MTR Shau Kei Wan. The green bus can be found opposite the bus terminal at MTR Shau Kei Wan exit A3. You can also choose to ride bus #9 at the bus terminal. The destination is Shek O.To take mini green bus, you need to know the exact location to stop at To Tei Wan as you need to alert the driver before the destination. I am first time going there, the bus driver is very helpful. He showed me the landmark and stopped for me the bus stop at To Tei Wan. The bus fare is HKD7 one way.The trail starts right beside the bus stop and you definitely won't miss it. Although the trail is steep incline and decline, it is not difficult to hike. Bring along drinking water to hydrate yourself and light refreshment to fill your hunger as it doesn't have any water replenish station until you reach Big Wave Bay. You have great sea view when you reach the peak.

Easy hike, superb view. Dragon back is one of the most popular local hikes. It is a hike suitable for 2 to 82 with breathtaking views all the way along. The hike takes about 2 hours for average adult. Do prepare yourself with plenty of water and a hat. 80% of the time there is no shade.

Great hike. Great hike, great views, less than 2 hours. I really loved it.
Do it, if you don't you are missing something

Dragon's Back Hike. Easy to find trailhead and pretty well marked trails. Great views from the top. Plan on jumping in Big Wave Bay when you complete the hike. Food/drinks/beach rentals all available.

Perfect Trail for a Start!. Approximately 1.5 - 2.5 hours duration if you keep walking and only stop for 5-10 minutes at each post.Remarkable scenery with great vantage point to HK island. I recommend to start from Southern side and end your trail at Big Wave Bay! Start at 3PM and you will have a perfect finish just before dark, and get ready to queue for a bus!
Amazing hike and views. Just avoid doing it at midday in 32 degrees and 90% humidity - 2 litres of water was simply not enough!!

Hiking the Dragon's Back. Very scenic. Easy to get to and easy to hike. This rides the ridge between Big Wave Bay and Tai Tam bay and provides great views of the South China Sea. Easily done from one end to the other in less than 2 hours. Flag a taxi or a mini bus when you get off at either end and head to Shek-O for Thai food and a dip in the ocean to cool off!

Enjoyable but crowded. This is a pleasant hike with some difficulty but beautiful views. Not nearly as challenging as Wilson trail, but a good way to work up an appetite! It is intertwined with many other trails, so it is easy to get lost. Pay attention to the signs!

Good, easily accessible hike. Take along water!. This hike was recommended to me by a friend who told me to take a taxi to the entry point of section 8 of the Hong Kong Trail. With four persons in the taxi and the meter stopping at HKD 134, that was a good start to the hike.The hike starts off quite steep to the top of the trail and then flattens out before heading down to the end point at Big Wave Bay. All in all 8K, but it took us almost 2.5 hours and we are all quite fit runners. What makes it take time is the pounding sun and the climbing, but it certainly is worth all the effort, because you have a grand view of almost all of the southern coast of Hong Kong island thoughout most of the hike and then, suddenly when you turn a corner, the scene changes and you see the easternmost parts in Chai Wan. At the end of the hike, there's a rewarding beer or ice cream waiting for you in one of the bars at Big Wave Bay. Getting back from Big Wave Bay, we caught another taxi, but we could just as well have hopped onto one of the shuttle buses back to the city.All in all a great hike, but remember to put on sun screen and take along plenty of water. We had about 2l each and I would not recommend less.

Best hike experience in Hong Kong. If you are a hiking enthusiast head over to this place. There are quite a few trails from here ranging from quick ones to long paths but all of them are potentially good and gives you the best sides and the trail I took fortunately were all shaded and saved me from get heat strokes. As part of any hiking preparation, make sure you have all the required supplies with you like comfortable clothes, shoes and lots of water because there are no stopovers where you could get a refill. The only way to do that is by ending your hiking which is where you will find the beach. An amazing result to your strenuous hike

Decent enjoyable Dragon Back hike.. Tried the Dragon Back's trail for first time, using below link information from discovery HK:http://www.discoverhongkong.com/common/images/see-do/great-outdoors/maps/map-03-dragon-back.pdfSome info to share:From Shau Kei Wan MTR Station, Take exit Shau Kei Wan Station Exit A2Walked to Shau Kei Wan Bus Terminus. Took bus No.9 towards Shek O. Bus No.9 stand is probably nearer to the other end of the Terminus. Dropped at Shek O Road near To Tei Wan Village. One can take note of the LED showing the next station on the bus or use smartphone GPS to be sure if required.Top up enough water or food (if required) in Shau Kei Wan before taking No.9.Hiked from near To Tei Wan Village via Shek O Peak to Dragon Back to Big Wave Beach took about 3++ hours. Normal walking pace. Mainly paved trails with clear trail directions along the way. Would say 60-70% of the trail probably is "inside" the forestry while te remaining would be clear views.IMHO, outstanding views of HK sea-line and scenery. The beaches at Big Wave and Shek O were also decent, ok clean, and nice sea scenery.Bring and wear light in the summer with lots of water.From Big Wave beach took no.9 to Shek O bus terminus (a small old bus stop) 5-10 mins journey and take the return trip on same bus number to Shau Kei Wan. Maybe around 30 mins trip for this. Went on a weekday, the bus trips and hike weren't crowded. But very hot July dayGood short hike for sporty visitors who like to sweat. Not as tough as Lantau Trail if any comparison needed. OK for grown ups and teenagers with normal fitness/ health. IMHO.Thanks.

A great hike with great views, many distance options. There are actually many possible hikes in Shek O park, ranging from 40 minutes (up and down Dragon Back) to several hours. Reviewers here may not have all taken the same trail.The trailheads are all serviced by the #9 bus or by minibuses that will take you to places like Big Wave beach. Another option is to go through the cemetery near Chai Wan station. So you can set out from anywhere, to anywhere, and feel confident you can get public transportation out. Bus fares are HKD 7 - 10 each way. Minibus drivers will make change; big bus drivers need the exact (you can round up) fare in coins. There are good signs on the trails in Chinese and English. Toilet facilities are available at trailheads.The #9 bus from Sai Wan Ho is an experience in itself. Try to sit upstairs so you can watch the twisty roads carved through rocks. Popular stops are at Lan Nai Wan (for a short hike to the peak) and Hong Kong Trail sec. 8 (next after Lan Nai Wan, to traverse the ridge). Fare is HKD 6.90 in 2014.The trail is quite easy, though slippery when wet. There are stairs on rises, and it's frequently carved in to the hillside. Trainers/sneakers are fine. I gained the ridge in only 15 minutes at a moderate pace, but I continued all the way along the ridge and over to Big Wave Beach at a fast pace in under 2 hours. The trail is mostly shady, except along the ridge. Views are very good on clear days. Bring lots of water, and avoid the middle of the day! I took along swimming trunks and a towel to cool off at Big Wave.Highly recommended for hikers of all abilities.

A fantastic hike. I'm not the most experienced hiker and I'm not always the most enthusiastic, but I loved this trail. It's relatively easy and the views are stunning from start to finish. We completed it in approximately two hours. I recommend this walk for anybody of any age or fitness. The views are definitely worth the effort. Take plenty of water though! We made that mistake.

Great hike!. Went with three friends in April. Accidentally went on a weekend so the bus ride there took a while as it is also on the way to the beach Big Wave Bay. It was a great hike though with some incredible views. Do your research before on how to get there and how long you'd like to hike but it was a great experience. We did the entire ~8K to the beach and were not disappointed by any of it.
a must see. the view was impressive on the topthere was no map up there,we almost got lostgo there in the early morning or late afternoon to avoid hot weather in the summer

Very tiring for an amateur non-hiker but a good experience nonetheless!. From Shau Kei Wan MTR station, take bus 9 down from the bus terminal. If you're lucky you'll see other hikers on the bus, get off where they get off. Follow the signs after that, there's only one path and rarely when the path splits into two, there will be more signs so that you're never lost. Views are stunning, visit when the weather is cooler and conducive for hiking. I just went in the middle of August/Summer/blazing heat so not a good idea but oh well. Watch out for the terrain, while not exactly mountaineering, there are some parts of the path that I would not bring young children to hike. Try starting from the South and ending off at Big Wave Beach, after a hike as strenuous as that, the beach is a very welcome respite.

Stunning hike, can't be missed. The Dragon's Back is a hidden gem of Hong Kong. It is a relatively easy hike after the initial 30 min uphill walk. Once you get to the top, you can enjoy the remarkable views of Hong Kong's nature.I highly recommend packing your swimmers as the hike ends at Shek O beach. There are a few small local restaurants for a cold beer and a bowl of noodles after the hike as well as shower and bathroom facilities free for the public to use.Peak summer should be avoided unless you go very early in the morning and avoid going on foggy days otherwise you won't see anything. A well worn in pair of trainers with decent grip is good enough for this hike. Plenty of water, sunscreen and mosquito repellent is highly recommended. The whole hike should take around 1hr 30min - 2hr at a casual pace.
Stunning views and great exercise. Loved the views and the elevated paths. The climb is not too bad - in all not too challenging if you like a hike.

Fantastic view from the top! Must-go if you visit HK!. Being adventurous, my boyfriend and I embarked on this trail on the second-last day of our trip. We took the MTR all the way to Chai Wan, and walked the bridge onto Lin Shing Road, and made our way up through the cemetery. You can also reach this place via MTR to Shau Kei Wan, and then taking bus 9. We took the other way and reached here all the same. It was around 12pm when we reached the bottom of the hill. Climbed uphill about 0.5 hr, and we reached the Dragon Back itself at around 1 pm with the blazing sun above us.The view was fantastic, you can see all the surrounding islands and the bays. You have to be there to experience it yourself! Going down, we took bus 9 back to the MTR station.It wasnt a very difficult hike, most of the places are actually shaded from the sun. Do remember to bring along your water bottles to hydrate yourself as it can get kinda hot. Recommended to go there early in the morning, when it is not so warm and hot and you wont get sunburnt. Do wear proper trekking shoes if not you will have blisters from all that walking!

Nice hike. I am not an experienced hiker, but this was very nice. It has some variance, with more rugged terrain at the start and a walk in the woods at the end. I walked through to the shoreline, what was very nice. Looking back and seeing where I started, I felt proud of myself!

Best short Hike. It's not a piece of cake, yet not gonna kill you either. A very pleasant medium difficulty hike close to the city with amazing view. Once you get to the top of the hill, you'll know the 1000 steps are totally worth it.

Something else to do besides shopping. It is easily accessible by public transport. Just take the MTR to the Sau Kei Wan Station and take Bus No. 9 at the bus terminal and alight at To Tei Wan stop. You will be right at the start of the hike. We took about one and a half hours to reach the peak and another two and a half hours to reach Tai Long Beach. After having sone snacks there, we took the mini bus back to Sau Kei Wan Station. The mini bus fare is $2 per person and must be paid by cash.The view at the top is beautiful and refreshing. It is a good change from the usual crowded shopping malls and places of interest. The distance from the peak to Tai Long Beach is longer than the distance from To Tei Wan to the peak. So it is easier to start the hike at ToTei Wan and end at Tai Long Beach.
really great hike. Dragon's Back is a great hike- even when it is hot out since there is a nice breeze for most of the hike. Views are great and the path is easy to follow and not too steep

best trail on HK. This trek can take up to 3 hours and it starts in the old female penitentiary. About 75% of the trails have the shadow from the trees which make it perfect even for hot days. The end of the trek is in the Shek O seafood village where you can enjoy very nice and cheap food. Do not miss out the nice cliff-like rocks at the west part of the village!

Wonderful views. The trail is fairly easy and well kept. The beginning is more strenuous due to the climb uphill but when you get to the highest point it is well worth the we effort! There are wonderful views of Big Wave Bay and Shek O village and beach. I prefer to go during winter when the temperatures are not high but still pleasant and the sky is clearer. There are less people on the trail as well. Make sure to take water and maybe fruit for a little snack when you reach the top. Just don't leave any garbage behind! On the way down you pass by some nice streams and when you get to Shek O you can have a nice drink in the village and a good meal, either at the local fish restaurants or if you prefer western food, The Black Sheep offers very good food! My husband and I had some pizza, but they offer all kinds of dishes. All looked really nice. And the place has a quaint atmosphere as well. The beach in Shek O is very nice and the coast is quite interesting.

Hard work but well worth it!. The Dragon's back is such a welcome break from the manic life in Hong Kong and do it on a clear day and the views will not disappoint. The trek is approx 8km long and took us (novice hikers) around 3 hours to complete at a reasonable walking speed. The first part of the Dragon's back is the hardest up to Shek O peak as it is a hard steep climb with very little shade. We did this trek in 35 degree heat and considerable humidity! So this was all a factor into the speed we could physically walk. The views over the Stanley Peninsula are wonderful and you can see for miles around. Very much worth it!Once over the steep climbs it levels off and is shaded for a good portion to help you recover from the climb.I cannot stress the importance of carrying water and snacks with you - you will be out there for 2-3 hours and there are no refreshments available until the very end. Go prepared else you run the serious risk of heatstroke especially with it being so exposed. We carried over 3L of water and drank it all! There are toilets at the beginning and middle of the trail and helpful markers point out how far you have come. Ending up at Big Wave Bay was a bonus - recommend carrying beach gear with you as relaxing there with an ice cream following your achievement is worth it! I would also recommend a change of clothes - you will be soaked by the end of the trek and there are showers on the beach so a change of clothes is welcomed! Go out and do it, the more prepared you are the more you will enjoy it! Do not be put off, we managed it and if we can, anyone can!!
