Wonderful hike. You need good shoes but not hiking boots. A lot of sun and very hot along the ridge. Takes about 3 hours total but that depends on how often you stop. We took a lot of pictures. Got their on the #9 bus for about 1 dollar US and same for return. Hard part of walk was in the beginning up the steep hill to the beginning of the trail. Then trail goes up but easily. Now you come to a couple of harder area but man made steps. At this point you are high so breathing is a little harder. No where to get water so bring plenty with you. Enjoy the view and take your time. Remember a sweat rag and camera and enjoy the journey. Going down the other side is a lot of steps and easy. A beer station at the top would have been great but this is BYOB.

Compulsory break from the city madness. This should be high on the list for any visitor to Hong Kong - and the more people who do it, the more likely it'll remain a pristine wilderness! Easy to get to the starting point by bus or taxi and then a nice few hours of well-marked trails and delightful views all the way to Big Wave Bay for a swim (reasonable waves though the water is a little murky - may be that the coliform count was high when I was there?) Good food options at Big Wave Bay. Overall, a fantastic & accessible walk and entirely unexpected if you have the usual understanding of Hong Kong as a real-life version of Blade Runner.

Great Breath. Easy access by public bus, the trail is so good for halfday hike, besides, you got an awesome view of the peninsula and a good beach at the end of the trail. Just remember to bring snacks drinks and clothes cause you'll sweat a lot

Refreshing hike with the locals, and wait for reward once you completed the hike...it is AWESOMEE!. If you are looking for a reward of like no other, then this is the place to go. Plan for a morning hike to the Dragon's back and you will be just in time for a relaxing time at the surf beach down at the foot hill of the Dragon!Best Hike for tourist Best Surf Beach (Big Dave Wave Bay)You can cross-checked these two off your list!

A good hike. I did the recommended Dragon's Back hike from the Hong Kong tourism web site which started from To Tei Wan and ended at Big Wave Bay. The hike in total was about 8KM and was vertical with steps for about the first 2 kilometers and then leveled out after the Dragon's Back section.The best part of this hike was the Dragon's Back section which had great views of Stanley Peninsula, Shek O and the rest of Hong Kong island. If I were to do it again, I would finish the hike after the Dragon's Back section or bring my swimsuit and swim in Big Wave Bay and Shek O after the hike. Shek O also looked interesting, but I didn't stick around this time.

Another choice other than shopping. If you like hiking and want to explore the backyard of Hong Kong this is a good place to go. The trail is not difficult and I'll give it a rating of 6 out of 10. Besides, public transportation is so convenient in Hong Kong so it is very easy to get there.

Great views, a nice getaway from the bustle of HK. We walked the Dragon's back in January and again in June. The mountain and ocean views are great and it's nice to be away from the crowds. A clear day in January is terrific - take a jacket. A clear day in June is likely to be very warm, so take water and pace yourself on the steps. To get there: MTR to Shau Kei Wan Station, look for Exit A3 and take bus 9 from Shau Kei Wan bus terminus to To Tei Wan on Shekou Road. The bus is easy to find and an electronic sign inside will tell you when you reach the right stop. There's a porto potty at the start of the trail and at the end. Basic, but usable.The full hike is about 4 km if you start at To Tei Wan. This takes you up to and along the ridge and back down to another point on Shekou Road. From there, you can hail a taxi or hike another 2.5 km to the seaside village of Shekou. Just follow the signs. Have a libation in Shekou by the beach or catch a bus or taxi to Stanley, a great place for lunch al fresco.Enjoy.

Great hike. First thanks to reviewer abhidfreak(spelling?) who listed the MTR stop and bus. One note is small bus from Big Wave beach you must use cash, not Octopus card. Bus 9 was great. Asked driver, and he pointed out stop. 3 others got off with me, but we all travelled separately. I had a warm, humid day and was rained on, but will return on a cooler winter day. Some younger men were jogging trail. Enjoy the photos.
Perfectly nice. lots of nicer hikes in hk - MINUS the billions of tourists. shek o offers lots of food options when you're done though :)

Hiker's Diary - not a stroll in the park but good work out. If you are not into hiking, my guess is you will be not reading this. I read many articles on how to get here and it was confusing with various accounts. A below reviewer mentioned that route via the last MTR Chai Wan stop was confusing and the hike up tje 300 steps path up the cemetery requiring much effort. Here s an account of my journey.1, Took MTR to Shau Kei Wan, went to main bus terminal and asked for directions and was directed to a double decker bus no 9, Caught the bus and got assistance from the bus driver whom stopped us at 6 or 7th bus stop at trail head atTo Tei Wan where there is a sign[post to points to trial. Time to hike up 1km uphill was indicated 1 hr and if you are fit you can cut down that time top 35 mins walking without need to rest. Note walking 1 km up requires more time and effort than on flat terrainPast the small bamboo forest and 15 mins up, you start to get good views, If you emjoy flora the camellias and bushes along the way and watch out for butterfliesIt can take less than an hour to get up to Shek O peak where you will be rewarded with a great view of the Shek O Bay & Tai long Wan /beaches and the surroundings (view golf course, condos and a massive bungalows, mountains and blue seas but grey skies.From the Shek O peak, it would a longer walk to 2-3 km to Tai Long Wan so we opted for a shorter hike back via Tai Tam Wan trail to bus stop, passing by a small waterfall (rocky path n be careful on wet days) and reaching the Correction centre at end of trial. Caught the mini bus A (pay cash) which stops opposite the Shau Kei Wan wet market. Visit it if you got the time.Good 2 + hours hike (not stroll) and if you are not a regular hiker, take it easy. Don't forget to bring a litre of water, some chocs/energy booster, wear a cap or carry an umbrella in case it rains or avoid a heat stroke if you are hiking on a hot cloudless day.If youcan DIY you can join a 4 hr tour *HK$500 ?). There were few people on the morning of my hike as it was rainy and I started early at 730am. Be forewarned, there are no toilets up along the way ! How long it takes depends entirely on your as you need not double back but opt out for another trail (shorter one back via Tai Tam Wan). Local hikers could give us more tips

Great walk - A must for everyone. Was a great walk with awesome views and finished off having lunch in the village before the taxi ride back into Hong Kong.If you dont do it you don't know what you have missed out on.Hong Kong Bucketlist item

A must hike when visiting Hong Kong!. Voted the best urban hike in Asia and it truly lives up to the name. The hike is easy to moderate, some steep parts but most is fairly flat. The hiking time is about three to four hours and you can see the most beautiful ocean view of Hong Kong! No wild mammal life, but tons of butterflies and birds. At the end of hike, you can jump into the ocean taking a swim. The beach is white soft sand, the water has perfect temperature.
Nice hiking trail. Very nice view over HK and the trail is not difficult. Great for a weekend hike with friends and you can have lunch in Shek O afterwards.

Outstanding hike. Let me start by saying that based on some blog's we read we started this hike at Cape Collision Cemetery. I would not recommend that. First one is faced with 100's (really, we counted, but lost track gasping for breath). I think the site I originally read said 300 stairs - believe me there were many more than that. Additionally it's not easy to find the trail - just know that you need to keep climbing the steps to the very top in order to find the trail. That being said, we started the hike pretty proud of our step climbing ability. However, we soon found that we had no idea where we were walking. We tried following signs, but invariably took wrong turns. Eventually we got on the right track and saw beautiful views and had great experiences and challenges. At some points the trail was extremely rocky and narrow, crossing tiny little creeks. Most of the time we were not sure how we would ever find and end point with any sort of transportation. We did what most people along the way did - asked people who were walking from the direction we were going and usually got pointed in the right direction. It was a wonderful hike, and we did reach a "correct" end point where the bus was available. Lovely, fun and challenging. Very nice people on the trails - Asian and Caucasian alike - everyone was helpful.

Foggy Hike. When we walked the Dragon's Back Hike it seemed to be the most foggy day of the year or maybe this is ordinary state, I don't know.The walk itself is easy to reach if you rely on the information given by HKTB. Although the weather was very hot and humid the walk was quite comfortable.It is said that there is a wonderful view around but we couldn't certify this this time. Maybe next time.Be aware that on the way you won't find any snacks, drinks, toilets. Only in the village at the end but until then you should have enough with you.All in all the walk took us 3hrs and including bus trip 5hrs.

The views will make you forget your exhaustion.. It is tough, really tough to hike all the way from To Tei Wan Village to Big Wave Bay Beach. Nevertheless, the effort, even with my fear of heights, is well worth it. The climb up the first hour or so can be monotonous & tiring. Butterflies flutter around & trail you. Nearer the Dragon's Back is where the breathtaking views begin. Stay on the path between the bushes although the slopes do not seem steep on both sides. It rained the day before but the sun had dried the ground. Hold on to your cap for the wind is very strong up there. Light snacks may not be sufficient for the whole trail. Having said that, pack as light as possible. I regretted not capturing the views with a video. The views coupled with the sound of wind culminates the whole experience. After Dragon's Back, the hike seemed easier but the views disappear. Just be prepared to wet your shoes as you pass through countless refreshing waterfalls. We were lucky to have met 2 native hikers who guided us through the waterfalls swiftly. Having a trail map also proved handy as the directions are posted with names of roads. Only the last 2 signs gave directions to Big Wave Bay Beach.After Tai Tam Road, the downward hike is on a road surface. After Cape Collinson, the downward hike turns back into a forested area with boulders. You will hit Tai Long Wan Village. That's where Big Wave Bay Beach is located. The beach is as awesome as the peak. We didn't use the restroom there as it seemed disused. Instead, we opted to lunch & use the facilities at one of the eating places there. Meet fellow hikers of different nationalities who trek alone or in groups. Single female hikers are as many male hikers. We took many rest stops along the way as suggested by other reviewers. All in, my 10 & 13 year old boys with my husband & I took a total of 4 hours to complete the trek. Experience of a lifetime for us!

A great hike. Wanted something different on my 7th trip back to Hong Kong and this was recommended by a friend. was a really nice hike with a really nice view at the top. The steps are quite daunting but very satisfying when completed. Would recommend it to anyone who loves the outdoors.

Unbeatable view. One of the 'must do' hikes in Hong Kong. The end of the route brings you over the famous back of the dragon which offers a stunning view to Shek O and the ocean (given the weather is fine). Wear good shoes as it can get rocky at times.

Good views but bit slippery during rain. Its a really nice trek , takes around 2 hours from "to tei wan" to big wave bay...first part of the trek is uphill from "to tei wan" to dragons back and takes about 45 min...its bit tiring so try and cover this early morning before its hot n humid..dragons back it self is flat and doesn't take much time...views are best from here...from here to big wave bay is mostly down hill and it relatively easy but not much scenic...to get there take a MTR to "shau kie wan" and take bus 9 to "to tei wan"...while returning you get a mini bus just from big wave bay itself to "shau kie wan" every 10 mins though it charges bit extra (10 hkd vs 6,9 in public bus) but it saves lot of time as you will have to wait for bus no 9...keep shoes with good grip preferably rubber soles as parts of the trek are rocky and becomes bit slippery during rain...even carrying a light rain coat is recommended dependent on whether...also if you are planning to take a dip in big wave beech please carry some sheets to relax on beech and shorts as its pretty expensive there ...beech is decent nothing like Thailand or Goa but its nice to relax after trek...

Great afternoon out of the city!. This was a nice way to spend a few hours away from the hectic city and get a bit of space and (relatively) fresh air. The tourist website says it takes 6 hours from To Tei Wan to big wave bay but it only took us 3 so can be done nicely in a morning / afternoon. If you're with kids or less mobile and if you decide to picnic on top then of course would take longer of course. The first part up to the top if te dragon's ack is great with lots of nice views. The second part down to big wave bay is mostly in the trees so no great views but still fine. Big wave bay is fine. Not the most attractive town but the beach is nice. We went on a Saturday afternoon so was pretty busy with horrible tannoy announcements but imagine its nicer during the week. Food didn't look good anywhere to be honest so we didn't bother (the water safety/e-coli rating for the bay on the side of the restaurant dulled our appetites a little too!); we just had a beer and watched the surf before heading back to the MTR (there was a public minibus in th car park back to the station which was handy). Remember there are no shops on the walk after the MTR station until you get to big wave bay so bring water and any snacks you might need with you.

Go up through the cemetery and skip Shek O. I walked Dragons Back early one morning in October on my own. It was a great time of year, and I almost had the whole path to myself.I studied the web and decided I would walk the path in the reverse direction for something a bit different. I headed off on the MTR to Chai Wan, the last stop on the line. From there I walked up through the cemetery. It was quite enjoyable at 7am and worth a look. I went straight up through the top of the cemetery and found the staircase taking me up to the start of Dragons Back.It was a beautiful day and although a little Hong Kong hazy, there were still great views to be had. I also walked the next section and although not as picturesque, it was beautiful being out on my own. I only saw 3 people on the next leg. I exited at the main road, hailed a bus and was back poolside by midday drinking mojitos.A great morning out!

The views are worth the effort. All our preparatory reading warned of the need to go prepared for a 'strenuous walk' without any replenishing facilities on the route. We certainly needed the water we carried with us. The day we undertook the walk was during the recent 'Thunderstorm' weather in HK. On the day we went the forecast was for sunshine. It was sunny for the large part of the walk, it was also very humid, probably too hot. However, the effort was worth it, and the need to ease up at times during the walk meant that we took our time and enjoyed the spectacular views. Both of us are retired and in our mid 60s, but still managed the walk which is in parts quite steep. If you have the time and are prepared to move outside of the air-conditioned tour bus, this is an activity that will reward you with the opportunity to see yet another side of the beauty evident on HK Island. We finished our journey at Big Wave Bay with the intentions of a cooling down dip to end the day. That was not necessary as about a mile from the end we were completely soaked by a sudden outburst of 'monsoon' type rain which lasted about 20 mins. It didn't dampen our spirits as we sat in the beach cafe at Deep Water and enjoyed a drink and the scenery. A good day out.

A side of hong kong tourists hardly see. I like how this is more or less an easy trail to take friends or family to. It has a stunning view once you get to the top. and at the end of the hike, you can opt to go to shek-o beach and have lunch at the restaurants near the beach.there are two starting points though. im not sure of the names but you would want your hike to end where shek-o beach will be.

Walking with Dragons. From the beach to the mountains, we took on Hong Kong’s most popular walking trail, Dragon’s Back, one afternoon after seven days of dumplings. It was quite foggy, but we could make out the shape of the mountain (the sleeping dragon).Check out full review and other HK recommendations at http://feastplaylove.me/2014/05/21/10-things-hong-kong-part-2/

One of the best hikes ever!. If you like to hike, and you are going to Hong Kong, DO NOT MISS this hike. The views of both the bay and sea are amazing. It is a little challenging. A couple of out of shape office workers survived, but it took some effort. But would do it again in a heart beat. Be aware of the soil. Its very sandy and after a rain, quite slick. Even though I had hiking shoes on, I fell and had an unpleasant trip down and subsequent flight home the next day. But the views were worth every ounce of pain. Would not attempt this without proper footwear though.

Fabulous hike across a ridge known as dragon's back. Spectacular views out to sea. Bring lots of water if it's hot. Lots of steps and steep path. If you want you can walk all the way to big wave bay. Nice to sit and have a beer after a hike.

Easy walking, great views. Dragons back is a nice easy hike for people of all levels. There are a few steps and ups here and there, but nothing stopping anyone from making the walk. The views from the top - or the dragons back - are sensational. They really give you a different view on Hong Kong, showing up mountains and hills as far as the eye can see. If you plan your hike to finish in Shek-O, then the thai place near the bus stop is great for an easy bite, and of course you can spend the rest of the day on Shek-O beach soaking up the rays.

Great views and easy to access. It is easy to see why this is a top-rated hike. It is not too hard (but expect to sweat a lot) and offers stunning views. Since it ends in Tai Long Wan (signposted as Big Wave Bay along the hike), packing a swimsuit would be a good idea.To the the start by taking the MTR to Shau Kei Wan Station then bus 9 from the bus terminal outside. Get off at Stop #12 To Tei Wan on Shek O Road. (Stop #11 is Lan Nai Wan on Shek O Road.) The trail head is right at the bus stop and is part of the Hong Kong Trail.

Sweat, water and beers!. Loved it! We hiked for three hours with our guide trough the dragons back, the forrest was amazing and the view even more! Be sure you wear good shoes as I got stinged with some animal in my ankle. When you finished (and probably be wet from sweat haha) you can relax at the beach! Buy a beer at the shop with very friendly people and take a dive in the suprisingly cold water! We had a great day!

Wonderful Track. The Track of Dragons back it's really worth to do. You will feel far away from HK when you are just a fews minutes from there.It makes me feel rally good, peace and beautiful spots.The other face of HK.A must to do.
One of our favourites. Fantastic hike- great view and not too streniuous .. finishing your the hike at Deep water bay . Perfect.

Beautiful hike. Dragon's Back is probably one of the most well-known hikes in HK. Beautiful and not too intensive. Best to do this hike on a clear day when it's not too hot, and reward yourself with a nice lunch or dinner and a cold TsingTao afterwards!

The first of the many hikes in Hong Kong. Dragon's back was our introduction to hiking in Hong Kong. And What an introduction it was !On all counts - be it the natural beauty of the trail or the beautiful vistas, it was well worth the effort. We ended up hiking the Tai Tam reservoir trail as well. On a difficulty level, it was medium. What was amazing was the fact that there was no much natural beauty right on Hong Kong Island

Outstanding hike, but use caution. I loved this hike and the views were incredible, but it was not quite as easy as some others have suggested. This may be partly due to the fact that I did the hike in May in the heat and humidity, however there is perhaps more difficult terrain than I had anticipated. This didn't bother me, but perhaps this hike wouldn't be right for younger children. Anyway, I got off bus 9 at the "Cape Collinson" stop and had no trouble finding the start of the trail. The first 60 minutes, however, had heavy vegetation on both sides with very limited (an usually no) views of the surrounding mountains in ocean. After this, however, I continued the hike to Tie Wan which had many beautiful views and ended right at another stop for the #9 bus.

great hiking trail. If a senior can do it, so can you. It is an easy hike on this trail. When I first visited Hong Kong I thought of nothing, but its high density,especially in Tsim Sha Tsui. Now after having been to the Dragon's Back, I am convinced that Hong Kong has its beauty in nature, too. The trees are wild and one can see the beaches, islands and clear waters. Hong Kong is no longer a tiny island, but its suburbs add lengths and breadths to its size.

Amazing View. The hiking trail is easy to go in this crowded city. People wil find it unexpected beautiful with different kind of amazing view. Sea, hill and lots of tress. Of course, hope have the luck to see the blue sky. Then, it will be such a wonder experience!

Excellent Hike in an Urban City. It was very easy though the scorching heat made it a bit challenging. The trail has a mix of wet land, dry slopes and forest shade. The views on top were excellent. Don't forget to bring water with you for there were no shops on the way until the end- the tiny beach with nice little shops. The hike took around 2- 2.5 hours on a regular pace.
very nice walk. easy to access, you get a dose of nature in the middle of the city and the trek is easy to follow. count 3hrs minimum..
Breathtaking Views!. Was incredibly lucky as the day I did this hike HK had the bluest of skies, which is such a rarity. Well worth the hike for those amazing views!

Quiet on Monday, not so easy after Shek O peak but good hike. I took the route given by some HK experts and also detailed in Serious Hiker's Guide to Hong Kong by Pete Spurrier Hong Kong Trail Stage 8 - Tai Long WanI think it covers 10km or so in 3 hours+ today with lunch at Shek O Thai restaurant at the roundabout just a little after the bus terminus. The temperature was around 27% with some sun and humid. I had 1.5L water but only drank about 1L, might need more if the weather is warmer.MTR to Shau Kei Wan and then bus #9 (at the furthest end of terminal), I saw the signal board in the bus show To Tei Wan Village and pressed the bell to drop. You can try telling the driver and he should be able to help you too if you need. I took pictures of the bus stop and the sight of the view opposite the bus top facing Tai Tam Bay. The stairs is on the left after you dropped with toilet facilities (not very clean type). - some said it was stop #12 but I think very hard to keep the count as the bus does not stop at every stop.Make sure you have enough water so there is really NO replenishment till Big Wave Bay. The parts to the peak is up and up, so take it slowly. I went with hiking boots, one walking stick and wide brim hat. I would strongly recommend that especially if you are going all the way to Big Wave Bay. There was a red storm alert last night and there were plenty of water in the streams and some parts are more rocky and less well defined (although very small parts).The route is well signed and you are unlikely to get lost. I was alone and did fine given it was my first time hiking alone in HK. I only saw 3 people, 2 runners, 1 walker/hiker - it was Monday late morning afterall. The first signage show picnic area which gives a better view of Tai Tam Bay but you get even better view later so no need to detour there. Just keep following the signs to Dragon Back. My first distance post was H085 (you get them every 500m) and the last one was H100 before enter Big Wave Bay village.After reaching the peak, continuing on will bring you across several streams/fall which are manageable - tracking shoes will get wet for sure (not sure it was due to the rain the previous night). The path from the water tank to Big Wave Bay is paved for quite some distance, passing the cemetry on the left (you need to peek through the trees to see it). The final leg to the Big Wave Bay is back on hiking tracks which is still ok. Just follow the signs to the beach where the waves did not seem big at all. I headed for Shek O (you can have lunch at the village if you like) - which is almost 2km away. There is a bus stop for #9 at the entrance to the village if you like to take bus back to MTR. Check the bus schedule, not sure it comes every 20min or only once an hour. I did see (or actually miss one). Anyway walk and keep left all the way - the country club with golf course is on the left, you will reach Shek O where there is a beach too. There are more people and foreigners in Shek O and seemed to be living there.Take the minibus or #9 back to MTR station. I took minibus back for Hk$7 - the last stop. Recommended only if you like to hike and would enjoy seeing HK from such places.I enjoyed it certainly

A great outdoor hike to get out of busy city area. Loved this easy hike which is suitable for everyone & kids as well. Got great directions sign to guide us and lots if great sceneries alone the way to reward us during the hike. We end up at Shek O taking bus no.9 which end at the terminal for a seafood dinner & a good dip at the sea to end the hike before going back to the city.

Well worth the sweat. Try and head off early as the trail can get busy, especially on the weekends. There is the option to start the trail at the halfway point which provides a less traversed and dare I say more breathtaking walk.

Hard going but well worth it!. Now, I am not the fittest person by any means! So when my friends suggested we tackle the famous Dragons Back, I was hesitant. My friends persuaded me to go hiking; luring me in with the promise of an amazing lunch afterwards as a reward. When it comes to food, how was I to say no! 2.5 hours later... we finally got to the top. I admit I was the straggler, I was the complainer, walking at a 90 degree angle up the mountain. I basically looked like the hunch-back of Notre Dame. However, after making the journey up those notorious steps, sucking on candy to get my sugar level up, downing at least a liter of water and after several tantrums.... We finally made it! and the view was BREATHTAKING!!!! I would do it all over again just to see that view.I wouldn't be surprised if my friends never invite me to go hiking again, but i am sure glad I made it to the top and even took a celebratory photo with the plaque.If you a traveling to HK, this is one place you NEED to experience. Its a world away from the hustle and bustle of Central and Mong Kok.

Wonderful Hike only Minutes away from the Hustle and Bustle of Hong Kong. The Dragon's Back trail is Stage 8, and the final stage, of the 50 km Hong Kong Trail that runs from the Peak to Big Wave Bay. The Dragon's Back stage of the trail offers spectacular views in all directions, is well maintained and is approximately 8.5 km in length. The final 2.5 km are on concrete, and the rest of the path is compacted dirt and rock. There are patches along the way that are slippery when wet. This is an easy hike for anyone used to hiking.There are many terrific view points once the ridge is attained. Still on Hong Kong Island, and only minutes from the urban core, the greenery and scenery on the Dragon Back's trail make you feel like you are much further away from the hustle and bustle of the city.The trailhead is directly across the road from the To Tei Wan bus stop for the no. 9 bus for Shek O from Shaukeiwan MTR Station. The terminus is at Big Wave Bay, which also is served by the no. 9 bus.There are small shops and cafes/restaurants at Big Wave Bay. Venture down to the beach and you'll find a variety of choices. Big Wave Bay is popular with surfers. Hiking Dragon's Back, with travel time included, takes about is half-a-day, and is a great way to enjoy the beauty of the region.

Nice walk going up, a tat tricky going down if you are not too good at it.. Walking up is nice and easy,Watch out for windy days as it does get quite cold and windy, going up is not too much of a problem, if you have bad knees going down the stair case could be slightly problem some. Lovely view from top, well worth your time to go there.

Easy hike, but fabulous scenery!. This hike has sensational views. My friends and I found the hike pretty easy (I suppose we hike for our jobs) but it was easy to navigate with great 360 degree views of the surrounding beautiful beaches! :)

Decent Hike. Not too challenging, a decent hike. Great views and good vibe, plenty of tourists and locals enjoying a good day out. Its normally alot more crowded in the weekends we were told, as we went on a Saturday..

Great walk. Just the right balance between rigour, time and great destination - Big Wave Beach is a cool spot and lovely beach with waves. Some great great views along the way especially on a clear day & you walk through some very attractive terrain. You can get a bus from there to Shek O for lunch at the Thai or other restaurant. Then bus back from there to MTR - easy.

Beautiful Hike. We hiked this trail one morning with our 5 year old and two year old. The 5 year old was able to do the entire hike, and the 2 year old rode in a back carrier. I suggest bring plenty of drinking water. The hike was a bit longer than we anticipated based on the guide book we were used. Amazing 360 degree views. Well worth spending a full morning on!

Taming the dragon. A short but steep ascent on to the ridge but once you are up there the views are spectacular. The old colonial town of Stanley across the harbour on one side and the beautiful coastal village on the other side. The walk is not over demanding and access points to the ridge are well served by the local bus.

Lovely views and out of the city. We caught a cab out to this amazing hill walk with amazing views all around the island . The caught a bus ( the stop is right there at the end of the walk) down to the beach - bliss!

Great hike. I've done this hike a couple of times. It's a good length with some nice views. Get a bus towards Shek O from Sheung Wan and get off at To Tei Wan, there are steps up to the trail and it's something like 6km-8km hike from there to Big Wave Bay.

Nice getaway from the city. There were lots of people on the day we went given it was a public holiday but it was still very enjoyable. A great half day trip. Getting to the top was o my about a quarter of the walk with the descent taking the longest. Bring your own water and towel! Perfect sadly was finishing in Shek O for lunch. The pizza place is great as well as the BBQ food on the street.

Breath of fresh air. A nice 2 hour hike, the views are lovely. It's one of the easiest hikes on the Island. You come down to Big Wave bay or can carry onto to Shek O beach where you can get great Thai food or even hire out a BBQ pit that has everything included! Just bring your swimmers!

Wonderful hike. Good long morning's walk, but once you get up, it undulates with gradual ascents/descents along the ridge. Path can be a bit slippery when it's wet, and the wind can howl up there, so even on a sunny day, you'll need to take some protection. Trail is well marked with markers, so no worries about getting lost. And plenty of other friendly folk doing the trail as well.
Try. So beautiful place. Th mountain , beach is very nice and i cant know how to talk about it. Finally, the atmostphere is so good
Views of Sheko are breathtaking !. Afterwards walk to Sheko for lunch at the local Thai resto, not fancy but tasty. Then get to the beach and take a dip

Fabulous even on a hazy day. If you enjoy fresh air fabulous views and moderate exercise this walk is for you . Planning this walk can be confusing the geography is complicated and in fact there are several ways to attempt the dragons back. The HK tourist office in the arrival area ( before you leave the secure area) has a great free publication on hiking and cycling in HK with clear instructions for several walks including dragons back. Following their instructions will give you a longer hike than the one we did and you will walk in the same direction as most other hikers. We followed another group of walkers off the number 9 bus at a stop called COLLINSON on the display panel at the front of the bus ( several stops before the stop where we had planned to alight) walked up some cement steps then a longish steep cement road past some toilets and onto a track pointing to dragons back .At this point we turned right and started walking the dragons back walk in reverse if we had turned left we would have walked to big wave bay. walking the hike in the opposite direction is shorter, easier and still spectacular. We missed the section to BIG wave bay and finished the walk by descending to the bus stop where we should have begun! From there we caught a bus for the short ride down to Shek O as there was no foot path at all. I have also heard it is possible to do a much longer walk from the last station on the red line all the way to dragons back which would be interesting. The Hong Kong haze meant our views were limited ( no distant island views) but still spectacular . We had lunch at the Thai restaurant a wander around Shek O,walked out to the island and returned for a coffee in the funky little cafe near the Thai restaurant before returning to central. If you are interested in pushing on to Stanley it is possible to get off bus 9 on the return journey at the stop marked COLLINSON walk forwards to the junction then turn R . You should see another bus stop close by where you can catch bus number 14 to Stanley.

How to unwind from long flights!. As other reviews say, it easy to get to the trail by public transport, and the walk is really good, especially if you have just spent 24 hours or so trapped in an aeroplane! Take half a day and be sure to do it - the change from the crowded bustling city just a mile or two away is amazing. Shek O is a good place to end with a Thai Restaurant that is rated by my local friends in HK....

Fairly easy 3 hour walk, accessible from public transport, nice views. We took the number 9 bus and the driver advised us where the start point was for the shorter of the 2 walks. The first km or so is uphill, mostly steps cut into the hill. It's not too difficult if you take your time. The route then takes you across the summit of the hills - the Dragon's Back - and, on a good day, the views are great. It rained the day we did it, but it was still worthwhile even though visibility wasn't great and some of the walk was a bit slippery. The route back to Big Wave Bay is signposted, but sometimes to signs are partially hidden by vegetation or there's a side route that isn't signposted. We managed not to get lost and found a minibus back to Shek O, which cost $5 each, then teh number 9 bus back to town. Overall, a great way to spend some time in the open air for less than $20 each (transport cost, the walk is free!). Take water and snacks with you, as there's nothing available en route.

Great views on a clear day.. Public transport to the track head is both cheap and convenient, and the views from the top are pleasant on a clear day. Worth a visit if you have a few hours to spare. The walk up is not very difficult either.

An easy city breakaway. Before setting up for the Dragon's Back consider visiting the Tourism Board Office at the Star Ferry Pier - it's good to have a map of the whole trail at hand. Do not rely 100% on the hiking information contained in the leaflets though: it's written the trail is approx. 8,5 km and takes around 6 hours. If you are reasonably fit, however, it takes 2,5 hours. To get there: take the metro until Shau Kei Wan station (8 HKD from Central), exit A3 (Shau Kei Wan Bus Terminus) and from there bus n.9 to To Tei Wan (HKD 6.7). The bus ride will take around 20 min. The stops are indicated on a screen, but you will recognize on your left the beginning of the Dragon's Back Trail marked by hiking signs and a map board. The first part of the trail is rising fast but in most cases there are stone staircases, so it's quick and easy. The Shek O Peak is the highest point of the trail (284m) and from there the view is great. Just pay attention not to miss it, since it's not on the main route, but rather a deviation. It's not hard to find it: the first pavilion you encounter on your way marks a bifurcation: if you go straight you follow the main trail, but on your right is a little hidden path leading to the scenic point and later on reconnecting to the main trail. After that the road starts descending and the last section is enclosed in the forest, so it can get quite boring, specially because there are many other hikers - even if it's late afternoon and even if the weather is not great! - so you might lose the feeling of being in the nature. Anyway, at the end of the trail you will find Big Wave Bay Beach (eating in a local restaurant is about 5 HKD) - nothing special really. I think the best part of the whole trail was actually the scenic spot and the Dragon's Back view itself - the profile of the hills along the South-East part of Hong Kong Island. To get back: take a minibus from Big Wave Bay Beach (12 HKD) to Shau Kei Wan Bus Terminus.

A great getaway from the city. We read lots of great reviews on Trip Advisor and many other websites and knew this was something we could not miss while we were in HK. We went on a sunny weekend in late March. We started at the trail at To Tei Wan (MTR to Shau Kei Wan. Exit A3 to get to the Bus Terminus. NWFB Bus no. 9). It took us around an hour to reach the top and the view was breath-taking despite the slight fog. If you would like to get away from the skyscrapers and shopping malls for a little while & enjoy a little exercise, this is a great getaway. The hike was not difficult and that was evident by the many young families we met on the hike. We stopped for a little break at a picnic site on the way to Big Wave Bay and ended the trip at Big Wave Bay by taking a bus back to the Shau Kei Wan Station. The entire hike and journey took us around 3.5 hours.Remember to bring your own bottle of water and a little snack as there are no shops throughout the trail.

Deserves a slot in your itinerary. We went on a weekday afternoon while the weather was unpredictable. The place was quite deserted, and we only met a few fellow hikers along the way. However despite the intermittent drizzling, strong wind and often muddy tracks, we made it to Shek O Peak. We couldn't see any scenery because of the fog, so made our way back to the main road. Verdict: it's worth the time and no words can describe the fun we had.Getting there is easy, take the MTR (blue line) to Shau Kei Wan station, exit and take from the bus terminal Bus no. 9. Alight 11 stops away at To Tei Wan, there are LED signs in the bus indicating the next stop the bus will stop at, so no worries about getting lost, unless you get off at a wrong stop.
Great Views. Worth the (cheap) bus journey to find the start of this walk. Not too difficult and great views on the right day

A great hiking experience for beginners. You don't have to worry about what your mum says about the dangers of hiking, be it being abducted etc, because there will be lots of ppl hiking in the day to help each other. The steps are fairly easy to climb but the sight when you reach the top isn't the best. I would suggest you to walk in the road which says "picnic site" - the scene there is the best for photography! Note that when you reach the peak, you have a choice to continue walking straight or turn back. I would suggest that you walk straight and go down by there as it is much gentler. I would also strongly recommend all to bring your own hand sanitiser/wet tissues to wipe your hands after using the toilet instead of washing your hands in the sink as..... The water really stinks.....

Nice getaway from the busy city. We went on a weekday afternoon and it was not crowded.We started at To Tei Wan and as mentioned by many reviewers, the initial part of the hike was mostly steps and more steps.Views from the Shek O Peak were great.After the Dragon's Back, the hike to Tai Tam Gap was pretty boring. We ended our hike at Cape Collinson Road and did not continue to Big Bay Wave Beach. We took about 1.5 hours from To Tei Wan to Cape Collinson Road. Overall, it was a nice getaway from the busy city.
Perfect get-away from the busy HK streets. You don't have to be a pro to take on this treck... It's a half day affair and not too TOUGH... Breath taking views of city, mountains, beach and sea...

Nice route. Really nice route. Took 1h 45mins to the dragon's back and another ~2h down to the road. Alight at To Tei Wan (unsure of spelling) and there's toilet there, and only one there throughout the entire route. I went in mid march and couldn't see anything but fog. Still, its a great experience becos the weather is cool (~ 13-14 oC) and the route is beautiful.
MOST BEAUTIFUL HIKE. There isn't a better hike in Hong Kong and arguably in east asia. A must do for all, and it's fairly easy for all ages! Shek O Beach is a good ending point!
Good on a clear day. It's a bit of a knee trembler up the stairs to the path but worth it for the view. I would also recommend getting the bus down to Shek-O beach.

Very nice,variety of views. Cityscape and the bay on one side, beaches and nature on the other. Very nice elevated views, great variety, unlike the "switchbacks" along canyon walls that often give you the same view for hours at a time. Bring water, includes trails and stairs. Can walk down to the beach villages for seafood in the evening.

Go early. Dragon's Back was one of the greatest hikes I went on in HK. The hike is not too hard but there are a few steep part with stairs. There are arrows you can follow so you won't get lost and a few rest stops along the way. I recommend you to definitely bring water and a CAMERA. The view is amazing, as you climb up there are several spots where you feel like you are on top of the world. Make sure you start your trip in the morning as it's always dangerous being on a hike at night. Mostly go early because once you finish the hike, it ends up at Shek O beach! The beach is great and I always love when there are fun waves. I do recall seeing a floating dock that someone was playing with their dog on. Great atmosphere, there was some sort of festivities happening when we went. Definitely put this on your to do list!

Lovely walk with great views. Nice views of the Stanley peninsular on one side and the East of the island on the other. Best to go in the morning on a sunny, clear day. The walk is fairly easy going. Not too many steps on this one compared to many of the other hill walks and the distance isn't too far.

Great hike!. First, and most important is to do this beautiful hike on a day with good weather. When we went there the weather was nice and warm (around 20 C) but at the top of the trail the wind was blowing strongly making the temp feel lower. There is no point going on a cloudy and hazy day because you will miss the wonderful view.We took the hike on a Sunday and the trail was so crowded that you had to wait in line in order to get through certain areas... So, if possible, go on a week day. The hike to the top is quite easy but you should have some hiking shoes with a good grip. I didn't and coming down was a bit challenging as I had no support for my ankles. After the hike, visit Shek O beach.

See another side of HK!. I couldn't give Dragons Back 5 stars as we went on a gloomy, cloudy day so we missed out on the views - they look amazing though. However, the hike was still fun and we had a tasty meal at the Chinese Thai restaurant in Shek O. Take the MTR to Shau Kei Wan station (towards the end of the blue line), take the bus depot exit and catch the No.9 to To Tei Wan. Don't be too worried about where to get off - the bus has an automated sign which will flash up each stop. The bus stop is directly at the start of the trail. The trail has adequate signage so it's hard to get lost. As a gym goer, the hike was fairly easy. There are some inclines but someone of moderate health would be just fine. Kids would be fine too. The hike can be completed between 2-3 hours depending on the pace. Just make sure you schedule this hike on a nice clear day otherwise you will see nothing. I'd recommend going during the week to beat any potential crowds - we only saw a handful of people.Also, make sure you have enough water and snacks for the duration of the hike as there are no shops until Big Wave Bay.

Check the weather before you go!. We went on a Monday morning and it was a very peaceful hike up to the peak. There weren't many people - we met a group at the start and lone hikers along the way - so it made for a nice change compared to crowded Hong Kong. The weather definitely wasn't on our side though, it was misty and we couldn't see anything at the top, so do check the weather forecast before going. Overall, it was an easy 5km hike which took 2 hours. At the end of the hike, there are signages to either Shek O road (where you can take bus no 9 from the opposite side of the road back to the interchange), or a 4km walk to Shek O beach. As the weather wasn't too good, we took bus no 9 from the same side of the road to the last stop and it brought us right to Shek O beach.Directions:We followed the directions given by many reviewers - exit A3 at Shau Kei Wan MTR station and take bus no 9 from the interchange. You can choose to alight at Tai Tam or To Tei Wan Village stop (there are panels on the bus showing the name of the stop in English) - they are just opposite ends of the same route. I would recommend starting from To Tei Wan village though. There were parts of the hike where we walked uphill which I feel would have been more difficult walking down.Do consider spending the day at Dragon's Back and Shek O beach. We left from Mongkok at 11 in the morning and returned at 6 in the evening. There is also a wet market set up every evening near the bus interchange, and it was fun walking and looking around.

good hike! not too challenging. we caught the bus no. 9 here from shau kei wan and got off at tei wan. the view was stunning and the climb was not too challenging. we decided to go on a saturday to avoid the crowds at other attractions. this track is popular with tourists and locals. it took about 2 hours to walk it but we didnt go all the way to shek o village. make sure to wear comfty clothes. It wasnt too cold here in the middle on winter as there was cover from the trees. but at the shrek peak it was windy. we saw a lot of local wildlife in particular there was 4 eagles circularing above. go to the road and catch bus no. 9 back to the metro station. make sure you use the toilet at the start of the track otherwise you will have to bear it to the end. and bring some water as there are no fountains. there are some picnic areas if you like to have a picnic with a view.

An unexpected side of Hong Kong. Our hike up Dragon's Back trail was glorious simply because the sun chose to shine the day we went. Blue sea as far as the eye can see...We took the MTR to Shau kei Wan station, then walked the 3mins to the bus depot to catch the No. 9 bus (HKD6.90 by octopus card). Get off at stop #12 (To Tei Wan), and you'll be at the start of the trail. This hike is pretty popular so expect a lot of people to be hiking there too. There are a few paths you can choose to start your hike. We decided to go straight up; the first KM was pretty steep but after that, it levels off and the incline is more friendly. There are sign-posts almost every half KM and you'll have the option of choosing different paths. The one with the best view is straight up to Shek O Peak/Dragon's Back Peak. After the busy urban jungle, this hike is the needed breath of fresh air, and it definitely showed me a side of Hong Kong I didn't expect.This hike is a snore if you're a gym-goer and doable even if you're moderately fit. If kids as young as 5 can do it, there's really no excuse you can't make it to the top. The views will be worth it. We finished the Dargon's Back trail in 1.5hrs, and decided to continue hiking to Big Wave Bay, which was another 45mins frm the bottom of the hill. Getting transport back to Shau Kei Wan from Big wave Bay can be quite tricky. You can opt to take the mini-bus (at HKD12) or walk out 5mins to the main road past the small round-a-bout to the citybus bus stop (same bus to get there) for half-the cost.

A Hiking Trail for Anyone who loves a VIEW. When you know how to get there, the view is mind blowing. Only takes half an hour since bus stop to reach the first of many views, simply breath taking, and the hike difficulty is only moderate, so choose appropriate day snd make it happen.

perfect escape from the city. have been to Hong Kong for a few times but never did have the chance to go to Dragon's Back. finally went on the recent trip, and it was really fun! got to see Hong Kong from a different perspective. the hike took about 1.5hours to the Peak of Dragon Back (We stopped along the way to take many photos) and you have the option of ending the hike by going down or continuing the hike toto Big Wave Beach (which we did), and the distance was about 8km in total. it was really windy too, so the hike was enjoyable. if you have the time and want to see a different side of Hong Kong, do head to Dragon's Back!

Great Day Trip. This was a great trail, with gorgeous views, and an easy-moderate climb. One of my favorite parts of the trail, was that it ends at a beach! It took us (young adults) 2 hours to hike the entire trail and then we spent the day at the beach. The one downfall was that we went during the Chinese New Years and there were many busloads of people also hiking that same day. However, most people didn't mind us going around them on the trail and we were then able to attain a more peaceful experience as we hiked. I would highly recommend this trip.
Great family hike. Dragon's Back is a great family hike for a sunny Sunday. You will enjoy arriving at Big Wave beach or Shek O and have good lunch in one of the nice restaurants there.

Hong Kong Hikes. I love this hike. We get a cab there from Mid Levels. It cost about HKD120. Most cabbies know where the start of the hike is. The beginning of the hike is the most difficult but I would say on a scale of 1 - 5 this hike is a 2 so not overly strenuous at all. The views from the ridge are awesome. The Shek O Golf Course looks so beautiful and the outer Island add to the vista. We always reward ourselves by continuing the walk into Shek O and having lunch at the Thai and Chinese restaurant on the left hand side of the roundabout. It's a great day out. Highly recommend it.

Worth going. It was an easy trek and it is safe to trek alone too. The views from the summit was marvellous. Wind was so strong and the sun was very scorching as well. I really enjoyed this break from the usual shopping spree in the city.
Great trek. Great trek, amazing scenary and was great to get to see the other side of Hong Kong. I loved the skyscrapers and everything but this reminds me of being back in Italy.

No physical challange but a nice change from the city centre. The trail is super easy to reach and offers beautiful views. Considering that it's no surprise that it can get very crowded. Still, it's a nice change from Hong Kong's stressful city center.We expected it to be far more challenging, but we reached Shek O in less than two hours. It's rather a walk than a hike. If you bring your swimsuit you can combine the walk with an afternoon at the beach.

Great WALK, super views. From Skek O to the prison, good 8km walk, super views, fairly undulating lots of steps but worth it. Many other trekkers of every nationality - if the views are good on a clear day, its a great walk and not very difficult.

Spectacular & worth the effort. My wife & I did the Dragon's back trail on Feb 1. It was a clear, pleasant day & boy, the views made up for the effort & the crowd (it was Lunar New Year hols). The rolling hills, shrubbery and the absolutely stunning beaches make for a truly spectacular setting. Getting to Deagon's back isn't too difficult either-Sheu Kei Wan by MTR & Bus 9 will take you to Shek O country park in less than an hour from the city centre. While the trek itself isn't too grueling, be dressed appropriately-jeans & dress shoes won't help!

Too crowded, nice with little children but not for a real hike. Dragon's back is a nice day-trip if you have small children and you don't want to wonder off or go offroad. But I wouldn't recommend it at all for the more experienced hikers amongs us. It gets really crowded and you have to overtake people time after time to just get moving a bit. If you want a real hike, this is not the way to go. Some nice views though and afterwards you can go to Shek-o Beach for some drinks of thai food.

The walk worth your while. I spent a Saturday morning walking this trail with my family.This trail is easy to find. Take the MTR to Shau Kei Wan and exit at A3 and you will see the bus terminus. On the extreme right of the bus bay, you will see bus number 9. Alight at "To Tei Wan"- which is 11 stops away. Do not be anxious when you need to alight the bus because the bus has a panel stating the next bus stop. It makes sense to buy the Octopus Card at any MTR station and you can use this card to pay for all your transport. Once you reach "TO TEI WAN", you will see the trail there. The view is amazing and even on a weekend, you will not see the crowd like those in town. It was the highlight of our trip to Hong Kong and my wife and 2 adult kids were very happy. At the end of the trail, you will find a T-junction. We went to Big Wave Beach. The view was another winner. You will find bus number 9 there but it is one stop to Shek-O and you need to alight and re-board the bus 9 to get back to Shau Kei Wan. But I am sure there is a way to get to Shau Kei Wan without going to Shek-O first.
Dragon's Back. Nice leisurely walk. Away from the typical tourist trail of shop, shop, shop! Great scenery, pleasantly surprised by the views. Journey there is good too.

Very pleasant and easy walk. Based on some of the reviews I was expecting a walk or hike of some challenge, but in reality this is a few hours walk. Some of the ups and downs are fairly steep and young kids can struggle a little, but it's so wing most people should be able to do. It was easy enough to get a taxi at the start and the end and the kids had a great time. Stunning views and nice to get away from the commercialism and buildings.

Good hike to get away from city life. Hike was not overly strenuous. Got lost a bit at Chai Wan station but once on track it was interesting starting walk climbing up a cemetery. The walk is clearly marked and there are regular markers so you know you're on track. The views are lovely and it's so nice to be in green space especially in such a large metropolis like HK. The view from Dragon's Back is beautiful.

Brilliant - you'll see another side of HK, literally. This is a great walk, and far easier than the guides would have you believe. We are keen walkers but even then this is an achievable walk for anyone who is moderately fit. And the views, particularly on the first half, are simply stunning; you can forget that Hong Kong is basically a tropical island when you're in Central or Admiralty, but this walk will remind you.We skipped the descent to Big Wave Bay and exited at the NW tip to get back to the Shek'O Road and the number 9 bus back to the MTR. To get to this point took around 2 hours at a relaxed pace. I'm sure a swim at the beach and perhaps a leisurely lunch would have been lovely, but we had a flight to catch.Pick a clear day and wear decent shoes/walking boots. If it's hot, take loads of water.There is a good map at the start and I recommend taking a photo of this if you haven't got a guide. There is one section where it's not entirely clear whether you turn right or left at a T-junction just after descending some steps; we turned right after much deliberation and this seemed to be the right choice!I highly recommend that you do this walk as it gives you a completely different perspective on Hong Kong, away from all the skyscrapers and crowds.

Go on a good sunny day.. Lovely Hike, Done it three times over my 5 month stay. It is one of the easiest hikes, although a bit long if you are not used to it. It finishes on a nice little surfer beach where you can go for a swim, have some food and get the bus back. If its a very misty day, you will be missing some of the best views of HK island, so try and do it in good weather.

Fantastic escape from the hustle and bustle.. We were so glad to experience this hiking trail.The taxi from central cost about £8 and we were dropped by "lai chi rehabiltation centre".you can get a bus number 780 then pick up the number 9 which we did in reverse to return.(9 from Shek o then 780 to central-write the numbers down and show the drivers and they will tell you where to get off for the next bus) Buses cost less than £2 for the total return journey. The walk is steep in places and should not be attempted if you have health problems.It took us two + hours at a leisurely pace to get to shek o ( hop on the 9 bus at the end of the trail into the seaside village) We were lucky to meet a fantastic gentleman called Lim who regularly flies his glider up there. he was so helpful and accompanied us on the second leg of the journey pointing us in the right direction for the buses etc.A pleasant outing was made more special by meeting someone with local knowledge who was really kind and friendly. No trip to Hong Kong would be complete without seeing the Dragons back.

Wilderness Trail in Hong Kong. Hiking Dragon's Back in Hong Kong is not exactly like hiking a true wilderness trail, but it is considered the last urban wilderness trail in Asia, and it is definitely worth a day of an extended stay. The trail is accessible by bus or car, and the trails are well marked and easy to follow. Some sections include steep stairs, so this isn't an easy hike, but it's nothing that someone in reasonable shape cannot do. We took the trail down to the beach and enjoyed lunch in town before finishing the trail and taking a bus back to the city. Along the way, you'll see views of islands, bays, a golf course, some very large private homes, and lots of undeveloped woodland. It's hard to iimagine that one of the world's great cities is a short ride away.

Nice Hike. Take the MTR to Shau Kei Wan, go out at exit A3 and take the number 9 bus and get off at the trail head. It is not a challenging hike but it is a very beautiful one. This is an opportunity to see and experience a different Hong Kong. You can end your hike with lunch at Big Wave Bay or Shek O. We ended our hike at Big Wave Bay but then walked along the road to Shek O (about 20 minutes). This is a very pretty place with an excellent Thai Restaurant near the beach.

A serious hike with an even more serious view! Amazing!!. We just came back from Hong Kong where we spent the New Years.. We woke up early on New Years eve and had a cab driver from our hotel take us to start of the hike. We got dropped off way before the actual start and were getting really nervous as the highway is deserted and with limited walk ways!! After walking for about 20 minutes, we found the entrance!! Make sure if you go and get dropped off by taxi ask them to drop you at the top of the observation point, the entrance is very small so be careful you might miss it. The entire hike took us 2.5 hrs, we are fit and work out a lot, we have heard it might take 4 hours depending on endurance. The steps are high and its a difficult hike but it's very worthy it. At the top of the mountain you get to see the south china sea and the north bay - its an amazing view!! If you can make it all the way down to the beach - you should, its really pretty - not much of a tons or bars, three at max little beach shacks, but we were able to get a sandwich and a cold beer. To get back to hong kong the best bet is to take the bus - but if you are really lucky like us, we caught a cab that was dropping someone off when we got to the bus stop - the can back is about 170 Hk dollars, or $21 US dollars - also worth not the hassle after an entire day.

An exhilarating walk. I had no idea that Hong Kong had such wonderful countryside as this until I went there. The Dragon's Back is a great way to see the 'other' side of Hong Kong. We took the MTR to Shau Kei Wan and then a bus to the Shek O Road to the start of the trail. Then it was a stunning walk along the coast to Shek O where we had a delicious lunch before spending a couple of hours and then catching the bus back. All in all a wonderful day.

Wonderful hike with kids. We hiked part of Dragon's Back with two small kids, as we wanted to get into nature after several days of urban immersion. Highly recommended as long as you are somewhat adventurous - the kids loved it. We started after lunch and were done before sundown: it took some extra time as parts of the trail were quite steep, but was not overly difficult as long as you are careful. We were rewarded with some sweeping views of the Hong Kong skyline, including of Shek O and the southern part of the island. We hiked on a weekday; it wasn't too crowded.

Good hike. The Dragon's back hike starts on the Shek O road and then you can choose to end it either on Big Wave Bay or Tai Tam or forgot the other place name. The hike has some steep slopes, it has some steps, flat roads and rough patches at different places and they all add up to a good hike experience. The views from the top are some of the best views of Hong Kong. Also, you would see some people paragliding here if the weather is good.Note: There are no refreshments available on the hike. So, it would be a pretty good choice to pack some food and drinks before you embark on the hike.

Beautiful views and not too difficult. This hike has some wonderful views above the Hong Kong skyline. It is an easy to moderate hike and was somewhat crowded the day we went. take some water if it is warm and you might have to arrange transportation ahead of time for the ride back.

Beautiful and Scenic Hiking Route. If you are into hiking and a nature loving person, this is a really beautiful place that you must not miss while you are in Hong Kong! Its recommended to cater about half a day for this trip.Took a train to Shau Kei Wan Station, exit A3, followed by taking bus no.9 from the bus interchange and alight at To Tei Wan Village stop along Shek O Road to start off the route up Dragon's Back. The hike up is not difficult and the path is well defined and easy to follow with many areas to stop by to take photos and to enjoy the breathtaking coastal views of beaches, golf courses, islands and villages. It can get abit chilly as winds are very strong up there during this season. It took me about 1.5hrs to finish the trek and another 1 hr more to walk to the the big wave beach where you can have a your lunch there and enjoy the sea breeze and beautiful big waves.

wilderness so close to town. 10 minute taxi ride from central and amazing walk on the spine to Shek. Only issue can be transport back - sometimes a big queue and not many taxis come. still, there is a bus....

Cracking views. Wear good footwear. We followed the very good instructions others have posted on this web site I.e. No 9 Bus out of MTR station. The first part of the walk is uphill on mostly steps. You see some great views of the bays behind as you climb but the view from the first view from the top is awesome. You then meander along the ridge and up to the official top. It is all well marked.Then you commence a partial drop until you come to a T junction and turn right. This next part of the walk is flat and you cannot see too much because of trees etc. it takes about 30 minutes to complete this section before you turn right towards the bay. At this junction there are toilets.Then a section on a road before starting a very uneven stretch to the bay. This part is where you need good footwear and by the time we got to the bay we were both feeling the uneven rocks through our trainers.Super little bay but disappointed that the cafe on beach (Eric's) served mostly European food. We went into the village for local fare and after eating a very nice meal back to the cafe on the front for a beer in the sun looking over beach and sea. NB if we revisited we would get the restaurant to do us a takeaway and take this to the beach. Good clean toilets at the beach.Short walk to the bus stop and we caught the mini bus back to MTR for $10 each. Driver knew when no. 9 bus was due and set off about 10 mins before.The walk took us approx 2.5 hours and we did not rush and had plenty of water and picture stops.A super day out which we would recommend.

Easy Hike With Splendid Views. It is very easy to get to the Dragon's Back. The hike itself is very easy and relaxing, although it goes up and down a lot. The views are truly amazing. For a good hiker the whole thing can take less than half a day (including to and from downtown hotel).

Best walk in HK. Absolutely my favourite walk in HK. Take number 9 bus from Shau Kai Wan MTR, get out at Tai Tam stop, and you can't miss the start. Then it is signed all the way, firstly for Dragon's Back, then Big Wave Bay, and then Shek O - but take a bus from Big Wave Bay to Shek O, there is nothing to see and you have to walk down a main road. The walk is tough in parts, but nothing that this somewhat overweight 43 yr old couldn't manage, knowing there was cold beer and Shek O's wonderful beach and food at the end of it, and the views once you are on the Dragon's Back are magnificent, it's difficult to believe you are actually on HK Island.
A great day out fabulous views. Can be busy and make sure you get the bus back before 5 or you will be queuing.. But we'll worth the views across both sides of the island . Handy loos at the bus stop

An Easy day hike. Very easy and straightforward hike with spectacular mountain-meet-ocean views. We hiked with a 5-year-old child and there were no problems. Definitely recommend it to any visitors who are interested in exploring the countryside of Hong Kong.

Highly recommended!. Fantastic hike that is a great way to see a different side of Hong Kong. Highly recommended! We did the hike on NYE and there were barely any others on the trail.We took the bus to Tei To Wan and walked through to Big Wave Bay which took us around 2 hours 45. The first half of the hike was definitely more scenic.

Great walk of (HK) China. After a week in HK, and thoroughly enjoying the beautiful, but chaotic pace of busy HK, I wasn't sure I wanted to do a hike through the hills - I get out and walk through nature all the time back home, so why would I want to do it here? Well, I'm thrilled I made the effort, because walking the Dragon's Back is one of the highlights of my two week trip to HK! We got dropped by a taxi on Chek O Bay Road and immediately ascended as we started the walk. A few hours later (about 6km I think?), we were looking down on Big Wave Bay and the village of Chek O, with their beautiful beaches and picturesque, rocky coastline! It's a distinctly different side to HK's bustling shopping, dining and touring experience! Make the effort!

excellent even with kids. We live nearby and we love this hike Easy even with small kids and amazing viewsWhen finishing on the main road, take a bus to Shek O and have a drink there for a nice ending

Beautiful Walk. The view from here is fantastic, if the pollution is not high. Looking out to the sea in the direction of Waglan Island. At the end you will be at Big Wave Bay. Nice to stop for a drink/snack before you head back to the city

Hiking the Back. We did not do the whole hike from start to finish (which ends at the big wave beach) but rather from the start to the Shek O peak which took us 45mins (1 way) and then turned around, but it was enough to give us a good feel of doing the hike . The hike though short was nice with paths well marked .We did the hike on a Sunday and was a bit crowded as what others have also mentioned, but the upside is that you feel safe with so many hikers around, but personally I would prefer to do it on a weekday and complete it - something to plan for in the future

I found and walked it alone. Lonely Planet get there instructions were perfect, the walk was amazing and when I finished up in the Big Wave sufring village I was stunned with happy surprise. Wonderful exhilarating experience.
Dont' miss it!. Hong Kong is not just skyscrapers and lights! there is also nature and a very nice 8km trekking that should not be missed. the view is great, dont forget your camera

Dragon's back vs Twin Peak Hike. The Twin Peak Hike from Hong Kong Park View to Stanley Promenade is definitely much tougher than the Dragon's back hike. If your criteria for a hike is a scenic view then I would definitely recommend the Dragon's back hike. Moreover on completion of this hike you land up in either Shek O beach (more commercial) or Big Wave Bay beach (more secluded). The site of surfers surfing, dogs running, and a little snack bar to satisfy the big post hike hunger pang, is extremely rewarding! It took us 3 hours to complete this undulating hike. A day well spent in Hong Kong. If you take the island line from central to Shau Kei Wan, it will take you around 20 minutes to reach. Grab Mc Donalds or some other grub at Shau Kei Wan and then take the number 9 bus (the terminus is located outside exit A3 of the MTR) to Shek O road. It will take another 20-30 minutes to reach so even if you leave from central at noon you will easily complete the hike before sunset.

Dragon's back hiking. Just returned from an afternoon trek across Dragon's back in Hong Kong.I would suggest it a great day outing if you are tired of the hustle and bustle of Hong Kong and want to take a break from seeing the throngs of people in HK and Kowloon. Though I would suggest the best time to do the walk is when there is less people on the mountain as parts of the track are quite narrow. As we did the hike in Winter and not on the week end, there were very few people to be seen. We had read other reports on Trip Adviser and comments made by hikers who had to beat off crowds. I could understand that on busy days it would be very frustrating to do the walk, when the sole purpose was to avoid crowds, so best check with the HK tourist board to check on the crowds before heading off. We started making our way on the MTR from Tsim Sha Tsui at 3pm so we thought we might miss the morning rush (if it existed) on the mountain. It was also a lot cooler especially on the return leg. Today is Jan 3rd and the day's temp was 21 deg celsius. It was quite warm in downtown Kowloon so my wife and I were a little hesitant in doing the trek due to the warm weather in Tsim Sha Tsui, however when we returned to our hotel and sat around, we thought what the heck, let's do it, even though we had no caps/hats to wear to shield the sun. This as it turned out was not really necessary as most of the walk (except the Dragon's back section) was sheltered by the shrubbery. We also didn't have sunglasses ,nor did i have shorts - as you can see we were not really dressed for the part. We did however both have our sneakers (runners) which was fortunate. I would suggest comfortable footwear and loose fitting clothes.How to get there: Fairly simple.Take MTR Blue line toward Chai Wan. Get off at Shau Kei Wan stop. Exit the station via A3 exit and head across the road toward the bus depot. Look for No.9 bus (On our day it was the line of buses furtherest away from the MTR exit). We scanned our Octopus card on the bus. If i remember correctly the bus fare was HK$6.90. Then took the bus ride up the narrow (Shek O) road and got off at stop "To Tei Wan".Then as we got off the bus we immediately saw the wooden sign "Dragon's back" walk. There was also an aerial map of the region outlining the pathways and place names and distances.The climb up Dragon's back for the first 1km was quite rugged, so i would suggest people with leg/joint problems might find the going a bit tough. The path gets a little narrow in some spots and the path surface is uneven/irregular due to the numerous exposed rocks, however there are resting spots along the way. A moderate degree of fitness is highly recommended for the uphill climb to reach the top/ridge of Dragon's back. However getting to the top is well worth the climb. The view is breath taking! We decided to continue the walk to Big Wave bay. There were several options along the way to cut short the walk, however it was still light and we made good progress (as i am a relatively fast walker) so we thought to follow the path down to where we looked down upon when we were on top of the mountain - so the walk would finish at the quaint surf beach of Tai Long Wan.The HK tourist board website advises that the Dragon's walk is 8.5km and the ave. hiking time is 6hrs. We completed the walk in 2 hrs (we jogged approx 1km on part of the descent on the boring concreted section which had a gentle gradient). We were concerned about making a dinner deadline so we thought we should hurry up. So I think the 6hr time frame is very generous. The weather also helped and by the time we started our descent the sun was less strong and so the weather conditions were very pleasant. We capped it off with ice creams at the final destination. There are no drinking stations so bring water and food if required. We did not wait for the No. 9 bus for the return journey, as not to long after we waited, a maxi bus (seats approx 16 people) turned up - fix rate HK$10 back to Shau Kei Wan MTR station.I noticed that on the way back there were more people waiting at stops along the way back, however as our bus was full the driver waved them down. I guess in reaching the terminal part of the walk has the advantage of ensuring a seat back on the next bus/maxibus/taxi. All in all a great day away from the mad rush in downtown HK.

Hike the Dragons Back- Asia's best urban hiking trail!!!. There are a number of ways to reach the start of the Dragons Back or even extend the hike slightly if you wish.One option is to start at Big Wave Bay, this can be reached by getting off at Shau Kei Wan MTR (on the blue Island Line). Just outside the station you will find a bus terminal (or taxi rank, although this option is more expensive) take number 9 bus to the end of the route, Big Wave Bay. From here start the hike which will initially be signposted 'Hong Kong Trail' and will eventually turn into the Dragons Back. This will extend your trip length and you will get to visit the untouched and local village at Big Wave Bay. A second option is to get off at Shau Kei wan station, take bus number 9 to Tei Wan stop along the Shek O road, the hike starts directly opposite the bus stop.Alternatively you can get off at Chai Wan MTR (on the blue Island Line) start your hike directly from outside Chai Wan station, where you will quickly ascend to the start of the Dragons Back through a series of steep steps through a graveyard. The choice really is yours.The Dragons Back really is a fabulous hike, apart from the initial ascent the hike is relatively easy and accessible to most abilities including families. However, do wear a pair of good hiking shoes, take plenty of water and sunscreen as there is limited sun protection at the top. There is a reason that the Dragons Back is HKG's top day hiking trail, the view are fabulous as far as the eye can see from from Tai Long Wan, Tung Lung island, Shek O and Big Wave Bay. Try and choose a clear day if possible to do the hike as the view reaches as far as the outlying islands on clear days. The hike itself is approx 8km in length and should take an average walker stopping for photos 2-3hours. There are no facilities or replenishing stations along the way, so be prepared to stock up in advance at Shau Kei Wan station. The Dragons Back allows you peace and solace in otherwise one of the worlds busiest cities, I would recommend visiting in the week and certainly not on public holiday, if you just want to 'get away from it all'. Once you have seen all the views and taken all the photos you wanted, then you will gently head down onto the Shek O road, where a bus stop is conveniently located at the end. Take Bus 9 again back to Shau Kei Wan MTR where you can head on back into the city.A good note to remember, if you buy an Octopus Card (our equivalent of an Oyster card in the UK) at one of the MRT stations you can pre load it, you can then use this card anywhere that has the Octopus sign, so you can buy your train tickets, bottles of water in MTR stations and your bus tickets on Bus 9. This is really useful and means you have to take little if no cash with you on your hike. The Dragons Back, is a must when in HKG a great morning or afternoon away from the hustle bustle of city life, but short enough so that you have time to return to the twinkling lights of city to experience Hong Kong by night.

Easy-going hike. I would recommend this hike to any nature lover who can spare an afternoon. The trail is well-connected to the public transport, so it is really easy to get there and back. Thanks to the numerous signs and maps along the way and fellow hikers there is no need for a map or GPS devices. The hike takes around 2-2,5 hours with an easy-going pace and several photo-shooting breaks. There are only a few parts where it is a bit steeper, but even children and older people managed it, so this shouldn't keep anybody. In case you can spare a whole day and want a more challenging hike I would recommend the Sai Kung Peninsula Hike, which was (in my opinion) even more fascinating.

Another side of Hong Kong. I love hiking in Hong Kong, and I love the hike along the Dragon's Back. It is very easy to get to the trail head by public bus, or, if you prefer, by taxi.
