(Psst...use Google Maps to know your way around HK by public transportation. It will save you a bundle!)Gorgeous views along the ridge and beautiful scenery the whole way up.

A great healthy walk, with great views. You'll spend quite a few hours doing this hike; add on transportation to and from the urban side to the hike start point and you'll take up a major portion of a day. Quite fun and lots of scenic views. Wouldn't call it a hike but rather a walk as it is mostly flat and should be doable by everyone. The walk takes about 2-3 hours depending on your speed

amazing out of city experience. You can do this trip in half a day. Just a beautiful ridge hike where you can get out of the frenetic cty center and bee in mountains and greenery within an hour. The view of the sea and coast is stunning end ending up on the beach in little SHEK O is treat I didnt expect. Perfect for someone without much time for someone who wants to see the "other side of hk" or the long term traveller just lookin for a pleasant day trip.

First and definitely not the last hike!. Dragon back is definitely my best hike ever (even though its my first ever hike)! Like its name, the hike goes up and down initially, but towards to ends, its more of walking around the hill. Its a hike where you could see where you are heading to and the scenery from the peak, its pretty awesome. You'll get a bird's eye view of Hong Kong, where the different areas are and what's there (like the rich mansions, prisons, and boys home scattered around the different parts of Hong Kong). And the hike ends at Big Wave Beach, and a village there as well. Be sure to check out the Thai food there! The pad thai there is pretty decent and after the long hike (about 4 hours), its even more delicious! Take some time to hang out by the beach too! I'm sure to check it out the next time and surf there (as so the name suggests, its a good place to surf!). Definitely a must go place when you're in Hong Kong! Take a cab down to the start of the mountain, its not so much of a touristry hike, but the cab drivers will surely know where it is. The start of the hike is Shek O!
Great hiking experience, suitable for all ages. The view was good, location accessible and plenty of hikers, both local & foreign, old & young.Take a public bus from the nearest MTR station

Superb. DId the hike,and was completely worth it after doing nothing but city life stuff for an entire week. Public transport in this city is one of the most clean and convenient I have ever seen in my life, and it is really easy to get in and out of the city. The dragons back is a train ride and mini bus ride away from the main city areas. Its not a challenging hike, more fun and relaxing, full of tourists, amazing views completely worth it

Come in winter.... A worthwhile walk around picturesque scenery. Take the number 9 Sheko bus from Shau Kei Wan subway station - it's on Kongkong Island on the line from Central Station. The weather in winter is perfect for a walk here - bring a light jacket and some lunch/water at the top.

Gorgeous views. Did the Dragon's back hike today, it was lovely. We thought we might have to get a taxi from the Shau Kei Wan MRT but walked out at exit A1 (or A2) and found a mini bus that took us straight there. The mini bus leaves when full but we found that it only took about 5 to fill and the first stop it made on its way to Big Wave Beach was at the start of the Dragon back walk. The best part about the mini bus was that it didn't keep stopping everywhere like a regular bus and only cost HK $10 each. The walk itself has beautiful views. The only reason I did not give he walk 5/5 is because it was a little over crowded and if you like a fast pace walk it can get frustrating at times during the first part of the walk as there are many leisurely walkers taking their time. People are happy enough if you ask to pass though. We ended our walk down at Big Wave Beach which was beautiful. Places to eat and buy beachy things. Upon our departure towards Shek O we saw the mini bus again which was going straight back to the MRT so decided to get on that instead of walk to Shek O! Lovely day out :-) We weren't ready for the beach but if I went back I would take some beach things to enjoy a nice afternoon on the beach after the walk!

Excellent break from the city crowd while in Hong Kong. What a relief to be here while you are in Hong Kong. Not strenuous by any means. You can take your own pace. I would have loved if those concrete pavement or stairs are not there instead left as a dirt road. Interesting views open up as you reach the top and along the way. Take a break here out of the city when in Hong Kong.

Best "urban" hike. Very do-able hike along the crest of some mountains on Hong Kong island. The view is spectacular. We took a bus up to the HK prison (sorry, don't remember the bus number) and walked from there. The uphill climb is steady but not difficult. You won't see much among the shrubs, but when you get to the top, the view opens up to ocean, beach, and sky.Come down the other end of the trail at Shek-O beach and grab a lunch at the famous long-time Thai restaurant there. I recommend hiking the trail early in the morning on hot days, when the air is cooler. I did it on a day that turned 98F and 98% humidity without breaking much of a sweat.

Amazing views for a day out. The Dragon's Back is section 8 of the Hong Kong Trail. To get here, take bus number 9 from Shau Kei Wan Bus Terminus. This bus terminus is situated at the Shau Kei Wan MTR station. So just get to the MTR station first.The bus displays the next coming stop. Just get down at the To Tei Wan stop. There are porta loos just before the start if you need to take a leak. The initial climb is hard but not as hard as the climb I had to Qixingshan in Yamingshan National Park from Xiaoyoukeng. After that it is undulating as you walk along the ridge of the "Dragon's Back". After Shek O Peak, it gets boring as you descend towards Big Wave Beach. We started at 12:30pm and ended at 4:45pm on Big Wave Beach with some stops along the way. At Big Wave Beach, bus number 9's frequency gets less and you will most likely be met with a red top minibus for the ride back to Shau Kei Wan. Fee is HKD10 and the driver is very persuasive. He is right though as you will most likely wait 2 hours for the next bus if you came to the bus stop at 5:00pmAs suggested, the best months for any type of hiking in Hong Kong is during the winter months of Dec to Feb. We came in Dec but was fortunate to have clear skies but cold temperatures of 11-15 deg C. It was raining for three days prior.Will be considering Pat Sin Leng. Another great views hike but strenuous on the climb.

Beautiful scenery. Beautiful, perfect for a fit family/friends chilled hike! Would recommend it to tourists who want to leave with a beautiful nature pics of Hong Kong. Hiking fans tip： Personally not a huge fan of the long flat cement road part at the later part of the hike... not a good workout at all, but perfect for bringing your non-hiking friends for a fun day out.
Beautiful scenery. Popular urban walk offer beautiful scenery of Stanley, Tai Tam and Shek O. In some places need clearer sign posts.

A respite from the hustle and bustle. If you've spent a few days in the heart of HK and need to get away for a bit, this is the perfect way to do it. This is a pretty leisurely hike and can be completed easily in 3-4 hours. Make sure you end at the Shek-O side, and then you can go the beach for a quick dip and shower. You can tie in this trek with a visit to Stanley which is nearby.

Nice contrast. After the hustle and bustle of most of Hong Kong, the walk on the Dragon Back trail is a pleasant contrast. Finding the start of the trail by public transport is fine if you follow the instuctions carefully. The start of the walk involves a fairly steep climb but is well worth it for the views which greet you, although they are not particularly photogenic because of the usual cover of mist. The track is well prepared and signposted and takes a solid 2 1/2 to 3 hours to complete. I feel sure that I will revisit the track on my next visit to Hong Kong.
Dragons back Hong Kong. Walked this trail with my daughter. Really enjoyed it great way to spend a few hours. Fantastic views for the top.

Hiking in Hong Kong. Wonderful hiking and beautiful vistas - right in Hong Kong. The trail is well maintained. There are some inclines but basically this is a relatively easy hike for anyone in relatively good shape.

What a gem in Hong Kong. My previous view of HK was the cauldron that is Central, TST and Mong Kok. Surely this is part of the reason why I love HK, but I was surprised to learn that you within striking distance can find tranquility and really beautiful scenery.I went to Dragon's Back by public transport which is a mix of the metro (Shau Kei Wan) and a local bus (#9). As the stops are announced on route in Chinese and English it's simply a matter of knowing which stop to get off at (To Tei Wan stop).From here you can't go wrong.The hike is pleasant and the views really great.

What a Hike!!!. Wow...this was a nice find! My cousin and I unfortunately went in flip flops though, and the ground was not as dry and accommodating. But it was definitely a good workout! The views at the top and along the route were awesome. I would love to try it again, but with shoes this time. Also did not have a chance to walk the entire trail. Wish we had set aside more time. The only hitch was trying to find the entrance. We kind of wandered a bit after exiting the bus, but eventually found it. Well worth it!

Some of the best views in Hong Kong. Went hiking on a weekday morning and had the whole place almost completely to ourselves. Great hike and not difficult at all. Had to navigate a little bit but that added to the fun.

Absolutely stunning and completely unexpected. Stopped in Hong Kong for a quick 4 day trip on the way to Thailand and was unsure what to expect. We were jetlagged and woke up at 5AM - what to do!? We scoured several travel brochures from the hotel lobby and finally found a self guided hike in a small article with obscure bus instructions to get there.... After an hour and 2 busses later... We were finally dropped off at a deserted stop in the middle of nowhere on Hong Kong island. Oh the horror. What have we done!!?? We quickly found the obscure trail beginning and tentatively started the hike. After about 30 minutes we started seeing other people and felt a little more comfortable. I think it was about an hour into the hike when you are hit with this absolutely stunning 360 degree view of sky scrapers, beautiful green mountains, and amazing resort towns. Not at all what I would expect from Hong Kong island. It was so diverse. After we descended on the other side of the mountain, we made our way to a small town right on the beach. We bought a couple of beers and put or feet in the sand on the ocean. Amazing. It was by far my favorite day on the entire Asia trip (HK, Thailand, Tokyo)... You must do it.

great hike; do it with a guide. This is an excellent and moderately-difficult lengthy hike. You'll spend quite a few hours doing this hike; add on transportation to and from the urban side to the hike start point and you'll take up a major portion of a day. Quite fun and lots of scenic views. I recommend doing this with a guide who is knowledgeable about the area and who can embellish your hiking with great stories.

Easy hike with lovely weather. After reading the reviews here, I decided to go for it! In fact I'm in bed with very sore knees and an aching back writing this. After a heavy yum cha lunch, we took the MTR to Shau Kei Wan. From the bus terminal, we hopped onto bus 9 (HKD 6.90) to To Tei Wan. The start of the trail is just right beside the bus stop. To our surprise, there were quite a number of fellow hikers there today, considering its a Tuesday afternoon. The view from the beginning of the hike to the Shek O Peak was breathtaking. It took us about an hour to get there. It's quite a tedious 1 hour though.From the peak, we continued on towards the direction of Tai Tam Gap. It's a much easier hike from here, however the view was almost nonexistence. Towards the end of the trail, we were at a split road (paved road) 1 goes towards Tai Tam Gap and the other Big Wave Bay. We walked towards the latter and arrived at Big Wave Bay in 45 mins. Total distance travelled 8.5km in around 2.5hrs.

An intermediate hike with views!. This is my favourite hike in HK! It's not too demanding, whilst offering some challenging bits that will give you a sense of pride when you finish. I went with my girlfriend and we did the hike where it ended us up at Shek O beach, which is a nice beach to chill out on with a beer after the long hike. There's also a great thai restaurant there that served some delicious food. Overall, great day

Great walk. Wouldn't call it a hike but rather a walk as it is mostly flat and should be doable by everyone. The walk takes about 2-3 hours depending on your speed, it is easily accessible and the views are great. After the walk treat yourself to a great meal at the thai restaurant in Shrek O.

A fantastic little adventure. This was my favorite activity in Hong Kong. I had researched it ahead of time, and found a great blog entry on Lonely Planet that listed several itineraries, each with very specific directions. I highly recommend that you look at this blog if you want to do this hike.I was outvoted, and we chose to go through the cemetery. I had expected a field with some headstones, but instead found an enormous hillside filled with terraces! We followed a ridge line through some amazing scenery, up through some wooded areas with a paved trail, to a peak with ocean on both sides. The entire trail I was on, paved or not, was well maintained and easy to follow. Everyone with an interest in doing so would be able to do at least some of the trail.

I would go to another section of the trek. This is a beautiful trek but there are many other treks that are much more beautiful. The problem with the dragon back section of the Hong Kong trail is that it is the most famous one. During the weekends gets very crowded here. This put a damper on the experience. When you have this scenic landscape and beautiful views you don’t want it to be over crowded.There are other sections of the trek where you will be almost alone and were the views in my opinion is much more beautiful. I have been living in Hong Kong for two years now and been trekking almost every weekend.If you would like to know more about trekking in Hong Kong there is a great book called “The Serious Hiker’s Guide to Hong Kong”. It describes the three major trekking trails in Hong Kong (The Hong Kong Trail, The Wilson Trail and The MacLehouse Trail) with pictures of each section and detailed information about how to get there and the level of the trek. These three treks are also marked on google maps if you would like to do your own research.My personal favorites are the trek in Sai Kung, Tai Long Wan (MacLehouse Stage 2) or on Hong Kong Island the trek around Tai Tam reservoir (Hong Kong Trail stage 5 and 6).

Not for the un-fit. The walk itself has lovely views and is well worth doing but I found it too difficult and had to turn around after about 4 kms. It has lots of steps and in the heat and humidity was just beyond me. We took water with us but it was hot after a very short time. We decided to go back and catch the bus to Shek O beach and have a swim which was very refreshing.

Quick Hike. We checked few websites and were told that the hike ranges from 4-6 hours. I decided to go with someone who had already been on this trail. We started at 8 am on Shek O Beach road starting point and enjoyed the hike, It was nice and easy with few tough climbs. Overall, was nice mix of walk, climb and descent. The views from top were amazing and so was the breeze. We finished the hike in 2 hours and landed in big wave bay beach. Enjoyed the hike.
Fairly difficult but worthwhile. Have done this twice now & enjoyed both times. Best to avoid weekends as it gets very busy and you are forever stopping to let people pass on the narrow path.

Beautiful !. Some people say this trail isn't a difficult walk but for the beginner like me, it's too difficult :) I took about 3 - 4 hours to be there. I was so tired but the scenery was very beautiful. The sea breeze boosted my energy. If you love to trek the trail, do not miss this path. Don't forget to take a rest at Big Wave beach or Shek O beach. It's also a beautiful place.

Good hike with great views.. My wife and I love to hike. This had great views. It ended up taking about 2 hours of hiking for us. We were a bit tired at the end, but much enjoyed it. Ate at a small place at Big Wave bay. Bring enough cash to buy food and taxi/bus out of there because there are no cash machines. Taxi's don't come by often and you will wait a bit (10 - 15 min for us) for the bus. Definitely worth the time.
Tiring but amazing. This takes about 3 hours but the view is amazing and jumping in the sea on arrival at Big Wave Bay is awesome

Beautiful views marred only by the poor air quality. Easily one of the most scenic walks in Hong Kong. Not a difficult walk and thoroughly enjoyable. The only lamentable thing was the poor air quality which affected the otherwise picturesque views.

Unexpected Beauty in Hong Kong. We only discovered this walking trail from reading other Trip Advisor reviews, so thankyou! We started the walk in the middle of the trail, by getting the number 9 bus from Shau Kei Wan to Collision Road (1st stop after the tiny roundabout), and walking up the stairs to the right of the correctional facility. We headed toward Shek O, although you can go to Big Wave Beach as well. The first part of the walk is pretty easy, walking through forest on a well worn path. We turned left after a km or 2 to climb the Dragon's Back. Wow, what an unexpected treat at the top. The view to both The Stanley Peninsula and Big Wave and Shek O is spectacular. Beautiful water, magnificent houses and the most immaculately mown golf course. Obviously where the elite of Hong Kong spend their weekends. We then walked back down to Shek O road.The trail is an easy enough walk for a relatively fit person with a few steep parts. The section we walked was about 5 km and took 1.5 hours walking fairly briskly including stops for photos at the top. Take water, as there is none available near or on the trail. We went on a weekend along with every man and his dog (literally, we saw at least 5 dogs on the trail) and we don't like to meander so if you can avoid weekends I'd do so. After the walk we took a taxi to Shek O beach (also the end of the line for the number 9 bus). It's great for people watching and the beach is beautiful and well kept. There are drop toilets and showers and plenty of places to eat on and around the beach. We ate by the roundabout in a funky burger place sitting next to a Great Dane. As you do :-)

Lifechanging!. As a resident of Boulder, Colorado, I know a thing or two about hiking in the mountains. I hiked Dragon's Back with my 70-year-old mother and a business colleague. It was unforgettable! The views were absolutely stunning - secluded beaches, quaint fishing villages, opulent homes and Shek-O Country Club. There were a few semi-technical areas where the trail was very steep and narrow. We managed to take it slowly and did fine. We completed the trail end-to-end, and managed to catch a taxi to Shek-O for lunch afterward. I would definitely recommend a backpack, a water bottle, hiking shoes, a hiking pole -- and of course, your camera! The photos will make your friends envious! :)

A short, easy hike for beginners.. The Dragon's Back is part of the Hong Kong Trail, Stage 8, and is a quick and easy (approx 1-2 hours) hike, depending on the chosen ingress point (of which there are many). Probably the easiest way is to take a bus to Tai Long Wan (Big Wave Bay) and hike Stage 8 backwards, which will make Shek O Road the egress point from where you could catch a bus back to civilisation. The top of Dragon's Back has some very good views of Stanley Peninsula on one side, and Shek O on the other. It can get very hot there in the middle of summer as there is no shade and no wind, though it does get very windy there in winter. Nevertheless it's a far cry from being one of the better trails in Hong Kong.

A 'Must Do' activity in Hong Kong. Certainly one of the best Hong Kong has to offer! - the Dragon's back! Rather easy hike for anyone who is in reasonably physical condition, and you won't need any special hiking gears/equipment either. I did the hike early Oct …and it was still rather hot (especially on the way up the summit). Do bring a bottle of water & sunscreen will be helpful. And yes.. the view is fantastic when u reach the high range.. However the trail down was quite uneventful.. Total time taken about 3 hours (rested for around 20 mins at the top to enjoy the views..). Finally..took a public bus back to chai wan MTR - a short 20 mins ride.

The other side to Hong Kong. This was a fantastic hike that was a total contrast to the hustle and bustle of the city. The views were fabulous and the walk not too strenuous for the reasonably active.

A good start to hiking in HK. There are many nice hiking trails in HK and Dragon's Back is a good start. Not too strenuous and doesn't take away too much of our time for sightseeing and food hunting. It was really hot when my hubby and I were there in September. Remember to put on a hat and lots of sunblock lotion. Insect repellent is a must too! Lovely views. :) Big Wave Bay was worth the walk. It was interesting to mingle with the locals and people-watch. Treat yourself to a nice, cold drink before taking the minibus back to Shau Kei Wan. In less than half an hour, you will find yourself in town with a totally different crowd.

Great views - easy hike. One of the more scenic hikes we have done. Absolutely stunning views across the South China Sea. Definitely recommend to those who want to get out of the hustle of the city and see a little more of Hong Kong. The guides state this is a six hour hike, but it only took us 2.5hours from the start point to the end point. There are no shops along the way so make sure you bring all of your water, food etc. the starting point is also a little hard to find....recommend watching the screen in the bus for the stop and make sure you get off at "To Tei Wan" we thought the "To" meant the bus was still on its way to Tei wan, we. missed the stop, got off a few stops later and spent an hour trying to find our way back.....rookie mistake....don't do the same :-) nonetheless definitely worthwhile!

An escape from the city madness. I finally got away from the Hong Kong shops to see some nature and wasn't disappointed. A really gradual and easy hike which even in a rainy day gave us impressive views of Hong Kong. Getting there by bus from Central wasn't hard to figure out either.

one of hte best hinkng on the area. Take a nice and easy walk, no need to be super accesorizes as chinese and HKese do, just normal gym shoes and shorts. It is easy and you have a beautiful view on the bay in front. You can go down unti larrive to Big Wave beach. Takes around 3 h if you take it easy, stop for pictures, to breath the air etc...etc... TO do when is not too hot

Easy hike with lovely voews. We did only a part of the hike. It was easy, with routes well marked and all the paths were clean and comfortable. Please pick up fruits and water before you get to the starting point (preferably, before you board the minibus). Our hike ended at the Big Wave Beach, which was a great beach. Depending on which portion you do, the hike can take you anywhere between 1 hr to 2.5 hours.The views were lovely, especially from a few viewing points. They would have been even better had the day been nice and clear. If you have time at hand, and are tired of man made buildings in HK, this is a good getaway.

Amazing Hike. My hike through Dragon's Back trail was the highlight of my stay in Hong Kong and one of the best hikes I've done to date. The trail is beautiful and provides a moment of peace away from the city. It takes about 2-3 hours to hike depending on how many photo/rest breaks you take in between. Once you've reached the peak, the views are breathtaking and well worth the sweat and fatigue endured - take a moment to take it all in, however, please pay attention to the trail signs. .I ended my hike at Big Wave Bay Beach... stunning to say the least. I never knew Hong Kong provided such beauty.Check out my blog post for photos!http://www.vagabondingheights.com/2013/10/a-new-discovery-new-experience-hong.html

Make sure you do the right track. I did the wrong track which led to the beach it was nothing special, will go and do the right track next time. Caught a bus back to Central, was cheaper than the train. The beach was nice

Easy, short hike with a stunning view. Easy to teach by bus from MTR Shaukeiwan (10min busride with bus 9, stop at the wooden sign, right after the roundabout).Quite an easy hike of 2hours with stunning viewsYou can finish the hike with a swim or lovely stay at the beach

Make sure you know where you're going. Our experience was somewhat tarnished by my inadequate preparation. I had decided to end at Shek O but didn't know where to start. I failed to get clarification from the hotel concierge and ended up searching the internet for directions. Those I got were from a committed hiker whereas we were more of a country stroll group. We took the MTR to the end of the line and then set off. That was our big mistake. We should have taken the bus or grabbed a cab up to the country park entrance instead of wasting our energy walking up there. Once we reached the top the views were, as reviewed, stunning but my second warning is to be prepared for the exposure. Carry plenty water and I recommend a wide brimmed hat. Once on the ridge you are fully exposed to the sun and as pale skinned Westerners we found it fierce.

Great hike. Starting from To Tei Wan, the hike to Big Wave took about 3.5 hours with some breaks in between. It was a leisurely hike, but the steep uphill can be quite a walk. View was totally worth it! Would walk again some day!
Great trail. A great trail really. Been here a few times. Some ups and downs. Great views both ways, both sides. Takes around 2 hrs. An easy/average trail to enjoy scenery and get a mild workout!

Great Hiking Experience!. The Dragon's Back Hike was amazing. One of the best hikes I've ever done... It has tons of stairs, but the views are SO breathtaking that every step is worth it. We decided to end our hike at the Big Wave Bay, and the beach was great.. Perfect activity for active people who want to get away from the fast pace of Hong Kong!

Best Hike in Hong Kong. Great views, well maintained track. Though needs to be done on dry day as though the track is well maintained it is largely just dirt. From a starting point of Shek 'O road to Big wave beach it is ~9Km, the first 4km is fairly difficult but the final 5kms very easy. Big waive beach is very nice, so bring your swimmers! (every time you come to an intersection on the track turn right - to get to big wave beach)Catch the MTR to Shau Kei Wan, then the no.9 bus from outside the terminal, You will need to tell the bus driver where you want to go, otherwise it will be very easy to miss the stop. Alternatively catch a cab from the MTR, would cost less then 10 USD.From the Big Wave beach you can catch a mini bus that goes straight to Shau Kei Wan MTR for $1 USD. The clearer/dryer the day the more you will enjoy this trip. There are no shops between MTR and Big wave beach, so bring plenty of water.

Easy but satisfying stroll close to Hong Kong - great views. I was working in Hong Kong and wanted to be an intrepid explorer at the weekends and found this in a tour guide. It was great! Easy peasy to get to using the MTR Island Line and the bus (number 9). HK buses have the next station in English and Cantonese and as it turns out on a Sunday afternoon LOTS of people do this walk so it was easy to know when to leave the bus. It took only about 1.5 hours to do the trek and then you can walk down a road to Shek O beach but that looked a bit dull so I caught a bus. The beach was pretty and again super easy to get the bus and MTR back. Highly recommend this as an alternative to the hustle and bustle of downtown Hong Kong - definitely blows the cobwebs away.

Great hike. We loved this hike. It took around 3 hrs and was incredibly rewarding to go for a swim at Shek-O afterwards (catch a #9 bus or local shuttle there). The views at Shek-O Peak are spectacular, it is so serene up there. Lunch at Shek-O was delish - Happy Garden Thai. Amazing vegetarian dishes.
Nothing special. It's just a small mountain that has a road to hike on top. The climb is lackluster for those seeking a challenge.

Morning walk with stunning panoramic views of coastline. Remember to take drinks and there are waterfalls to dip your toes in if you need to cool off. Will take about 45 mins but can be done at a leisurely stroll; look out for beautiful butterflies. Wear strong shoes - not flip-flops because of roots and rocks. Well worth the effort.
Fantastic Views. The hike can be somewhat grueling at times given Hong Kong's heat and humidity, but the views along the trail are spectacular. Be sure to end your trip at Big Wave bay to cool off!

great bay views. Although it takes about an hour to get there by mtr & bus the views and beauty of the trail make it worth it. Beware, once you reach the top of the mountains turn back! My wife and i thought there was more and continued for another 2 hours going forward to Shek O beach. There is a much closer beach if you turn around and take the bus.

Great Half Day Trip. The Dragon's Back trip has certainly been a highlight of our trip so far. Easy to get to, just take the MTR to Shau Kei Wan, go to the bus terminus, take the no.9 bus and ask the driver which stop you need to get off on to start the hike. Take lots of water! Beautiful views, a nice and easy hike. Also recommend going for a swim in the sea afterwards. We went to Shek O beach which is the last stop on the no.9 bus.
Great walk. Fantastic views. Don't do it when it's raining and it's pretty slippy. Go to shek-o at the end, lovely village and beach

best trekking day in HK. I found some information about this trekking in a book. It was not very clear how to arrive there but that made the trekking day more interesting. I started in a small round about where I was suppose to get off the bus. 5 minutes later I arrived to the women prision so I knew I was in the right spot. There is not too many people so you can just enjoy the nature. After a couple hours you arrive to the Dragons Back (you will see a sign) where the view is spectacular. I made my way down to the Shek O village by bus (dont walk along the road... there is nothing else to see) where I could enjoy a quick swim in the beach, eat nice and relatively cheap seafood. Also they have some kind of cliffs over there that you totally need to see. 100% recommended.

Beautiful time. Hong Kong Island, it is only skyscrapers. No it isn´t true because there are beautiful green walk area. Dragon´s back is one of them and for me it is charming trip through peaks hills which they make up undulating way with beautiful view of surroundings. This way leads from East of Island to Big Wave Bay which is the paradise for surfers. For land animal as me there is cook excellent noodle with vegetables. Petra Bačovská

Best Hike on the HK Island. If you wanted a 2-3 hour that is not so strenuous, something that you can easily travel to, doesn't need real mountain boots and a hiking pole, I'd recommend the dragons back. I started my hike from To Tei Wan, where I have got off from the Sau Kei Wan Metro station and took bus no 9. Don't worry about not knowing when to get off, you can either talk to the driver, other passengers or just look at the sign board for the correct stop. After getting off from To Tei Wan, you'll automatically see the sign boards with a map, and I just followed the route crossing the dragon's back and reach Big Wave Bay. This entire section is around 10 km long and I think the maximum elevation is not beyond 300m. If you go on a clear day, you'll see the entire southern part of Hong Kong island which is gorgeous.Best of all, when we finish the hike, we landed on a beach and took brunch at the beach side cafe. They serve pretty authentic continental all day breakfast, international snacks and cold beer!!!

Amazing hike. An amazing hiking trail just a little bit outside of the city with some real fantastic view points. The hike is perfect for an half day trip and the rest of the day u can spend and the very relaxed bay of Shek O

It's free and beautiful. What a fantastic couple of hours. Great views and good exercise. Lots of birdcall and watched a long column of ants cross the path. Stayed for 5 minutes and didn't see beginning or end of column. You can see what turns on David Attenborough. Finished at Shek O beach for a swim and a well earned beer

Magnificent view. Dragon's Back is one of the easiest hiking trails in Hong Kong with the Magnificent view of the South central and Eastern view of Hong Kong Island. Recommendation just at the end of the ridge when the trail turns down to the Shek-O road, go further on the un-trodden path. You'll find a huge rock on the hillside where you can get the best view of the whole trail as well as Shek-O.

Ideal walk for the tourist. I've walked Dragon's Back many time, living in Hong Kong but I've also taken many a visiting friend on this reasonably easy hike. There are a few steep section s but nothing that a reasonable fit person can't tackle. Start at the Correctional Centre on Shek O road. After a while walking on the flat you'll come out into the first of many amazing views.Once we walked in the late afternoon and had the phenomenal sight of the sun setting on one side of the Dragon's Back and the moon rising on the other. Probably good to have a torch with you for the descent if you leave it too late! The wind on the crest can be fierce at times but oh those views!!! Both sides of the back you can see the beauty of Hong Kong, something that few tourists ever get to see. It's a wonderful place to be when you're up in the hills but most visitors miss it unless they know a resident who likes walking.You can end up either on the Shek O road or on Tai Long Wan Beach. If you choose to descend to Shek O Road you can catch a bus down into Shek O village and have a well earned beer and excellent seafood at the restaurant by the roundabout. Check out Shek O beach too.Buses and taxis back can be difficult at peak periods and the weekend so try to time your visit "off peak"

Beautiful scenery and a satisfying walk! Another side of HK.. The coastline and islands around Hong Kong are surprisingly beautiful, and this is a relatively easy walk which shows this beauty. Take water, a hat, your Octopus card, and wear decent shoes. We took the MTR to Shau Kei Wan. We took exit A3 from the station and walked across to the nearby bus terminal, and then took the number 9 bus toward Skek O. We had to ask when to get off along Shek O Road to find the start of the trail (it is the first stop on Shek O Road). The trail is well sign posted, and fairly easy walking with a bit of steeper sections. The views along the walk are wonderful! We did the walk on a hot and humid summer day, and sweated a lot. At the end of the trail we caught a number 9 bus into Shek O for a dip in the sea, some lovely cold beer and Thai food. A great afternoon! Only downside was seeing the water bottles, orange peels and tissues/toilet paper left along the trail by others. Take your litter with you!

Great walk, but not for a summers days. If you're looking for the natural side of Hong Kong or you just have the need to stretch your legs - please make sure you give the Dragon's Back a good walking over. It's an easy walk that takes in some good sights by HK standards. If you're staying in HK for 4 or 5 days this is the perfect rest away from the hive of activity down on the streets. Worth a look, but only if you have the time and not in the middle of a hot summers day.
Walking the Dragon. Beautiful walk. Great Thai restaurant in Shek O. Nice deck chairs on Big Wave Bay and good coffee at the café.
Outstanding views. Great views, but try to avoid the 5/6pm rush out of the beach. It can take a while to catch bus or taxi.

Great walk. A great 3 hour hike, a bit steep & slippery, well worth it. Follow the Luxe instructions to access starting at the Corrections Centre - our taxi driver wanted to take us too far. Take your Octopus card & allow time to explore Shek O beach & Village before returning.

Amazing views and tranquility so close to Central HK!. The Dragons back is a glorious walk- strenuous enough to make you feel like you've done some exercise but enjoyable for the whole family. The gorgeous views of the crystal blue seas and golden beaches on either side of the ridge are what keep you marveling and heading upwards. On a sunny day you can see for miles and it looks like you're in Hawaii!It's really easy to get to as well. MTR to Shau Kei Wan (Island line) then once out of the MTR head to the bus depot right beside and get the number 9. Get some water before you get on the bus because there are no shops to buy water until the end of the walk. The bus will climb uphill and once it gets past all the buildings it will head into forests. Keep an eye out, You will go past a tiny roundabout and you get off right after this. The bus takes about 10 minutes. Next to the stop are some steps heading up the hill, well signposted to the Dragons back. (The steps are on the same side you get off the bus next to Tai Tam gap correctional facility.) The walk takes between 1- 1.5 hours, depending on how often you stop to take photos! Well maintained steps and paths.It's well worth heading down to the Shek O road and taking a very short bus ride to Shek O village. Amazing Thai seafood restaurant - no.303 as you come into village on the left- and beautiful clean beach with showers as a reward for your efforts. Then you can catch the bus straight back to Shau Kei Wan.

Visitors & locals alike must do!. The view when you get to the top of the ridge is truly rewarding. When you get to the end the Thai restaurant is always serving freshly chilled lime sodas and tasty food! A refreshing escape from the concrete jungle and nearly every fitness level and age can participate.
Great scenery. Easy hike, even with baby!. The scenery was gorgeous. My sister had her 1 year old son on her back and it was fine. You overlook the beaches, over the rolling hills.

BEAUTIFUL!. The sights along the mountain are beautiful..It took about half an hour to climb from the busstop to dragon's back and about half an hour to complete it. It isnt tough but mind you, the route is really like a dragon's back (rocky and 'scaley' and the sight up there is worth it. You can see the different islands from most of the points on the back. It took about an hour or so to walk down to the other exit from the back and we were treated to small waterfalls that were along the path back. Bring some snacks so you can have them after the climb while waiting for bus 9 to bring you back to civilisation.
Stunning views. Nice walking trail, the views are well worth the walk, gets quite busy on weekends. Still beautiful and fairly quiet considering it's in HK.

Brilliant walk - do it!. We did this walk "the other way" - starting at the walk from Chai Wan and walking to Shek-O. I liked the walk up through the Graveyard at Chain Wan, and then the first perhaps third of the trail is nothing spectacular - you get the occasional view through the tress and can appreciate the views. However, as the trial progresses, the views open up and become really stunning. Well worth doing, and would do it again. Takes around 2.5 - 3.5 hrs or so with some breaks.

Excellent hike. The views are really nice along the hike, and one would meet plenty of friendly people escaping from the urban sprawl that is Hong Kong, including a group of housewives enjoying Alan Tam songs being blasted from their CD player! Be warned though that toilets are scarce along the hike, so be prepared to take a short detour into the forest to relieve yourself.

Even our local relatives were asking how we knew about this!. Allocate at least half a day out. Bring enough food and water, sunscreen, hat, and the usual hiking gear - be prepared for all types of weather up there on the mountain! For us it was humid, and sunny, and then overcast, and a little windy, with a few mud pools on the track. Toilets are only available once you come back down the mountain.But definitely worth a visit for the spectacular views over Tai Tam Bay and the other side over Shek O!Keep an eye out for the various native flora, and insects (beetles, bugs, butterflies, ants), and mini waterfalls.The signs say the trail is open for mountain biking (and we saw a group), but as a mountain biker myself, it would be hard going up some of those pinch climbs... They were pushing their bikes up.We ended up just doing the Dragon's Back trail (since we had dad accompany us) and took it at an easy pace of 2.5 hours, resting when there was a bench available. Next time we'll do the full trail, onwards to Shek O. This trip, we finished halfway after coming back down the mountain, and catching the same bus back on Shek O Road.

Great if you love hiking, mountains and scenery.. It is fairly easy to reach Dragon's back. Take the island line to Shau Kei Wan station, exit to the bus terminal and take bus no. 9, stopping at To Tei Wan stop. Once you alight, you wouldn't miss the sign that says Dragon's Back. It is a "medium" level hike with some steep steps and uneven sandy paths here and there but it is really not that difficult. It is very rewarding once you reach the top with the stunning views of the mountains and seas. Remember to bring lots of water if you are hiking in the summer as the heat can really gets onto you. My journey started from Central Station to Shau Kei Wan which took me about 20 minutes and the bus journey was another 20-30 minutes depending on traffic condition as the roads are mainly single lane. As i didn't bring enough water, i couldn't carry on further towards the Hong Kong Trail and another continuing trail once i reach the top. The Dragon's back is just about 1 kilometers and 283 meters in height. In all, it took me about an hour going up and exiting down to the base. I would definitely go back again and continue my hike with the continuing trails the next time. If you are planning on completing the trails, do allocate more time and be sufficient with water and food etc.

Stunning!...Run or trail walk of a lifetime. Check out Shek'O Beach afterwards.. Running the Dragon's Back in Hong Kong turned out to be our very favorite thing we did on that trip. We went to Macau and Lan Tau too, but we really loved this experience the best. We are avid runners and love exploring new places in the elements, and not much for guided tours. If you feel the same about your travel then you will love this trail. Just spectacular views and at parts of the trail slightly challenging of a run. I think it took about 2hours, mainly because we stopped at various photo ops. Afterwards we hopped in a cab (but there are buses too) and headed down to Shek'O Beach. Shek'O is a delightful beach town right below the Dragon's Back. There are many cafes and bars on the water, it is a great little town. By train this area of Hong Kong is about an hour from the city. We loved this town so much if we ever go back to Hong Kong we would prefer to stay in Shek'O than in the city.

Brilliant. A simply fantastic hike in Hong Kong. I took my two boys (4 and 3 years) on it the other day and they loved it. Starts flat through the trees with good shelter from the Sun. They a series of humps and climbs with breath taking views over Big Wave Bay and Shek'O. You normally get a nice breeze at the top and on the way up.On the way down can be a little tricky if it's been raining but in general a nice walk that will get the pulse going. Takes about 2 hours. A bus stop at the end can take you into Shek'O for a well earned beer and Thai.

Most popular trail on HK island. This is a beautiful walk with Tai O beach on one side and view of Red Hill peninsula on the other. It's a beautiful trail, not too hard and not too easy. Definitely a must try if you're in HK.

Greta Hike, great beach, great thai restraunt!. Hike takes 90 mins or so, is not too strenuous and you can recoup on the beach plus wash it all down with an incredible thai - v. close to the car park near the main beach

Dragon's Back is a must do in HK. This was a fantastic hike. Take a taxi out to the start of the walk and take your time enjoying some magnificent views. The walk itself is steep in some parts but relatively easy and anyone can do it. There are a lot of walkers along the path so be patient but it's definitely worth the visit.

The other side of HK. A good way to escape from the crowd, traffic and buildings of HK, and get yourself in an almost solitary path in the middle of the nature. The hike is quite easy, about 8km. During the hike you can see the beaches and shores of Stanley, Shek O and Big wave and some small island. Unfortunately when we took the hike there was a mist and we could get only a glimpse of the beautiful landscapes.

Very enjoyable trail hike. I read about this trail in an in-flight magazine on my way into Hong Kong and thought it sounded like a great hike.There are a bunch of websites that feature this trail but some of them are a bit confusing and a couple make it out to be a tough hike. It really isn't: there are a few relatively steep sections, and if it's been raining recently some sections are a bit muddy, but I saw one couple hiking in flip-flops and there were some pretty young kids too, so it's definitely do-able for most people. The best trail map is on the Discover Hong Kong website.One nice feature of the trail is that it breaks into a number of sections, and you can potentially bail out (or start) at any of these points. One website puts the trail length at 8.5km but I don't think it can be that long as I did it in under two-and-a-half hours. The trail starts at To Tei Wan towards the southern tip of Hong Kong island. You get to the trail head by taking the MTR to Shau Kei Wan and then a number 9 bus from there. The bus journey is maybe 10-15 minutes, and you need to watch out for the stop as it's pretty easy to miss (or ask the driver to tell you where to get off). You start by walking up steps cut into the hillside, eventually reaching Shek O Peak which is 284m above sea-level and about a quarter of the way along the trail. Along the way there are some nice views both East (over Shek O Village) and West. Some of this section runs through forest so it's dappled shade, but much is exposed so if you are fair-skinned bring a hat & sun-cream.After Shek O Peak the trail levels out a bit, though there's still some up-and-down, and more of it is through the forest. You then start to descend and some of this section is quite steep and can be slippery if it's been raining. There were a lot of butterflies and I could hear birdsong though I failed to spot any of the birds. Eventually you will come to Tai Tam Gap which is your first potential bug-out point. You're about 60% of the way around the trail so it's a good place to evaluate how you're feeling. If you choose to continue, the next section's a bit disappointing because it's a concrete road, though there are some tantalizing glimpses of a hillside cemetery through the trees in places. Don't worry though, it's a short section! It ends at Pottinger Gap (Ma Tong Au), another potential bug-out point if you're too weary to continue. Some people start the trail here and work it backwards down to To Tei Wan (see one review of this approach at Roz's Hiking Pages, for example). The final section is about another 2km and is all down-hill -- sometimes quite steep steps cut into the hillside -- leading to Big Wave Bay. It's pretty much entirely through forest, and so there's not much view plus you have to spend some concentration avoiding tree roots etc.... but I think it's rewarding to have done the whole thing and the Bay at the bottom is nice.There are a few places to eat & drink at the Beach which is very close to the end of the trail but this is really your first opportunity for water anywhere along the trail so it's quite sensible to take something with you on the hike.At Big Wave Beach there are supposed to be some pre-historic rock carvings but I didn't want to do any more walking by that time...... From here you can get back to Shau Kei Wan MTR via the number 9 bus or various little minibuses all of which leave from the road leading down to the beach.
Spectacular. Nothing better than a 3 hour walk across the dragon's back finishing with a couple of beers and some Thai Food at Shek O to finish off...

Great Hike - Easy to Get To. I used the route and map from the HKTB site http://www.discoverhongkong.com/eng/see-do/great-outdoors/hikes/dragons-back-hiking-tour.jsp Taking the bus was easy since stops are announced and displayed. The dragons back section is the best for the scenery. The remainder is not very scenic since you are walking surrounded by tall bushes. The section to Big Wave Bay is paved road for the first half and all downhill (do the reverse route if you want more of a workout). At Big Wave Bay, there is a path up the hill on the far side but this leads back to Cap Collinson. I took a red minibus from Big Wave Bay back to Shau Kei Wan for 10 HKD (no Octopus for red minibuses).

A Great Get Away from the City. Only a short subway ride and a world away. Great hiking and the views are spectacular! End your trek at Shek O for a meal and a much deserved drink. Highly recommended.

Easy walk beautiful views. Great way to spend a few hours. Joined the trail somewhere on the way to Shek O and had a leisurely walk into Big wave bay. Lots of places to stop and take some great pics. The para gliders floating above you and taking off from the ridge make for some great viewing.

Best thing to do in HK. The best hike in HK (short and not too difficult but amazing views- yet gives a bit of exercise) never has any crowds. You can take bus to the start and end points or try to get a cab when you can. I really advise ANYONE in HK (visitors or residents) to try this hike if you have never hiked in HK. It will show how HK is not all concrete and skyscrapers.

Pleasant hike. Take the #40 local bus from Causeway Bay (just off Hennessy Road) for 10HK$ to the Shek O stop. The trail is very well indicated and well maintained, so almost impossible to get lost. The first mile or so is steeply uphill on steps, then the trail opens out and meanders up and down until you get to the ridge. If it is sunny the views stretch far east and west, which makes the effort worthwhile. Most days there is mist or low cloud which somewhat spils the view, but if you are interested in circling birds of prey, paragliders or just a good walk away from the hustle and bustle of the city the walk is very enjoyable. It is not a tough walk, but decent shoes do help, especially if you do the whole walk all the way round to Big Wave Bay. The descent to BWB is slippy if it has rained, so sandals are out. Take the local bus back to Shau Kei Wan MTR for 10HK$.

Great Walk Despite the Mist. A rewarding and not too difficult walk on Hong Kong Island over some flat and averagely steep climbs. Well-maintained pathway over the complete length. Easily walkable in 2 or 3 hours. I imagine it would afford splendid views but alas the mist made sure that we did not see too far ahead of us. Tea in the Shining Stone in Shek O Village at the end of the walk soothed all wear and tear.

6 hour hike in 3 hours. The hike is actually quite easy. The first 3K is mostly up hill, but then you follow the Dragon's back meandering up and down and eventually down to the beach.It took only 3 hours because I was not that interested in the flora and what not and mostly did it for excercise. Access to the start is very easy and there is public transportation from the park to an MTR station.

A "not so strenuous" hike to enjoy gorgeous views. If you aren't familiar with the area, the Dragon's back trailhead may be hard to find, but once you find it, it's quite easy.Parts are shaded (the lower part) and on the dragon's back itself it is quite sunny, so beware if it's a sweltering day. Wonderful views of the South Eastern part of HK island with a great village of Shek O to visit for a post hike lunch or beer!

Favorite activity in Hong Kong. Start of Tai Tam road and finish at the Shek O end so you can have lunch at the Thai Chinese Restaurant. Not super challenging and the view is amazing. On a clear day look for the top of the ICC visible behind you.

If you only walk one trail in HK make it this one. Very easy going (but take sensible footwear if its been raining as it can be quite muddy and slippery). Great views and Shek O is a lovely village to wind up for lunch/drinks afterwards.

Even though it was very foggy...... Even though it was very foggy on the day we went and had no views, it was still a great walk. It was quite peace full and serene. There is no place to buy drinks or food. Make sure you bring what you need. You will find benches and pavilions to rest and enjoy the view on a clear day.To get there take bus 9 to To Tai Wan Village on Shek O Road. You will see a hiking map right next to the bus stop and know that that is the right place.Across the street from the Dragon Hill Hike entrance you will find stairs leading down to To Tai Wan Village (return trip about 2.5 km). It is just a few buildings with a private marina (no restaurants that we could see), but a nice place to spend a little time listening to the waves.

Fabulous views and would do it again.. This walk is for experienced walkers and the young/fit. The views are well worth the effort and we would do it again. We are in our late 50s early 60s and experienced walkers. We saw young families on our walk and dogs. It gives you a unique view of Hong Kong and is easily accessed by the Shek O bus.

Asia's best urban hike. I have taken every visitor on this hike. You can easily do it in a leisurely 3 hours, it provides amazing views, ends on my favorite beach on the island (Big Wave Bay) and you can end the hike with some Thai sea food at Shek'O. And the hike is not very strenuous at all.

great walk, good to get out of the city, great views. great walk, good to get out of the city, great views, good to get out do something healthy in hong kong for a change to take a break from drinking too much, eating too much, and going to wan chai too muchnice break from the hustle bustle
Dragon's Back. Went on a weekend morning. Did a 8km hike at dragons back; lovely scenery, weather. Overall, enjoyable. However, I feel that Mclehose trail at sai Kung was better!
Did the hike with our 2 & 3 year old.. Great views, not too hard if you plan it right and you can take a mini-bus to Shek-O after the hike to get some super tasty Thai food and hit the beach.
Easy to hike, amazing views. Great hike, very easy to walk. Awesome views. You can finish your walk at one of the beaches nearby and take a bus back to a MTR station.

Get ready for a "bumpy" ride/walk. Some truly amazing views from above. Make sure you know where you're going though, we followed a friend who had gone many times before. True to it's name, it's very up and down at times and quite a long walk so take comfortable shoes that don't slip on rocks, water and plenty of sunscreen. We ended up at one of the lovely beaches nearby to relax and recuperate from the hike. Overall, very glad we did it and especially glad we took the bus back at the end :)

nice view. Great place for hikers- beginners, not too hard to walk all of it but have amazing views of hk and can see how it looks, suggest to choose not too hot day for it, there are some peaks to reach and bring water and comfy sport shoes, to have a nice hike!

A little known gem in Hong Kong. This hike is billed as one of the top 10 urban hikes in Asia, and for good reason. From our hotel on Hong Kong island to the jump off point for the hike took us less than 50 minutes by public transport, so it gives you an idea of how accessible it is. Yet once you start the walk, it is not hard to imagine yourself anywhere but in Hong Kong, with fantastic views over bays and headlands, and a well marked pathway. We were there on a weekday, so it was secluded but I can imagine it probably gets crowded at the weekend. Although the hike is billed as moderately difficult, anyone can do it, its only a question of how long you take. The stairs at the beginning are probably the hardest part, but well worth the view once you reach Shek O peak. Thereafter, the hike is relatively flat and easy, up to the last bit, which is the way down to Big Wave Bay where there are more stairs.Bus number 9 from Shau Kei Wan MTR station takes you directly to the start of the hike, and hopping on a light public bus (HKD10) out from Big Wave Bay is probably the best way out back to Shau Kei Wan MTR. Total time for the walk at a leisurely pace was about 3 hours.

Great walk!. We took a taxi to the start of the walk on the road to Shek O, then walked to the car park near Big Wave Bay, where we were lucky enough to find a taxi to take us back. It would be possible by public transport, but taxis are more convenient! You need to be reasonably fit to do this section of the Hong Kong Trail. It goes up and along a ridge with great views of Shek O, then there is a long flat section before you descend to Big Wave Bay.

A must do !!. If you are in Hong Kong for no matter what reason, this hike is a must do. its breathtaking views will make you say "wow". The hike itself is not hard at all, maybe two hours of walking max. recommended for all ages.

wonderful view at the top. it is a relatively easy hike by Hong Kong's standard. but i found the steps at the beginning of hike rather steep and tiring. a really slow walk will take you up to the top in 45 minutes. all is forgotten as the view is breathtaking. bring sunglasses and hats as there are very little shade. journey back down can be difficult as small pebbles and stones makes it difficult to climb down the slopes.

Dragon's Back. We really had a good hike at Dragon's Back. It's a good hike with not too many steps. There are slopes , some steeps, some not and some narrow, but it's all pretty comfortable. We stopped a number of times, more than others. Enjoying bird-eye views and the cooling winds is all worth the climb. We went on a sunday, it wasn't crowded but you see people, many with young children and many groups of seniors too. there are some joggers too. No food or drinks sold, but it's good. the place is clean. Toilets are available, quite clean but still smells though. we spent more than 3 hrs taking our own sweet time.

Off the beaten track!. Martin was a great guide and am glad I took this hike... have been to HK a few times but this was very different from the usual night markets etc.. It was wet in December but still enjoyed it.. also, did not have time to head down to nearby Stanely so try to make a trip there if you can.

challenging hike for cool months. great hike on HK island but you cxould be miles from a city. Little known to the occasional visitor are the wonderful and often unique hiking trails linking the parts of HK and NT that are not often visited.

Must do iff you like hiking. Just take the time and do it. We went from around Regalia to Big wave beach. Takes quite a while but worth it. Great view. Goood pathes. You don't need to be a professional hiker to do it. Make sure you have water with you.
Good. Very good place "the Dragon's Bac" which is pretty easy to hike and convenient to reach but it is t a little crowded on weekend and hoilday.

Beautiful walk on HK Island. Beautiful walk on Hong Kong Island. A short distance away from the hustle and bustle of downtown Hong Kong, this walk is one of the many escapes that HK Island has to offer. Nice vistas over the bays of Island East and treat yourself to some beach time in Shek O after the walk or some nice Thai food in the village of Shek O.

What a great way to see this part of the island. I was completely not expecting to enjoy this walk as much as I did! It goes along a ridge of hills past some great vistas and above a posh golf course with private houses. Then down into Stanley for a refreshing pint at the British pub!!

Challenge Yourself!. Out of the hustle and bustle of Hong Kong are some beautiful mountains and Dragons Back is one of the best! Best to climb on a clear day and take a few water bottles with you as surprising 7-11 hasn't managed to add a location there :)A very enjoyable climb!

Dragon's Back. great walk, get there early and see the sun rise. beware, it get windy up there at the peak, however the walk down to Big Surf Bay is fantastic, beach cafe does the best chicken burger and beer
Fun hike. Had done this 15 years ago, great views of the eastern side of the island. Have lunch in Shek O after

Nice Hiking with amazing view. beautiful location close to Shek O, from the top a great view of big wave bay.the trail is not too hard family can make it with no problem in about 2h with no rush taking some time for pics.

Beatiful trek. This was an beautiful trek. Had my parents with me and they said that it was the best walking tour they have ever tried. A good trail to walk to get an overview of the southern parts of Hong Kong

Very nice treking. Not hard. Hi!I just arrived from the Dragon's Back trail. Awesome to see a different HongKong.To get there first you need to pick the Island Line, go alight in Shau Kei Wan and then take a bus (number nine) and alight in To Tei Wan. Very easy to ger there.It is a very simple track, but with a delightful views.
Worth the climb!. It took some encouragement to get up the hill, but the view was awesome and the reward of the beach at Shek O was great.
beautiful ocean view. steep walking trail but worth the hike to see the beaches on the south side of the HK island. Have more sunscreen before the hike as there will not be any cover from the sun.

Sunday Hike. If you love hiking Hong Kong you must eventually tackle Dragon's Back. The views from the top are wonderful. It is quite steep in parts both up and down. Even for the average fitness person it is achievable.

awesome place for some hiking!. really love the easy walk/hike and the great view that awaits once you have made it to the top. weather was great in jan and this helped in making the overall experience in hong kong so much more better!

Beautiful views towards the ocean. A small walk up to reach the top of the moutain, where you will have magnificent views above Shek-O and Big Wave bay. After going back down a bit, you will have a nice flat walk in the forrest. After a path on a road closed to vehicles, there is a beautiful way down in the forrest to reach Big Wave Bay.i did it once in 90 minutes but it usually takes 2 hours. If you walk slowly, it may take 165 minutes as advertised : it happened to me once on a very hot day with kids. Do not forget to take enough water (small bottle per person is a minimum, not really enough in the summer), there is none on the whole way.Depart from bus stop To Tei Wan village on Shek-O road, if you do not have time for the way down to Big Wave Bay, you may join the road back at Lai Chi rehabilitation center.
Great Hike. Full of great views, the Dragon's Back is pretty easy to hike and convenient to reach. Path can get a little crowded even on a weekday morning though.

No need to take a tour for The Dragons Back.. Take the MTR to Shau Kei Wan Station then Exit A3 brings you to the bus terminal. Take bus 9 to To Tei Wan, on Shek O Road, just keep an eye out for the sign... or just follow the tourist flock! It takes around 20min.There is a seedy port-a-loo at the start of the trail and another ½ way along, so make sure you empty your bladder at the MTR station before you head off as the next clean one is at the end of the hike!Be sure to follow the signs for the “Hong Kong Trail” as there is an alternate route around the dragons back, less steps but not as nice of a view.Its a great hike for everyone! We passed children and even an old woman on a walking stick, mind you she was doing better than some people we passed.If you found this helpful, hit the “YES” button below!
Excellent Hike. Take a little excursion out of the hustle and bustle of the city and enjoy the view from this great hike where the best views are on the first half of the hike.

Brilliant!. Highly recommend this hike. Isn't too hard, but there are lots of steps at the beginning. Went on Christmas Eve & the weather was perfect & we only passed about 10 people. I recommend getting a red mini bus up to the hike, they park in the bus terminus. Make sure you say you want to go to Dragon's Back though! Very helpful & friendly - cost $7.
Lovely walk along the ridgeline of SW HK. Get away from the hoards, start at Big Wave Bay and walk to To Tei Wan Village and home to Hong Kong's Hobie Cat Club.

Achievement. This is a beautiful walk and I highly recommend it to the adventurous, the curious and the nimble.Firstly, catch the MTR to SHAU KEI WAN on The Island Line (Blue). From here to go EXIT A3, up the stairs you'll come to Street Level and there is an open bus terminal there. Walk to the far end and catch BUS 9. It runs to Shek O but you will want to get off at Stop 12 - TO TEI WAN (there is an electronic sign with all the stops in English and Chinese so you won't miss it). Cost is approx. $7HKD. Once you leave the bus, the hike trail begins at your feet. Commence walking through the bamboo forest almost vertically for the next ten-fifteen minutes. You are now on the Dragon Back Trail, so take your time and enjoy every moment. About fifteen minutes into your walk you will come across a Wooden Building with sign posts directing you to either TAI TAM GAP/HONG KONG TRAIL/SHEK O - pay attention to this and turn off your current pathway and walk to the RIGHT past the Wooden Building/Picnic Stop and go on the HONG KONG TRAIL (a.k.a., but unknown to me.. DRAGON BACK TRAIL)… I proceeded to continue along a very flat pathway along the mountain to TAI TAM GAP and i wasted 40 minutes, its a nice view and easy walk but you don't get to the mountain top - ever.The rest of the walk is a series of vertical stairs and rocky pathways. I recommend for those who are agile, don't have any knee or ankle injuries, and are able to walk on uneven surfaces. A few times i was required to climb with my hands on the earth for assistance so you will need to be physically strong, but not necessarily fit. The view from the top is amazing, mind blowing, surreal and magical. Below you lies the South China Sea, the Golf Course, the undulating mountain sides, the Beaches, Shek O and Big Wave Bay. Eagles catch the thermals while Paraglider's soar with the Sea Breeze. If you don't want to/can't continue along, turn around and walk back the way you came, back to SHEK O ROAD and catch Bus 9 back to the MTR.Be sure to take water and have layers of shirts to accommodate to constant changing weather and temperatures and do not wear jeans in any circumstance as you need to be comfortable and agile. The hike took me three hours (with an unfortunate detour (40 minutes), stop at Shek O Peak and return back to Shek O Road (120 minutes) and allow half an hour each way to and from Hong Kong.Remember to catch your breath at the top, and enjoy all that this beautiful country is offering you.

Nice strong wind, good climb!!. Very easy to get to, refer to discovery hong kong website. The climb up to the dragon's back wasn't too bad. Lovely view from the top. I trekked down to Tai Long Wan Bay, and met a snake along the way (and I hate snakes), so be careful..
Easy hike great views.. View was great. Easy to go on your own. There were a lot of steps midway, but manageable. generally well worth the climb.

Best hiking spot on the island side. This hike is great for the novice who wants to go for a hike. Dragon's Back offers beautiful scenic views of both sides of the island. It's too far from the harbour to see it clearly though, so that's probably not a good reason to make the climb.

A Nice Hike in HK. The reviewers are right, taking a hike on the Dragon's Back Trail is a great way to get away from the hustle and bustle of city life in HK. To get here, it's not a far journey, yet you feel as though, you are far away from the city. From research, you can make a long hike out of this, OR you can make a short hike out of this. To take the long hike, take the MTR to the Shao Kei Wan Station. Head to the bus terminal to take bus No. 9. Get off at the Cape Collision stop, where Tai Tam Gap Correctional Facility is situated. Next to the correctional facility, is a stone staircase leading up to the trail. Follow the trail and the sign “Dragon’s Back” （龍脊). After about 1 hour’s walk, you will come to the top of the mountain, and you shall see a beautiful view of the sea and mountain. Going downhill, follow the direction going to the “Shek O Road”. Once you arrive at the Shek O Road, at an area called To Dei Wan (土地灣）, take bus No. 9 back to the opposite direction and you will be back at the bus terminal where the Shau Kei Wan MTR station is.I was limited with time because of dinner plans, I chose the short way. I took the No. 9 bus, and got off at To Dei Wan. For first time visitors, in the bus, the next stop/destination will be indicated, so To Dei Wan will appear on the panel to indicate that it will be the next stop. Press the red button on the bus to let the driver know you want to get off. Once you get off the bus, there is a sign that says Dragon's Back trail.You will follow the path up, where you will go through many inclines (not to strenuous); you will walk up dirt roads and stairs. I believe it was about a 20 minute walk to reach the top. I'm a fast walker, so it may take others a bit longer. I really enjoyed this hike, it only took about 2 hours for me. I went on a weekday earlier this month, and I only saw about 2 other hikers on this trail. Also, I enjoy running, so if there are any trail runners, the Dragon's Back trail is a nice place to run as well!

Beach, hiking..what else do you want in a first class world city?. We've taken this hike too many times to count, but still keep returning. Shau Kei Wan Station/ A3, or Bus 9, or minibus to Shek-O (which is just off the MTR exist and quicker, but could wind up waiting awhile unless there's a line, which more often than not there is). Tell the driver you want to take he Dragon Back trail.Lots of views over the ocean and S/Bay of HK. Nice picnic benches on the summit of each hill.Can be a bit crowded on prime weather days, but even then it's not overwhelming.Most of the hike is pretty flat, making it good for all ages.You can get lunch at either Big Wave Bay or Shek-O depending on which direction you walk. Better food at Shek-O.

Breathtaking view. It is an excellent way to have a workout whilst still on holiday. We enjoyed the fresh air and panaromic view. We were very touched by 'jogger' , I believe he is a local, who actually waited for us to ensure that we hit the right trail back to the road

Dragon's Back Trail. This trail offered a wonderful respite from the hustle and bustle of the shopping areas. It was beautiful at the top. Went on a Monday and had the trail practically to ourselves. It was quiet,peaceful and scenic. The hike was not at all difficult. Very relaxing and enjoyable. There were little bits on the hike where it was a little slippery. Otherwise, it was very manageable.

Great time if u love nature.. I went for a hike at the Dragon Back Trail in Dec 2012. The hike was quite easy except for the many stairs from the start. The sights was beautiful overlooking the coastal areas. It took me about 2hrs (was expecting 3hrs) to complete the hike - and I am not a avid hiker. The place is quite quiet and is a good place to get away for the buzz in the city. Only caution is that the place could be muddy and slippery in winter.
Walking. Good walk to do to get away from then city. q uiet iet a lot of steps, took a couple of hours. Fantastic fviews on a clear day.

Hong Kong Must. Sure Hong Kong is known for its Skylines and skyscrapers, but it really has a lot more to offer. The Dragon's Back hike was one of the highlights of our trip. Not only did it allow us to explore a side of the island not many take the time to see, it also gave us some spectacular views. Get our your runners and hit the trails!

Beautiful views over Shek O. The walk is a wonderful escape from bustle of commercial Hong Kong. It gives you the opportunity to find the wind in your hair while taking in the beautiful views to both sides of the path.
Easy hike with amazing views. The best trail on Hong Kong island and not too difficult. End it with a dip at Big Wave Bay beach and don't forget your camera: the views from the tops are stunning.
great walk, good views. We went on the Hong Kong Walks tour which I recommend. The guide tooks us there by tram, bus, and subway. It is a fairly strenuous walk.

one of the best hikes in HK. great hike to get started or as an introduction to Hong Kong. the best thing is it ends up near shek o village where you can get some great thai food after you work up an appetite on the hike

Go during the weekdays! Enjoy. Best views ever, very easy walk, with a few steep parts. The views are exhilarating! There is a fun steep walk all the way down to a beach by one of the bus pick-ups, the beach is called "deity beach" it is like stepping back in time, except that the beach is some sort of sailing club? There are Hobie Cats everywhere. There was a little cafe, but no one spoke English. We were able to get a coke. Worthwhile if you are here for awhile. Dragon-back is a must! The weekdays are less crowded.

Great Hike but too many people!. When I lived here, I used to do this trail and the preceding segment of the HK Trail at least twice a month. Its a nice walk and there is some decent scenery, just try to avoid the umbrella carrying crowd.
Nice Hike. Really nice hike with my husband. Ended on the beach. Really beautiful views from the top of the mountains. Not too hard, maybe next time we will bring the kids.

Wonderful family hike. We were at Dragon's back with our kids, aged 7 and 4 this past weekend. The weather is finally cooler and the hiking season starts. This trail was crowded but still very enjoyable. What I also like about this trail is that it starts half way up the hill so it's relatively flat on top hence very manageable for kids. Our kids hiked the entire length for slightly over 3 hours. I did carry the 4 year old for a few minutes in the last hour but he was happy to walk on his own for the remainder of the trail. We also made a game of finding the 'blue dots" on rocks (trail markers) and the kids loved it. The view over Shek-O is always georgeous. We have also seen people paragliding on these hills before. Take the No. 9 bus from Shau Kei Wan MTR station and tell the driver to stop at the Trail head in Shek O road. Once on top, you can follow the sign back to Shek O Road (Tau Dei Wan) direction or all the way to Shek O beach (Tai Tam direction). Parking hear the trail head is almost impossible so i don't recommend driving.If you only have time for 1 hike in HK you should seriously consider this one. I have done it 4-5 times over the last 8 years and the view is always impressive from the top. If you do this hike in the winter months do bring a wind breaker. It gets chilly with the wind on top.

Awesome! . A rly nice walk. Im not a hiker and never done any walks and only the day before yesterday decided (whilst in hk on business, as u do) to buy some walking shoes and a rucsac and pack it full of ray mears type equipment (spare tops, matches, food, water...2litres, plasters, mozzie spray etc!). Prob a little over the top but like i say I've never hiked and for all i know i cld be on some mountain rescue program from falling! Anyway, the hk mtr is easy to navigate. I took a taxi from shau kai Wan to the start of the hike on shek o road. Taxi was hkd43. Cld hv took a bus but the queue was miles long.Up the very first steep hill at the start of the hike i was huffing away and realising why i don't hike!That said, the trail was rly good. It was steep in places and the paths can be a danger if ur clumsy like me and don't lookwhr u put ur feet on the uneven ground. The views are awesome.Yes, the trail is busy and full of ppl so don't check reviews then be surprised how busy it is!I finished in big wave bay which was bit naff compared to othr beaches I've seen but u can get a hotdog, beer and chill after ur walk.Id advise leaving before it starts getting dark. The bus queue was bad. I waited about 80mins, and don't think u can get the bus further down the road and walk away from the queue. I tried that to beat queues but the buses don't stop. Just queue and live with it.I set off at 1215 midday in 33 degree heat. Im mid 30s and abt average fitness and it wasn't a hard walk by any means.Def do it if u have a day and want to get out the city (but maybe not away from ppl!)

Wonderful way to see HK views!. A beautiful hike, especially if you go in the eastern direction and work your way down to Shek O afterwards for a beer on the beach and snacks. However, if you arrive at the beach on a Sunday, beware, the bus and taxi lines can be BRUTAL. The hike isn't too strenuous and in parts is mostly steps. The views on a clear day are spectacular, so bring a camera. No amenities along the way like water, etc., so come stocked up.

Just outside the city, easy trail, and great view.. Also known as Hong Kong Trail, I consider this a fairly easy, straightforward trail to get to and complete. The first half of the walk is shaded and tranquil, and the second half you're in the sun, but with great views - despite the smog. It's not a loop, and if you start from Cape Collision Rd the entrance is across the road, up a set of narrow stairs. The trail ends at Shek O Rd, but if you wish there are other trails that splinter off to neighboring towns. As soon as you finish the hike, you'll see a bus stop on both sides of the street. Cross the road to get the bus back to the terminal. See below:To the starting point:MTR Shau Kei Wan Station Exit A3 and take Bus 9 for Shek O at the Shau Kei Wan bus terminus, making sure to get off at Cape Collinson Road. From the ending point:Take Bus 9 at Shek O Road near To Tei Wan Village back to the Shau Kei Wan bus terminus.

Great easy hike with great ending. Been on this hike many times and even took my parents on this hike and they loved it. After a relaxing hike down to Big Wave Bay you can either get some nice food and beers on the beach or head to Shek O for more swimming/slightly more upscale food.
