Great (half) day out with lovely views. This is a well marked walk & it's easy to reach on public transport. The views are wonderful & the walk isn't tough (though some level of fitness is required). However, I did this on a national holiday & there was almost a continuous 'snake' of people following the trail so it's good to pick your day or else start really early. Otherwise if you think you're getting away from the crowds of Kowloon & Central you may be disappointed! If you do this as a morning trip there are lots of places for lunch near Shau Kei Wan MTR station on the way back.

Excellent views. The dragon's back is a hike i've been meaning to do every time that i have been to HK, and this trip i eventually got round to completing it. The hike was fairly hilly in areas, the views were great and we ended up at big wave beach and treated ourselves to a well deserved drink and icecream.

A super hike. This hike is not too hard and is beautiful. The views are great. The path can get a little crowded. A rarity for HK, there are not too many stairs on this one, so it is a more pleasant hike than most.

Good hike and provides a good view of different side of Hong Kong. Was able to get to the starting point by subway/bus. Please sure you have small changes (take only exact change or so $7HKD) for the bus ride. We started on the back end of the Dragon back and walked towards where most people start. The hike does have steep sections and at the end it is mostly flat. Took about 1 1/2 to 2 hours to complete the hike. Make sure you bring water - views are amazing!!

Awesome Break from the City. So glad we took the time to do this hike. It was fun getting there by city bus, just a short ride away and its hard to believe you're so close to one of the world's major cities! The views of the coast and the vegetation are all amazing, it can be quite windy which cools you down in the summer. The hike is easy enough for anyone to do it. Would definitely recommend if you have a few days in Hong Kong, we were only there 3 days and are glad that we took half a day to do this.
Fun but need to be in good shape. You must be in good shape to do this, and remember to go to the Thai food place after, just ask around everyone knows it :)

Great views from this walk.. Toilets at the start aren't great but the walk is well worth doing with fabulous views along the way. When you get to the end catch a bus along to the beach at Shek-o. Take a picnic though you may be able to get BBQ.

great trip, stunning views. With the hike you escape the busy Hong Kong and you can find your inner peace again. At the end of the walk just across the road you can take ANOTHER 'few' steps (15-20 min) to have a swim at a deserted beach! Just great to relax and enjoy
A great walk. Fabulous walk, not to strenuous, clearly signposted, with great views, and can end with dinner and drinks in Shek O

Great hike. This hike was more strenuous than my friend and I imagined. We are both athletic, however, and appreciated traveling along the spine of some of Hong Kong Island's more rural bits. I recommend you bring a swimsuit so that you can visit the Shek-O beach afterwards for a swim. The Thai restaurant at the intersection at Shek-O is also popular with the local expat scene. We enjoyed it too.

Fabulous walk - worth the effort !. this route is perfect for families - if you are feeling energetic you can take the steeper route (left turn coming from Tai Tam starting point / Correction centre) or the lower route (less spectacular views) for an easier stroll. Highly recommend the steep climb up - views are wonderful and often there are microlight fliers which are fun to watch. Walk down to the road afterwards and take a relaxing casual lunch in Shek O. Great way to spend a day out for everyone.

Wow a must see. We did this hike and then went to Shek o beach. The hike was moderate intensity with some nice flat walks mixed in. The incline at the beginning makes it seem harder than it is. There was a walk about 10 minutes up a steep hill then a nice walk along a very well maintained trAil. There were some springs you had to get over by climbing a few rocks but they were easy. We saw lots of birds and a ton of butterflies. Then there was the dragons back Part with rocks and lots of steps but again it was not bad. We don't work out and were out of breath a couple spots but there were lots of scenic parts to look out at the view and rest. Shek o beach was perfect after to cool off And rest. It is a beautiful beach and the water was clean when we visited.

Beautiful trek for tourists and beginners. I'm a hiking enthusiast, and been on several treks in HK island, including Lantau trail, McLehose, Wilson trail and a few more which don't have any name. Dragon's Back stands out for its beautiful views, still being pretty close to the city. If done reversed you can relax on the beautiful Shek O beach near the start point. Clear day is a good time to visit, when you can get some pretty views. Recommended for beginners, or people visiting Hong Kong. trek time, ~1.5-2 hours.

Very nice Hike!. This is a fantastic , easy hike that lasts about 2-3 hours. During the hike, you have great views over the sea. I would highly recomend this hike for all, but not when its too hot as it will be less enjoyable to hike. At the peak it iswonderful as you have very strong winds, cooling you down. Great Hike and would highly recommend it!
Up , up and away.... So close to the bustling city,but very easy to get to and you feel leagues away. Fantastic 2 to 3 hour walk, with great views over lands and the seas,

great hike. but don't do it during summer, it's exposed so it can get very hot. take along lots of water, good hiking shoes and a cap...the beauty of it is you end up by the beach so you can go for a lovely dip after the hike. Gorgeous views from up there and loads of people para sailing above you.

Fabulous Walking Trails. We walked the Dragon's back in reverse (starting at Chai Wan and walking up through the Cemetary). Be sure to take plenty of water. The walk is fairly easy but has several uphill sections and the heat & humidity is not to be under-estimated. At the end of the walk, take a taxi to Shek O and enjoy a dip in the sea or have lunch at one of the many street restaurants which are very inexpensive compared to Central HK.

Great view on both sides. On a clear day - you get to see TaiTam bay and Shek-O / BigWave bay, on what is, in the end, a fairly easy hike - you can take shortcuts to avoid most of the steps and just go for the view !

Makes you wanna do it every weekend. When i went there i had only been in Hong Kong for a few weeks and i had only been walking on its grey pavements. I joined this local friend of mine and another foreigner like me: we took the mtr to shau kei wan (where i recommend to snack around if you feel hungry) and then a bus to the beginning of the path.We took the short way - 2hrs - cause we didn't want to be home after sunset but if i were to go there again i'ld go for the long one.It's not a difficult hike (there were some elderly too) and it's completely worth it: once we got on the top of the dragon's back an looked down to the blue ocean my heart fell! I couldn't imagine such natural beauty next to one of the most modern financial districts in the world!

Dragons Back Hike. This is a great get away hike on Hong Kong Island, that is so close to a very busy Urban centre. There are many ways to do the hike, either with guides, we were with Walk Hong Kong, as we enjoy the knowledge and extra tip bits a guide can pass on. But this is a well maintained trail, with lovely vegetation, and also awesome views of the South China Sea, on the clear day you can see some distances. Highly recommend. Half day, easy to fit into schedule, plus a quick trip down to Shek O, is worth the effort - lunch at the Chinese - thai style restaurant, seems to be the one to go to, but others also there.

This hike is definitely worth the time commitment to get there. Once rated Asia's best hike by Time Magazine, I completely understand why and strongly suggest you get away from touristy parts of HK Island and see the Island from a diferent view point.To get to the trail by MTR you get off at Shau Kei Wan MTR (筲箕灣) and connect to the Shau Kei Wan Bus Terminus to take the #92 KMB bus to Cape Collinson Road. There is a pagoda over looking the apartment buildings below the hill you overlook and a cemetery on the hill. Don't walk there and instead keeping walking along Cape Collinson Road in the direction fo the bus and you will see a flight of stairs that says "Shek O Country Park and from thereonin the signs are very easy to follow. The hike took me about 2 hours, and the first quarter to third is shaded. And then the vistas begin once you get out of the shrubs and trees blocking your view. From thereonin you are exposed to the elements but treated to a challenge up and down path with vistas on both sides. It can be pushingly hot, so bring water,a hat and definitely wear sunscreen if it's a sunny day. But the view of the South China Sea, Shek O town, and the skyscrapers in the distance are unbeatable. After you reach the end of the path you will find yourself on Shek O Road. From there you can wait for another bus across the street to get back to Shau Kei Wan (the bus stop on your side will not take you to the MTR stop). I didn't take the KMB bus back - in fact I hopped in a public light bus (or 'siu baa') back to the subway station for just a few HKD. Not a scam, but a legitimate alternative form of transport mostly used by locals.Overall, for those not afraid of some sun, and some walking. A great intro to the wonderful hiking HK has to offer.

Nice and easy hike. Dragon's back lies on the east of Hong Kong island. Easy to hike with breathtaking view. However, during my visit there are haze/midst covering most of the view. I took the Hong Kong trail and end up at Tai Long Wan village beach. Had a nice stroll at the beach before going back by public bus number 9 to Shakeiwan before taking the MTR back to Mong kok. Nice!

Beautiful, but more challenging than other reviews would lead you to believe!. The views from the Dragon's back are absolutely stunning and breathtaking! It is definitely worth the hike. I do feel that we were mislead about how "easy" the trail was to hike. The reason the trail is called the "Dragon's back" is because it curves up and down the top of the mountain and it looks like it is the back of a dragon. These are not gentle hills, they can be quite steep in areas (both going up and down). There are stairs in some areas and just steep dirt with occasional rocks in others. The trail is also in full sun with very little shade. On a clear day, the heat can be almost unbearable. Pack plenty of water and hats/umbrella's for shade. I sweat through all of my clothing! After completing the section known as the Dragon's back, there are other paths that are much more level and less challenging- although the terrain on the trail is far from even. We travelled through mud, rocks, twigs, roots, and over waterfalls to reach our final destination. It was a beautiful hike, but we had to constantly watch our footing to avoid tripping or falling off the cliff. :) We had read other reviews on trip advisor stating that this trail would be good for all families. Let me tell you, it is not meant for the younger crowd. I ended up carrying my son up the hills. I am at a moderate to high fitness level, and I found this trail to be a little difficult. My knees and ankles were sore the next day. If you have 3 hours to kill, this is a great experience...just be aware of what you are getting yourself into.
AWESOME VIEWS. Some of the most breathtaking views in Hong Kong. Hike is not all that challenging though the final step down into Big Wave Bay can be a pain.

Great trail for anyone. i went on a Saturday morning. It wasn't too crowded. I saw plenty of people, but for the most part I was hiking alone. The trail is pretty simple and nice. It is pretty hilly, so be ready for stairs, but nothing anyone who can put one foot in front of another couldn't handle. the views are great, but it was really hazy when i went. it was also extremely hot (probably because of the day I decided to go). Be prepared with water because you aren't going to find any on the trail.

Fantastic hike and great views. Fun and easy hike that takes 2-3 hours. My wife and I did it even though we are totally out of shape. It just took us a little longer than the rest, but the views are worth the effort. It is a great activity to take a break from business/city activity

great hike though a bit crowded. Time magazine (not TimeOut magazine!) rated this the top urban hike in asia a few years ago -- and it delivers on the promise. Though like any other popularized location, it's quite crowded on weekends, but I guess it comes with territory.On a very sunny day, shade is a bit lacking, but the views are fantastic and the hike is a lovely escape from the usual concrete jungle.

A great hike. Absolutely a great hike. Fun to get there. Various lengths and difficulties, but none approaching "technical" great destinations if you want to go down to Big Wave bay and have a primo lunch after you have burned off 1600 calories in a three hour hike. Avoid it in the summer. Unless you don't mind the heat in which case bring plenty of water and pace yourself.
an easy hike with breathtaking views. if you're a beginner at hiking, i suggest you start here. fairly easy even kids can do it. the view at the top is amazing. take a camera.

Great Views from above. We started from Shek O ..fairly steep but not hard for about 1km then we went on the dragon's back trail. As the name implies, the up and down trail on the dragon's back is about 1km long. Beautiful views on both sides of the peninsula. Saw many species of butterflies along the way. The heat and humidity was brutal during the summer months for hiking so probably nicer to do this when its a little cooler. At the other end of dragon's back trail back to tai tam, it was comparatively flat over 2km. We then took the bus #14, to Stanley for lunch and shopping at Stanley Market.

Excellent view and easy walk. Depending on one's fitness this walk can be slightly difficult or too easy too short. Either way it is worth going at least once to admire the beautiful view of the south of Hong Kong Island.
Amazing respite from busy HK. Beautiful scenery. best to go early or late in the day to avoid summer heat. Easy to get to by taxi. Just right distance and not too demanding ascend.

great open views. Like that its a quick walk from the bus stop and the walk is exactly on the crest of all peaks to the end of the peninsula. Open views of Tai Tam, Stanley and the other side to Shek O
Excellent Hike. I have done most of the hikes and trails in HK and this is easily one of the best.

Clear day is a must!. Not as strenuous as advertised and not particularly high (284m) but the views are absolutely fantastic. Its the perfect little day out:Start at Central - get the tram to Shau Kei Wai* and enjoy the hustle and bustle of the city from the tram - get the bus to the starting point - see beautiful views of HK's beaches and islands on Dragon's Back - finish at Shek O beach for a beer/swim/lounge.One of my favourite days here tbh

Great way to break up a city break. You can get a taxi there from mid lands - less than $US20 and. Its a great little trek that isnt too taxing and gives you a terrific overview of the island. Its worth a little hassle to get there.

A nice hike during a HK visit. You can take the MTR out of Central and a short bus ride and be on the trail in less than an hour. While not a long trail (maybe 5K and hiking time of 90 mins or so depending on pace) it is scenic and follows a ridge with lots of nice overlooks across to Stanley and many of the area bays. This doesn't require being a dedicated hiker and I saw young children and casual hikers on the trail as well as a few rather intrepid mountain bikers. A nice respite from the busy city and a good alternative for the business traveler in the area looking for some exercise away from the street level.

'Best city trail' for a good reason. So Dragon's back has been voted the best trail within city limits across the world and I completely appreciate why so. It's the last part of a much larger trail that extends across HK island. It is a very good walk not taxing at all and even people who don't exercise regularly can complete this within 3 hours. Dragon's back is easily accessible from the central part of HK by taxi, bus and MTR. One can reach the Shau Kei Wan MTR station within 15 mins from CBD, from there bus no 9 takes you to Shek O road, get off at the stop 12 mins into the journey near the correctional facility. Start the climb from where the board indicates. The intial steps are steep after which the trail is uphill but along a well trodden path, follow directions to the Dragon's back trail when you come to a Y fork. An hour or so into the trail you'll reach another T where one path goes to Dragon's back whereas the other goes to Big Bay (if I'm not mistaken). From here you follow the path to the top of Dragon's back taking in wonderful vistas on both sides. The way down from the trail is much faster (and hence tougher if you are coming up as it's steeper) and you'll end up once again further down on Shek O Road. From here you can take bus # 9 headed to Shau Kei Wan MTR or a minibus headed that way. Alternatively you can easily go to Stanley for a much deserved beer and lunch. Do make your way out to 3 hours of scenic beautiful exercise when in HK.

Great easy hike with fantastic views.. I have hiked Dragon's Back numerous times. As an avid hiker, I feel this is easy and great for families and people with good basic fitness. I have two children - ages 6 & 9 ad they are able to hike it without any problems. The hike can be anywhere from 5 - 8 KM long, depending on your start and stopping points. The views are gorgeous on a clear day. After this hike, I usually walk to Shek O beach and eat at my favorite Thai restaurant and hang around at the beach (though Big Wave Bay is closer). Definitely one of my favorite activities to do with my family.
A different view of HK. Nice walk of medium intensity with fantastic views over HK. Finish at the beach and have a swim.

Possibly the most scenic hike in the region. Took an afternoon hike on the Dragon's back today. Bad choice to have started at 1pm as it was still really hot but hey, the view was well worth it. I figured the best way would be to take the Island Line to Shau Kei Wan and take bus 9 at the bus terminal right outside exit A3. The bus takes you to the start of the Hong Kong walking trail along Collision road. Follow the trail all the way and soon, you will be greeted by unbelievable scenary.

Breathtaking views!. My 13yo and I did this walk on a humid, but sunny Hong Kong Day and thoroughly enjoyed it. We began at Shek O Road, and while there are quite a few stairs at the beginning, it gave us a good workout without being too strenuous. The spectacular views across Shek O and Tai Tam Bay make it well worth the effort. Some of the terrain is a little rough so good walking shoes or sport sandals are a must and definitely pack a sizable bottle of water. The walk took us about 2.5hrs as we took it fairly easy and finished up with a late lunch at the beachside cafe at Big Wave Bay. Minibuses from the carpark back to Shek-O and Shau Kei Wan MTR are very regular. This hike is a must for any HK visitor.

A walk of a lifetime!. Well worth the time to get there. Take the bus to Stanley, then transfer to the number 14 and then the 9 to the end of the route at Big Wave Bay. Just ask the bus drivers they or a local will be glad to help. Follow the signs tot he Hong Kong Trail, and follow it to the Dragon's Back. The views and breeze are well worth the effort it takes to get there, as well as many waterfalls. Bring water, and an umbrella (for shade, or rain protection) This takes about 2-3 hours depending on your pace, skill, heat, and how long you just want to sit and take in the breathtaking views.

Amazing hike on Hong Kong Island with stunning views. On a sunny day, dragons back is an amazing hike with great views and can end with a swim and sunbathe on one of Hong Kong's best beaches - big wave bay.
Escaping Concrete. Great views, and a little more "off the beaten track" in that not every path is paved and concreted.

South China Sea. Excellent walk with great views of the South China Sea. It was a bit difficult to find the start though. We wondered up from the underground but got lost and had to have a local point the route start out to us. On way back the bus stops to get back where fairly clear though. My tip is take instructions as when you get off the underground don't expect it to be signposted.

Where the Europeans hike!. What amazed me is that there was not a single candy wrapper in sight during this lovely trip. Remember to bring plenty to fluids. At the end of the hike, take the bus to Sheck-O Beach.

Walk Hong Kong Walking Tour. I enjoyed the Dragons Back Trail on Hong Kong Island. It was a hike that most day hikers would enjoy. The skill level needed is low but enough of a challenge to excercise your lungs. The views from the trail are breath taking. I would recommend Walk Hong Kong walking tours. Martin H. was our guide. He provided us with enough history and local facts to make the hike more iteresting that striking out on your own

Best views of HK from top of Dragon's Back. You'll need a medium level of fitness to complete the 1.45 min Dragon's back trail as there are some steep parts but it's not too strenuous. This is a side to HK that you'll never expect. It's a beautiful walk through a well maintained track and lush green forest. Once you get to the top of the Dragon's Back you have spectacular views on both sides and many photo opportunities. In my opinion, well worth it.

Wonderful Hike!!. We used to live on this side of the city and we always take visitors to hike this trek. You'll see parasailing, stunning views, and a beautiful golf course. Drop down and go straight to Thai Sheko Restaurant for a beer and fab food! It's part of the Dragon Back experience!

Great views for little work. A nice hike away from the hustle and bustle. Take sun screen and pack lots of water. The tourist Info office has a great handout on this and other hikes in the area.The hike takes about 3 hours and ends on a nice beach so bring your swimmers.
Stunning Views. It can be a challenging hike if completed. I suggest doing parts of it if you are a casual hiker! :)

The Ultimate Urban Hike. The dragon's back is a "little" (~ 5KM) hiking trail that gives you awesome views of multiple sides of the island. It is not that steep and requires no special equipment to climb it. When I went in January, it was not crowded at all.

An easy hike with brilliant views. What a wonderful way to see another dimension to Hong Kong! Dragon's Back is a very easy hike, being paved the entire way. There are plenty of pagodas along the way with benches so you can rest often and enjoy the views. There are many downward stairs though, so not suitable for those with weak knees
wonderful trail!. Wow, that was a wonderful trail!! I did not expected to have enjoy so much and to get such a perfect view of Hong Kong! It is definitely recomended!

Scenic walk at a good location. Short taxi ride from city centre so it is pretty easy to get to.
Perhaps in the average level of difficulty in terms of steepness, therefore it can be quite a good work out. The path can be quite bumpy and rocky. Once you get to the top, the view of Shek O is amazing.
Bring plenty of water!
Escape the city. Ask at HK tourist centre for a map and transport links. Great hike which finishes at HK's best beach.

Fabulous views, easy hike. A really refreshing hike (c. 3 miles, quite a bit of up and down hill as the name implies) after the hustle and bustle of Central or Kowloon and a surprising side of Hong Kong that appears to be entirely built up. Trail is well marked and there is a regular bus service that will drop you at the start and collect from the finish. Close to Stanley for a worthwhile visit before or after. Magnificent view of the sea on both sides as you approach the peak.

If you are aching for Nature. Tire of shopping? After days of walking around malls we were aching for some greenery and nature. Dragon's Back did the trick. Beautiful scenery all the way to the trailhead and the hike to Dragon's back is quite stunning with water views on both sides. Afterwards you must go to Shek-O village and eat at the Thai/Chinese restaurant. Order Thai base food because it was one of the best meals we had within the 3 weeks of travel throughout Asia.

Definitely reccomend.. Easy yet gorgeous! And just long/short enough to break into a light sweat and end up on two of the nice beaches of HK island. The views from the top of the hill are brilliant. Worth a pit stop and pictures with the friends and family. Best part is that its not too crowded at all so you still get the whole outdoorsy adventure feel.

great workout, great views to southern beaches. a different experience of Hong Kong through the network of country trails. you can take this trail all the way to surfing beaches in Shek O, or you can walk along the catchwater for a flatter route to Stanley. Bring your own water.
Hong Kongs best hike. excellent hike, can end up at Shek O beach or Big Wave bay..stunning views of the peninsula

Dragon's Back - a nice afternoon out.... The Dragon's back is a great hike and a great way to get out of the city without having to travel too far from the central part of HK. It is quite strenuous in bits though, and bring plenty of water if it's sunny/hot.

Wilderness just outside of town. My local friends took me on a hike on the Dragon's Back. It was a clear day with a breeze. We had wonderful views and had a chance to watch the hang gliders sail about.

Great half a day trip. Dragon's back is an easy half a day trip that show's the less civilized and amazing scenery of the once uninhabited island.The road is very originized and marked and is suited for young children. Make sure you take enough water - no place to fill them up.I recommend going on top of the mountain and not the 2/3 road the view is much better there.Where ever you go you should pass through the Shek'o'peak.Getting to the dragon's back is simple - take the subway to the east most station (chai wan) and from there take a taxi to the start of the road. If all the track is too long you may cut off in the middle and go down to the nearest road and catch a bus from there.to conclude, a must for anyone who can walk..

Great Hike. Date Visited: March 31 SatTime: noonweather: Somewhat sunny in the day at night it got windyI would rate this hike a 5 out of difficulty. The beginning of the hike is pretty flat until you get caught up with an incline of stairs. The stairs to me was the hardest part.Once you get up the view was amazing.... even on such the cloudy day that we went.The hike took approx 2 hours. Make sure you wear proper shoes and have plenty of water.Defn check out Shek O Village when your finished.
strenuous hiking not for everyone. There is good view but some slopes are steep and it can be windy.
A glorious hike with matching views. An excellent hike to do on a beautiful day. Make sure you end up in Shek-O for a bite to eat at the Thai restaurant with a few cold beers. Doesn't get much better

Wonderful views and a great hike.. Another must do if you are in the area. It's not too difficult, (although make sure you wear some decent shoes). The views are amazing, and you can take your time getting some good pictures. I wish I had gotten started earlier in the morning so I could see the sunrise, but it was still worth the trip.
Great Hike, Great Views!. A great hike with great views of the South China Sea. Give yourself time and be prepared for lots of stairs. Best done in the cool season (October-April).

Good track for a half-day walk. A group of us did the track covering about 8km within 3hours. The track is not tough but with enough difficulty to give someone who's not used to walking/exercise a good workout.The only part which wasn't so nice was the fog. Covered our view for most part of the walk. Get adequately prepared with raincoats so you can keep dry in case of rain.

Great escape from the city!. This hike is well worth the effort. Great views and the whole time you will think "I can't believe this is in Hong Kong!" If you're looking for some nature, this is where you'll find it.

Good urban hike. We took this trail upon a friend's recommendation. It's a very doable walk for those looking for a simple hike. And you really get the feeling you're out of town even though 'town' is all around you!

Great little hike. The views are really amazing and it's technically very easy though physically it is a little more demanding though well worth it and if you go to the big wave you can have an amazing guilt free dinnr

Enjoyable. Not a strenous walk by any means, although there are some stairs & hills. Definately take a jacket , as it was very cold with the wind on top the hills when there was no tree cover.A great view over part of the Island that you would not really see if you didnt do this walk.Very refreshing away from the city.No 9 bus from Shau Kei Wan MTR station (Island line), it will drop you at the start of walk & there is the bus stop at end to pick you up again to take you back to the station, or catch a taxi.

Probably the best Sunday Walk ever!. The Dragon's Back is one of the most popular walks in Hong Kong - and for good reason: It is a good way to work up an appetite, yet it's not as challenging as some routes on Lantau Island for example. The views are simply magnificient! And at the end of it all, you can enjoy a great lunch in the charming village of Shek O.Always a winner!
A great hike for all abilities. Super views and a satisfying trail, well sign posted with plenty of rest stops. Varied scenery- high hills and deep forests and ending up in the little beach villages.

One of the best hikes in Hong Kong. Start at the 83km trail mark oin the main road and make your way up and over the mountain ridge with views eastward to the beaches and ocean, and westward to the inland bay. Then watch out for the right turn point and hike into light forest for a while and finally a steep downhill section to Big Wave Bay. Takes 2.5-3 hours if you take your time and stop for snacks, photos along the way. Popular trail too.If you fing this review helpful, please give it a helpful vote. Thanks!

Trail running/hiking with great views!. I ran/hiked part of the Hong Kong trails along the Dragon's Back. Great views from up there and a beach waiting at the end of your walk. You can go down to Shek O or Big Wave Bay beaches. It's great to be out in the nature such a short distance from the bustle of Central.

Dragon's Back Guided Walk. This is for people who are used to quite steep and rocky terrain. It takes about three hours and has magnificent views of the surrounding coastline. Well worth doing in Spring or Autumn not Summer or Winter.
A terrific Hike. Not the easiest hike,but one worth it! We started at south entrance of hike and went north...much easier!

A easy hike - great with kids!. An easy hike that offers great views off the back of the island - looking down at Shekou and Big Wave bay. Often see parasailers launching off the East facing slope. At the end of the hike you can catch bus into Shekou for a great Thai meal (They have ice cold wash cloths that feel great after a hike) - and the San Miguel beer is COLD!

Great Views & Easy Hike. An easy hike for most people, with a great seaside view across the western side of Hong Kong Island.Access to start a challegne, suggest taxi, and also a little windy which made it a little cool. Well signposted like majority of climbs here in HK.

perfect day out with family. This is one of the hikes that you can do with children. We have done it several times (our youngest one being 7).Views are spectacular, the trail is well groomed although you really need to wear good walking shoes.Bring enough water, certainly on hot days, since there are no drinks or food stalls along the way at all.For kids it is nice that you arrive on the beach if you go all the way to the end of the trail. At big wave beach there is a small restaurant on the beach that serves some decent beach food (salads, pizza) and cool drinks at reasonable prices.
Best hike in HK. Amazing views - great hike. Always a great thing to do on the weekend and recommend to all friends visiting HK to do this hike!

Great hike. Best not during summer.. One of the things we love about Hong Kong island is that there are plenty of 'green options' considering how small and densely populated the island is. Walking up the Dragon's back is not only a great exercise and a great way to meet people on the trail, it is also an opportunity to discover great views of Hong Kong. It's a fantastic all-year activity, but best if you avoid Summer and the high temperatures as you may end up insolated.

A must-visit.. Dragon's Back is one of the easiest hiking trails in Hong Kong with an amazing view of the south central and eastern view of Hong Kong island. Take the MTR till Chai Wan and then a taxi till the starting point of the trail. After a brief walk in the woods, you reach the top from where you walk on the ridge shaped like a Dragon's Back. The view of the Golf courses, Shek-O beach and South China Sea is beautiful. Recommendation - Just at the end of the ridge when the trail turns down to the Shek-O road, go further on the untrodden path. You'll find a huge rocks on the hillside where you can get the best view of the whole trail as well as Shek-O.

Very nice hike. In the middle of the Aguillar peninsula on the Hong Kong island, the Dragon's Back is one of the must do hikes. Nice views, with the sea on both sides, not hard and very nice landscape.
Beautiful hike. Great views have done the hike a couple of times. It is busy on the weekends so try for a weekday hike

Satisfying 360 degree views. If your time is limited in HK, you can hike the Dragon's back in about 2 hours (maximum enjoyment for minimum effort). Save it for a clear sky day... As the name suggests, you go up and down hills but the difficulty is moderate. On hill tops, you get beautiful 360 views of mountains dropping into the seas.

Good break from the city. Hong Kong has many hiking trails and this is one of the easier and well groomed paths. There is a small village and beach you can reach from the trail.This path has many portions but it can be done in sections that suit your ability and time. There are many photo ops on the trail.There is no food or drink on the trail so bring your own lunch, snacks, water, and sunscreen. Don't forget the camera.The trail can be reached by the MTR at the Shau Kei Wan station then the bus number 9. You'll most likely see other hikers getting off at the stop to Shek O Road. Leaving the bus walk right and go up the stairs. At the top of the stairs veer right up a street and you should see the path trail marker on the right. The first portion of the trail at a normal walk will take about 2 hours. There are port o potty's at the start, middle and end of the trail. On clear days the top can get windy so bring a pullover if you intend to stop and eat.
Great view but ...... View is spectacular from the Dragon's Back itself but it is quite a long winded walk after that - not much of interest for a couple of hours and no food/drink stalls?!

Easy hike. Nothing too difficult, nothing too special. The final stairs down at the end of the trail can get a little slippery and precarious so make sure you have decent footwear - don't do this with a pair of flipflops or you will find yourself punished by the terrain.If you haven't hiked elsewhere in Hong Kong, this is an easy introduction to the heat and humidity. Views of the rest of the island are ok - not the greatest, and the first half of the trail is shaded by foliage, which is welcome but means no view of the landscape - but you're not having to trudge up endless steep climbs.On holidays and weekends this trail can get very busy - if not hiking it in the week then it's best to do it as early as you can to avoid crowds, sunburn and dehydration - I'd aim to be at the start by 9am.

Great but Challenging. This is a great trail for hikers. But you have to be fit and it is not easy to get there. If you start at Tai Tam (off the bus) then walk the trail you will finish up at Shek O. There are many very nice restaurants there with a lot of seafood and a cool beer. Worth the effort.
Chasing The Dragon. What a view! Shake off that hangover in a hike to Shek O. A must . . .

Dragons' Back - a must for visitors!. We were recommended to hike up Dragons Back when inquiring what to do in HK by the locals.It is BEAUTIFUL! and quite easy to do with 3 young children, with the youngest being only 5 years old.We climbed up some steps but alot of it were flat.We took an MTR from Central to Shau Kei Wan then took a bus 9 to Shek O. got off on the second entrance to the park which is the (To Tei Wan stop) (then returned to it after 1.5 hours of hiking)you can see more pictures on my blog:www.veryphotography.blogspot.comHope you will get a better feel for what it is like there.

a great hiking trail. if the weather permits , you can catch the trail from Tai Tam reservoir or from Happy Valley and enjoy a wonderful trail in nature . The sceneries are beautiful and it is very quiet .

Breathtaking views of Hong Kong. The two of us hiked up the trail starting at Shek O road at around 8.45 a.m. It was easy hike, just a little steep and rocky at some areas. The path has been carved nicely. There are markers to indicate positions along the way, there's no litter and it made for a very pleasant hike. It took us a little under two hours as we took our time to savour the environment and views. We finished up at the other end of the trail, and even found a picnic area on the way down.The view from the top is truly amazing. You get see the side of Hong Kong that is totally unlike the concrete jungle in the city. You'd be surprised to see how much of Hong Kong is still green.

Great views of Shek O and Big Wave Bay. This is a nice hike which is easily accessible from Chai Wan or Shau Kei Wan MTR station. Make sure you stock up on drinks at the MTR station as there is no other place to replenish until you finish the hike. We took a taxi from outside Exit B of Chai Wan MTR station to To Tei Wan Village on Shek O Road (HK$50). This is the beginning of Stage 8 of the Hong Kong trail. It’s a steep climb up from the bus stop to the ridge and the trail is well sign posted. Once you get up to the ridge, you can get excellent views over Shek O to the East, D’Aguilar Peak to the South and the Stanley Peninsular and Tai Tam Bay to the West. You can also see Junk Bay and Tseung Kwan O. As you get to the top of Shek O Peak, you will also have good views over Big Wave Bay. On the day that we hiked the trail, it was about 25 degrees and quite busy. The hike is mainly dirt track and undulating and could be slippery in the rain. The ridge section is also exposed so make sure you take a hat, sun screen and plenty of water. If it’s raining, make sure you take wet weather gear. After you drop down from Shek O Peak , the path heads at low level around Mount Collinson. This section is under the cover of trees and bamboo and the walk is relatively flat, crossing quite a few streams which were dry when we did the hike. If you do the hike from To Tei Wan Village, it is easy to curtail the hike if you’ve had enough or continue the hike if you still have energy and water. Once you hit the concrete track near Tai Tam Gap, you can either turn left towards Tai Tam Gap (and civilization) or turn right and continue on the Hong Kong trail. This section of the hike is also relatively flat as you head around Mount Collinson. There are some nice views over Chai Wan and Lei Yue Muen. At the end of the concrete track (Pottinger Gap), you will have a few options for continuing the hike. You can either take a left and head down into Chai Wan, turn left and continue on the Hong Kong trail down into Big Wave Bay or take the Pottinger Peak Country Trail around Pottinger Peak. We chose the latter which follows a concrete catchwater. There are some nice glimpses of the D’aguilar Peninsula through the bushes and you eventually get to another junction with a path for Big Wave Bay. You can get good views of the Shek O in the distance and the Dragon’s Back ridgeline that you have just walked. Finally you descend some steep steps back onto Cape Collinson Road, from where it’s a 2.2km walk back to Chai Wan MTR station.We took this walk at a leisurely pace and it took us just over 4 hours. However, you could probably do it quicker.

Dragon's Back - one of Hong Kong's great hikes. There are a number of options on this hike - we started at the Cape Collison Correctional Facility (on the left of Shek O Road, just after the roundabout) and walked to Big Wave Bay. It's about 7-8km and takes about 2-3 hours at a brisk pace. Alternatively, you could start halfway by getting off the bus/taxi about halfway down Shek-O Road, just after a car park on the right and with a toilet and concrete paving on the left, leading up to some stairs. Bring lots of water as there's nowhere to fill up and some protection from the sun as it's quite exposed. The hike takes you along the top of a north-south ridge so there's a decent climb up and climb down to start/end the hike and some up and down during, plus magnificent views either side - back to Tai Tam Harbour to the west and across to Big Wave Bay and the coastline on the west. Finish at one of the Big Wave Bay restaurants for some cheap beers and hearty local food, or head to Ben's Beach Bar on the back beach of Shek O to get away from the crowds at the main beach of Shek O.

Easy to get to, stunning views. Following the directions of other reviewers (MTR Shau Kei Wan take Bus #9 to Collison Cape OR MTR to Chai Wan and Bus #16... ask to be dropped off at the Sai Wan War Cemetery, and then hike up to the intersection... hang a left, and the park entrance is on your left), we set out this morning... it was hot and sunny, but well worth. When you get off the bus, you might want to double back to the intersection behind you, and visit the Chinese cemetery. As well, you might want to visit the Commonwealth War Cemetery, located just a wee bit further down the road. From the original bus stop, you will see a Park sign and markers indicating that the trail starts on your left. You'll begin walking up a set of stairs to a car park, then followed a paved road, until the cut off to the trail. The initial climb to the trail is steep but easy to climb with solid footings. Proceed along the trail (relatively flat, a few water crossings) and about 3 kilometers in, a cut off presents itself on your left. You can either a) take the cut off, and climb the steps to the top of the Dragon's Back or b) proceed on the original trail. Both come out at the same spot, though the Dragon's Back way, while more physically trying, is far more picturesque. The actual Dragon's Back is a series of peaks located in a line, so it's a bit of up and down. Frequent benches provide places to rest, and there was a great breeze at the top. Fantastic views of Stanley, and other beach towns. There were washrooms at either end, but make sure to take a lot of water with you.. it can be very warm there. It's a great HIKE, so don't expect a walk. Coming down on the peak, stairs are uneven, and I'd imagine in wet weather, slippery.Took us about 2 hours doing the Dragon's Back routing mentioned above.

Best Urban Hike in Asia - Ride on Dragon Back. Take MTR to Shau Kei Wan exit A3 to the bus terminus. Take Bus 9 and alight at To Tei Wan (BusStop 12). The entrance is to the walking trail is few steps from the bus stop.Bring your camera and water. 2-3 hours hike which can end at Tai Tam or Big Wave Bay.

Bring your hiking shoes. Let me begin by saying i like to hike-so this may not be the trail for everyone. There are a LOT of stairs and inclines. There are a lot of different places to start so when i walked this trail, it took about 4 hours and started only half-way. The trail does end at a wonderful beach-so if you plan on taking a dip, start early to enjoy the sun. There plenty of great photo opportunities as you walk along the ridge of the mountains(dragon's back) as well as through some woods. You may want to bring some bug repellent as well just in case. I would definitely recommend this trail for those seeking a good workout and great views of Hong Kong.
